It's a game. A game where you take over a city however you like. Pick one of various different classes, swing/fight/sneak/talk your way to the mayor and replace him, either by force or by peaceful means. With all these various ways to win the game, you'll find yourself playing this game over and over (in a good way).

There's also mutators and traits you can toggle on and off, either making the game less luck-based or more challenging. There's also super special abilities, serving as rewards for getting good at playing said classes.

Streets of Rogue is a Roguelike Sandbox city simulation split up into multiple levels. You play a member of the resistance tasked with overthrowing the corrupt Mayor of the city. At the beginning of a run you pick your class which dictates your starting items as well as a unique optional big quest to complete. 

On each level you are given random tasks that you must complete to advance. Every third level also has a level wide event to shake things up. There are 5 groupings of these levels that make up the different biomes of the game with Mayor city being the final level. 

The selection of different classes and procedural generation gives the game a high replayability. On top of that the characters have different behaviors in relation to each other, such as thieves trying to steal from people, gang members fighting with the opposite gang on sight, and cops getting violent with just about everybody. Each task can be solved in multiple ways and additional items can be unlocked with chicken nuggets that you get for free when you level up. Also on level up you can choose from one of three random perks with additional perks able to be unlocked. 

I found Streets of Rogue to be difficult but satisfying. There is a lot to learn and sometimes you can just sit back and watch the city operate without getting involved. Playing as the different classes switches things up significantly enough that no two runs every really feel the same. Its a fun game that can be played at your own pace.

AWESOME GAME! From the moment I dove into its anarchic world, I found myself hooked on its easy-to-learn yet endlessly entertaining gameplay. The game's missions offer a refreshing variety of approaches, thanks to the plethora of intriguing characters at your disposal. Whether you're a stealthy hacker or a brute-force brawler, there's a playstyle tailored just for you. Plus, the option for co-op with up to four players adds an extra layer of chaotic fun!

One of the standout features of "Streets of Rogue" is its delightful humor, which infuses every aspect of the game with a lighthearted charm. From quirky character interactions to unexpected events, there's never a dull moment in this anarchic city. 

/Must-play for all fans of rogue-lite genre!/

[h2]Tight mechanics; Robust build/playstyle options; Gets stale fast[/h2]

Not worth the full asking price by a long shot. For what you get I'm feeling like this should be priced under $7 regularly. That is just my personal opinion.

It's fun, you get a cool little world and there's lots of "interactions" between various things. Everything, even NPCs have their behavioral/event scripts, and it makes the world come alive and opens up creative gameplay approaches.

For example, you can shoot a generator through a window, which might alert guards. But as the guard is charging out of the building to get you, you bait it into shooting at you and hitting a crowd behind you, which starts a huge brawl. You can then use the distraction to finish everybody off and loot them, or sneak into the building to finish whatever brought you there in the first place (breaking into a safe, retrieving something, assassinating a key enemy, etc).

There are different player classes you can unlock and play, and they really do change the way you approach the game and strategize. There are many situations and building configurations that would be approached totally differently depending on your class. For example the hacker: a much weaker fighter but can hack terminals through walls and turn off a building's security features, or set the turrets to attack everybody. Or you can be a burglar with window-cutting tools, and you'll find that all the other burglars in the maps are your friends and will fight along side you for cheap, or sell you thief tools.

You can be a "good guy" as well and avoid conflict, free prisoners and caged-animals which then join your posse to fight with you. If you build your character in a certain direction, you can keep followers from map-to-map and increase the amount that will fight with you. Point is, there are many ways to approach the game and it's totally up to the player which is so wonderful.

All in all a very fun game. Even though I have many hours in the game, really it started to fall flat around the 3rd or 4th hour of play. The game mechanics are great, the variety of semi-randomized builds you make are dynamic and robust. Love the classes. Love that the player gets to decide how to approach the game. Yet somehow I feel I figured it all out very quickly, and as much as I kept playing to unlock different things I couldn't make it [i]click[/i]. I hoped that playing more would unlock more depth but it kinda didn't? Once you figure out the world mechanics and how everything interacts, that's it. And that really doesn't take the player very long.

I think the average player will get a 2 to 3 hours of fun before they get bored. Some players will want to unlock everything and that's fine too but expect A LOT of repetition of basic gameplay. Yes the classes are great and change the way you play, but 95% of most gameplay is the same repetitive stuff regardless.

I say buy it, but hold it on your Wishlist forever and wait for that next 80% off sale.

I'll be reviewing Streets of Rogue as the stone-faced grouch that I am, beating it repeatedly solo. SoR follows the traditional rule of co-op games in that it's well made for antics with friends, especially given the chaotic nature of SoR and the synergies created by the class system.

SoR is a rogue-like top-down view action-RPG and "immersive sim with elements of Deus Ex and Grand Theft Auto." To SoRs credit it actually does a few of those things, playing like a modern homage to the older 2D GTA titles. It's a fun sandbox merged with rogue-like levels that offer multiple approaches, limited by the variety in quest design yet doing enough to grease the rogue-like problem solving gland. There's still a lot of combat, much of it unavoidable, though you can play against that.

It does immerse you nicely, though the story is total nonsense that never takes itself seriously, thankfully vanishing after the tutorial and letting the environment and soundtrack carry things. The humor works well with the variety of goofy approaches and possible situations, mostly in the class, item and level design. I'm more amused by the idea of a Gorilla or Zombie playthrough backed by wacky utility gadgets and high explosives than I am the discount weak chuckle of "we use petrified chicken nuggets as currency!" Again, it doesn't lay it on that thick after the tutorial. 

It's a shame there aren't more set characters and quests in the game, as GTA covers for a lot of repetitive mission design by making the stories surrounding them extra entertaining. SoR does this with the final level and it's more interesting then the rest, naturally. The shallow quest pool could've been smoothed over a lot with character or area specific(maybe on the X-2 levels) set pieces/quest chains with a few more involved steps and non-generic NPCs. This also gives design space to make quests that guarantee certain approaches(i.e. stealth, talking, etc) have more chances to shine, as most quests are biased towards murder. The character-specific Big Quests are an entertaining extra but mostly a starting point or bonus and the gap in level design is felt.

So for gameplay naturally you can punch and shoot your way through, a few characters getting unique abilities with some limit to use as well as consumable items that offer strong utility. If you want to be a gungho killman then by all means, or focus on ranged combat, trap setting, or some other branch of modernish magic like hacking or bartending. There's also a limited bit of talkomancy such as making it easier to complete the item swap quests, recruit/befriend people or skirt social norms. The game mostly plays smoothly, movement and targeting as well as environment interaction being intuitive. This goes hand in hand with the default state of most levels being peaceful yet tense, a living city where every entity isn't a hostile monster. Yet. Gives you time to explore and plot your actions.

The best part of the game is the multiple ways to try to approach a tough quest or emergent problem like getting spotted by cops mid-crime or having to access a single person in a crowded shop. The quests do get repetitive, a majority of them being dives into a trap-filled box with multiple rooms and 1-4 forced combat goons, so it's impressive that things stay so interesting due to the sheer number of options or the addictive desire to pull off a run with your favorite approach. This perfectly captures the feel of a game like NetHack, where traditional builds are fun but trying to force a win out of Tourist can be infinitely engaging. The difficulty rises steadily, mostly tough yet fair and like all good rogue-likes open to the great fun of breaking the game once your head is full of overly specific knowledge.

I've used a lot of "mostly"s in this review and here's why: as much as I like SoR I found the greatest flaw to be the combat. The melee combat is atrocious. It's not unusable or unplayable. It's just not a great system and you endure it to enjoy everything else. Enemies are far, far too jittery and randomly inclined to slash rapidly at you with split second reactions and no wind up. It's possible to be hit 2+ times in under a second if you botch something adjacent to anyone with a melee weapon. Gunplay is more fair, demanding sensible use of cover, but I'd seethe every time I got ping-ponged around in melee or lost 50+ health failing little jousting approaches. How it works is that the best option is to alpha strike the enemy, using assassin characters(... like assassin, vampire, etc) or fast melee that can get backstabber and avoid line of sight/hostility toggles. If combat never starts it never hurts. Sure, it's fun if you get followers going or incite characters to fight each other, set traps, use guns or abilities at range. You're just usually in a steady decline if you get into a lot of melees or a few bad ones without a cheesy source of healing. 

Sometimes the RNG is ridiculous and you die rapidly with little input, or you enter X-3 and get "hey, screw your build" disasters or loads of unavoidable damage. It's part of the rogue-like spice but getting Police Lockdown 4 out of 5 Downtowns really killed my mood. While I want to praise the visual design for having traps that actually get me they suffer from the same problem as the melee of instant hits, especially manhole covers. There's also a few class balance issues, though perhaps I just didn't gel with them all. Well OK, Werewolf having all 1s for stats and a heinous downside to less than perfect play is a real masochist choice vs a perfectly oiled stealth machine like Vampire.

To give SoR some more praise I applaud the quality of life touches everywhere. The objectives teleporter, slowdown on item use/swap, mutator system and leniency in achievement unlocking makes the dev a real lad. I definitely want to use my Big Quest rewards all game after the effort to get them! With a good mind at the helm SoR ended up a pretty good game. For $4 on sale I'm delighted, SoR being a perfect $5 game. It's a good $10-15 game and... sorry, Overwhelmingly Positive reviews, $20 is a stretch. Definitely a fair price for a polished sequel, as SoR2 looks pretty good and I'm sure Matt has learned a great deal since SoR1 released. Here's hoping for a melee overhaul!

One of the most re-playable roguelites out there.

Each floor is a small town with shops, bars, police stations etc... and you need to complete a few tasks each floor to advance. There's wide variety of different characters, all with completely unique traits and very different play styles, plus a large variety of different items (hack security systems, warp through walls, poison  air supply etc, etc), so there's a near infinite number of different way to complete any task. You can even cause conflict between npc, which is always fun.

Special events at the third floor of each area really mix up the runs to prevent you getting too comfortable as well.

If the concept of an immersive sim inspired roguelite sounds at all interesting, can't go wrong with this one.

Streets of Rogue (SoR) is a genuinely flawless co-op friendly roguelite game that deserves your support. Disclaimer: I am friends with Matt Dabrowski but I promise you that does not sway my opinion whatsoever, I just think the game is honestly amazing.

You will play as one of many classes, all of which revolve around a profession or hobby or lifestyle, and begin in the Slums with little to nothing. You will work your way up through society until you eventually reach Mayor Village, where your objective is to usurp power from him via hostility or through election. You will have various ways of completing assigned tasks before you can progress to the next floor, and you can choose how passive or aggressive you wish to be. You must survive lowly pickpockets to Blaed & Crepe gang members, the mob, and supercops.

Streets of Rogue is so much fun because of the surprising amount of choice you have over how things go. You can make the game as easy or hard for yourself depending on play styles, decisions, and routes. It's also a great game to play with a friend and like most roguelites will be significantly more doable with a partner since you can revive each other instead of just instant permadeath. The art style isn't really my thing but the combat and mechanics make up for that and it does have a nice color palette with plenty of varying locations and map designs.

The classes are all distinguished from each other and play extremely differently. The fact the game has so many endings adds to the already great replay ability. There is a huge selection of items and tools to keep things interesting. The game also features intelligent NPCs with factions that have various degrees of reputation and status with each other, making things more advanced than necessary which is a good thing.

SoR is personally my favorite roguelite I've played, but I'm not super big on this genre so feel free to point me to some others if you think they are better. I look forward to playing the sequel to this gem!

This game is amazing!! I love it so much!!! There are so many different ways to get things done with some solutions I find making me feel like I did something really cool. The kinds of solutions you go for are even more different and available depending on what character you are being, and what point in a run you are at. Resources are a little tight early on, so you gotta really think hard to get things done as safety (or as interestingly) as possible, with more and more opportunities for causing pure chaos opening later on. 

Some of my favorite runs where when I decided to knock every single person on each floor unconscious as the doctor, the one where I kept blowing people up with their own tvs as the hacker, and the one where my siblings and I banded together to create a zombie apocalypse.

P.S. Something I don't see brought up a lot I thought I ought to mention is that the game has options for full Twitch integration as including chat interaction with the game.

Great open and fun roguelike with a ton of content and an amazing soundtrack

This game really exceeds my expectation. There are so many ways to complete the objectives using different characters/items. The difficulty makes sense and can be customized further using mutators. Achievements are fair and don't require you to grind a lot for many of them. The gameplay is very fun, I spent 20hrs in a single weekend to play this game alone. The game endings depend on how you interact with various NPCs in each level, and is definitely more complex than what the trailer shows.

[h1]THE MOST FUN CO-OP ROGUE-LIKE[/h1]

In the slew of 2D pixel-art rogue-likes that have flooded the market in the last few years, Streets of Rogue is probably the most memorable.
I've played it with a friend in couch co-op and online, and had a lot of fun!

[h2]Pros:[/h2]
 [list]
    [*]Fast-paced and hilarious situations
    [*]Replayable
    [*]Fun co-op, on the lighter side
    [*]Multiple play-styles with varied classes
[/list] 

[h2]Cons:[/h2]
 [list]
    [*]Limited amount of content, despite aforementioned replay-ability
    [*]Repetitive music
    [*]A bit quirky (but this could also be a pro)
[/list] 

[h2]Conclusion:[/h2]

[b]Streets of Rogue is a fun little game that really shines when you play with a friend or two.
Happily nominating for Labor of Love 2023.[/b]

- - - - - - -

[h3]Old Review (originally posted June 2021)[/h3]

[i]This game is fun, especially so with a friend. =) I most enjoy playing it with a controller, and my best gamer buddy, it's an excellent couch co-op game to jump into for a quick session or save your progress for later. Part of the replay value for me is unlocking the characters, which are each farely varied and wacky! Shout-out to the developer, I've seen this game improve quite consistently over the course of a year! Worth a buy, esp. if you enjoy multiplayer roguelikes.[/i]

Imagine a classic GTA but indoors and with classes. Your character gets items for completing missions and traits upon levelling up. It takes some time to get grasp how all of this interacts. Some items are absolute game changers on a run while they amount to very little on the next one.
If you liked a run in particular, just copy the seed and play it again with different mutators and get a completely different experience.

Game runs fine for me, sometimes I can't unlock a higher frame rate. Some minor issues with stuttering in online co-op at higher game speeds. Controls are completely customizable.
I don't know why this game is fun, but it sure is.

[b]Introduction:[/b] Streets of Rogue is a pretty bad game, it fails to be a stealth game in a lot of places. Although, calling Streets of Rogue a bad game is a bit of a stretch, besides, I do like to be fair here when it comes to talking about games but sorry, this game is just terribly designed. So what's wrong with Streets of Rogue? Well, allow me to tell you why but first, let's talk about the positives and then the negatives.

[b]Positives:[/b]
-The animation is smooth
-The movement is fluid and responsive
-It controls well
-It looks alright
-The gameplay is solid
-The themeing is unique
-There's a very diverse amount of strategies
-Customization
-And different attributes/abilities for different characters 

[b]Negatives, ranting, and rating:[/b]
First of all, a chunk of the game, the gameplay can feel repetitive, the music is pretty forgettable, you are forced to be perfect when sneaking around, and very poor ai.
The worst part and I can't stress these two major flaws enough, the big quest and the unfair amount of trial and error. Each character is given a quest to complete, a permanent one throughout the entire campaign of the character, you have to complete every single stage for said floor while doing the big quest requirements and If you leave one stage without completing the big quest of said floor, that's it, you can't complete it! Which leads into the biggest problem of this game...the poorly designed and cheap difficulty of this game. Trying to complete all of the quests you're given is both impossible and frustrating. Because you don't have enough money to buy something, you get hit really easily, the ai is way too annoying and cheap and having to go into forced fights you don't want to partake in. All of this combine with a health bar, generated levels that are terribly thought out with the traps and mechanics that make trying to not get hit nearly impossible. Oh! I am not done yet, there's one thing that makes this even worse. Dying, if you die, you go back to the very beginning. You did not just read that, if you die at any point, you go back, to the very beginning of the game. Which makes this one of the most punishing and biggest time wasters, I have ever experienced, it's not fun in the slightest and no, not doing the big quest doesn't erase this problem, if you die, you still have to start from the beginning of the game, regardless if you were doing the big quest or not. It doesn't matter what you say, It's a big problem that ruins the entire fun of the game, whether it's a casual or completionist playthrough. I never thought I would hate this game more than I did back then but it's unbelievably bad, with poorly made choices, cheap difficulty, forgettable aspects of the game, repetitive gameplay, dying, the big quest, and terrible ai. All of this makes for easily the worst and most unfair experience I've ever played in a rogue-like ever. I'm not going to list the rest of the sections like my usual reviews (like the price or verdict), all I give this game is a 1.5/10. Man the more I just talk about the poorly thought out game design the more I hate this game. Though to give it some credit, they did give us videos showing the making of this game showing that they cared about this. I appreciate the people who created this game but I wish the design if it was better. Lastly, I wouldn't even count this but a paywall behind a character pack, really. No offense to the creators of this game or anything, I appreciate the project they were making! Thank you for reading and have a good day!

Fun enough to recommend but the game gets too crazy past the industrial level. It becomes bullet hell and its very hard to see what is going on. I didn't get the appeal at first but after coming back a few times and getting into it, it's really good. Much better with a friend. Lots of variety in playstyles and options. It gets a little samey after awhile since you are doing the same thing every floor though. For what it is though, it's good, especially on sale, and the sequel is shaping up to be awesome and way more going on with it, I can't wait. Also the developer just seems like a swell guy from the interviews.

A run-based action game. It has strong replayability due to the sheer number of unlockable classes and abilities as well as the number of mechanical modifications you can apply to the game, not to mention goals and achievements. You can even create custom characters with different stats, abilities, traits, starting gear and choose a "big quest". You don't have to worry about "polluting" your trait/item pool with unlocks because you can disable any and all of them if you want, you can even save different loadouts.

Most maps in each of the five "areas" are somewhat similar to each other, but they will feel very different based on your character's capabilities. There are also random "disasters" on the third and final level of each area, ranging from spreading goo to a zombie infestation to a killer robot slowly walking towards you at all times and firing a rocket launcher at you (which you can attempt to use to your advantage, if you dare). 

NPCs will respond to a lot of actions (by your and by other NPCs) so there can be a lot of wild and amusing interactions happening on the map, and the world feels alive.

The graphics are extremely basic but the controls are good, the sound feedback is very satisfying, and the music is oddly great.

The devs did a really good job on this one.

Death Road to Canada's humor meets Hotline Miami's top-down carnage meets Deus Ex's dynamic AI. Somehow, they managed to make that work. This is a Splunkey style Roguelike, meaning it's all about wacky interactions between different elements. Death is swift, but knowledge is power.

My favorite part of this is the characters. Not only do they all have different abilities, but each one has a personal quest you need to complete in addition to reaching the end. One character wants to avoid killing people, another wants to kill as many as possible in a rampage, and there are weirder ones too. Each character forces you to play differently, much more effectively than most. Don't like any of them? You can make your own too!

A complete run is about an hour, but you'll die a lot before you reach that point. Afterwards there are a lot of reasons to keep playing. Multiple endings, modifiers, challenge runs, the works. This will keep you busy for a long time, and I highly recommend taking the plunge.
I had so much fun Playing this game, Can't wait for the second game to come out, since I completed all of the quests.

Ahh, Streets of Rouge... What a masterpiece. I cannot believe this game exists, and I also cannot believe there are people who do not like this game. you should understand that, for the most part, the people who are downvoting this game are fools. The only person that could downvote this game is the kind of person who angrily throws a plate and breaks it and gets more frustrated and blames the plate for breaking. It's the kind of game that you have to have an actual marble for a brain to not enjoy. Except unlike a marble, if you are not enjoying this game, your brain is likely very soft- liquid even. This game is incredible, and the amount of choice you have in the way you maneuver this game is even more incredible. As someone who has spent a lot of time playing games, and figuring out what it is I like about them, I have to say, this one has checked all the boxes. The main ones being that it fuels my addiction to dopamine spikes, depletes my serotonin, and virtually numbs me from all things that are not stimuli from the game itself. Not to mention that there are copious amounts of drugs in the game, and it is an absolute joy to be able to stick random, un-named needles into my arms without suffering from any real life adverse effects. I cannot believe more people do not play this game, and it baffles me that anyone wouldn't like it. Although some people also do not like 
In-N-Out Burger, so I guess that goes to show just what a mad world we live in. I'm not sure what you could say negatively about this game that doesn't have to do with your skill level, or your brain's information capacity, or your attention span. The only people who are suffering at this game seriously, are people that can't stop intermittently eating candy, and chips, and drinking soda, and eating cereal for dinner, and coming down with horrific, nightmarish sugar crashes, causing their undoing when they destroy everything on their desk on account of their irrationality. This game is seriously great, I recommend you do not read negative reviews, because they are mostly made by people who are festering in a pool of their own ass sweat day in and day out. They can't enjoy life because their dung drenched chair has gotten uncomfortable because they have pushed all the padding into a flat, crusted bed that lays atop the plastic construction that holds their 300 pound ass up all day. It is seriously not worth reading except for entertainment purposes. Do with this review what you will. I am mostly writing it because it felt crass to leave such a good game un-reviewed.

TURN OFF THE LIGHTING SYSTEM !!!

Game stupidly tosses you into a dark city and does not provide any means of illumination to combat the darkness. Unless you want to squint your eyes and suffer, go to Options -> Graphics -> Lighting Mode: None.

That makes the game 500 times better, trust me on this.

Anyway, besides that minor flaw that can be easily turned off, this is game is AWESOME.

Ever wanted to be an urban terrorist hooligan that does madlad things in an open world city that's way more interactive than GTA? As almost any person you can think of, be it a thief, fireman, soldier, zombie or gorilla?

Streets of Rogue delivers that and much more like a CHAMP.

Seriously, this game is legitimately one of the best games ever made in the last 20 years, regardless of its roguelite elements and nature.  In fact, I guarantee you'll love this even if you hate roguelikes otherwise - difficulty wise it can be one of the easiest roguelites ever.

Its more of an open world action game with very generous conditions for both victory and failure, wrapped in goofy humor yet is still very believable that it can be taken seriously. 

The amount of content, characters, places is massive, while each playthrough is never the same thanks to so many things that can be random, yet cohesive each time. The music is kickin' great too!

This game is *very* well done as a whole, I can not emphasize this enough. Absolutely get this gem if you get the chance! Its worth it even at full price, DLC characters too.

And once you're done with the vanilla game times 20, you can greatly extend it with new map chunks (hundreds of them!) and custom characters (hundreds more!). The best part is that the game can be played casually as a way to relax, pretty much perpetually - you'll be returning for another playthrough again and again, because the moment to moment gameplay is just that stellar.

There's something really chill to this game where you can spend hours just messing around in the city doing fun stuff at your own pace, however you want.

Playtime Update: 400+ hours later I still play this game again and again.

Ever since the days of my youth, this game has been a steadfast companion. It has been with me through wind and fire, witnessed things few others in my life have. When I sold my first baggie to a pregnant Thai woman in the slums of Bangkok, a bootleg version of Streets of Rogue was running on my gameboy. When I reached the upper echelons of drug dealing society, negotiating with the likes of El Chapo and Al Capone over the price of a Kilo or the ownership of territory, it was Streets of Rogue that kept me satisfied at night, and not the prostitutes that so many attempting to achieve my success fell victim to. At the end of my illustrious life, when I am indubitably greeted with the pearly gates of paradise, I will make a final request to good. For among the frolicking angels of heaven shall belong Streets of Rogue,

The controls are great and the game is adaptable to a lot of playstyles (I personally like the hacker playstyle as I can blow TVs up and make refrigerators run). It's not just characters that make this game so different to each player, you also have the ability to choose which perks you might receive after each level up, as well as a number of 'cheats' you can enable to make the game your own (like no melee durability). The combat is not taken seriously; you will hit people so hard that they break the ENTIRE wall behind them. It's still incredibly satisfying though.

Overall, a good game if... you play games. In general.

As a big single-player roguelike specialist, I loved all the clever and creative ideas Streets of Rogue brought to the table. Its unique mission-based GTA-style gameplay in a top-down 2D environment made it unlike any game I ever played, though I found the game to be brutally unforgiving in its difficulty, which didn't match up that well with the amount of time investment for one run. However, I came back to this game with the goal of trying out the multiplayer, and I finally managed to experience the true potential of the game.

The ability to continue the run after dying by having your teammate revive you is just what I was missing to really get the full experience. Being able to try out not just all the different wacky character types, but also the crazy combinations of them is remarkable, making each run a completely different experience. The game is insanely customizable and lets you play with any features on or off. I would highly recommend if you have some roguelike-loving friends looking for a fun co-op experience, and it's worth at least a few hours of fun even solo.

It's fun but the runs start to feel identical quickly.

Don't really enjoy how equipment (can drop during runs) and traits (selected on level-up) are unlocked. Secondary currency is awarded on level-up and on special quest completion. It can be used to unlock entries from both sets. The process is too slow though. I still have a lot of things to unlock and I am already pretty much done with the game.

Classes are distinct and have interesting  special skills but on later floors – 4 and 5 – it's best to use violence or items (cyanide, rage poison) to solve problems. This often escalates into massive fights, destroying big parts of the level. That IS fun. Still, it contributes to the mentioned samey-ness of runs.

Shooting is good. Enemies are pretty accurate and try to avoid incoming fire so it's necessary to lead targets. Deleting groups of mobsters/cops with a rocket launcher is pretty satisfying. Not really possible to go full Rambo because ammunition is limited. I like that.

Stealth is only viable in early game. No visual indicators of what NPCs can see.

Runs take too much time to keep me engaged (I am obsessively thorough with scavenging though).

Visually it's serviceable, if kind of ugly. Soundtrack is catchy but starts to get on your nerves quickly.

Kind of a let-down. 6/10, mild recommendation.

Listen up, my friend, and let me take you on a wild journey through the mean streets of Rogue. Picture this: I was just another soul lost in the corporate machine, a mere pawn in a world of suits and ties. But one day, I had enough. I reached my breaking point, fueled by a fiery determination to break free from the monotony.

With a loaded gun at my side, the last swig of a frosty beer in my hand, and a trusty crowbar clutched tightly, I embarked on a path of rebellion. I decided to pay a visit to my unsuspecting neighbor, knocking on their door with a sense of mystery and danger hanging in the air. What happened next, well, let's just say the details are better left to the imagination, but suffice it to say, their ill-gotten gains became mine.

Now imagine this: a boozy thief with a devil-may-care attitude, dressed to the nines in a sharp suit. I reveled in the thrill of my newfound lifestyle, living on the edge, and embracing the chaos that surrounded me. But little did I know that fate had a different plan in store.

In the very next building, destiny awaited me in the form of a formidable device. Its presence was palpable, and I could sense the power it possessed. Brimming with confidence, I marched forward, ready to conquer any obstacle that stood in my way.

But then, it happened. In a blink of an eye, I found myself hurtling through the air, crashing against a wall with bone-shattering force. The impact was intense, smashing me into a human-shaped paste against the unforgiving concrete. It was a moment of shocking realization, a reminder that even the boldest of thieves can meet their match.

So there you have it, my friend, a tale of rebellion, danger, and a sobering lesson learned. The streets of Rogue are no place for the faint-hearted, and as I lay broken and defeated, I couldn't help but wonder if there was a way to rise again, to face the challenges with newfound vigor. Only time will tell if I'll make a triumphant return or become just another cautionary tale in the annals of this unforgiving city.

I don't usually leave reviews, but this is one of the best designed and most replayable games available on Steam. I can't think of a game with better emergent gameplay.
There are 30ish characters and every single one (except for the two gang variants) have a totally unique gameplay style, and you can also create custom characters that let you mix and match the traits of the existing ones. Tons of different items that encourage approaching problems in different ways. There aren't a huge amount of different obstacles or enemy classes, but the insane variety of approach and the way systems and locations will interact with each other leads to unique situations. You can finesse the AI and movement systems as you learn how they work, it's sort of like a 2D hitman at some points. 
For as low as it goes when it's on sale (like 5 bucks?) and the fact that it has engaging 4 player online multiplayer through steam lobbies, you'd be a fool not to buy it.

Streets of Rogue is an interesting top-down hybrid of Spelunky and Deus Ex that never quite hits the heights of either; a kind of roguelike immersive sim that sees you running amok in a series of city blocks and attempting to exploit their interacting, sometimes unpredictable systems to your advantage. Loosely tasked with toppling the mayor of the titular Streets, you must complete a series of missions on each “floor” before progressing to the next area. Your character’s equipment and capabilities mount alongside the challenge; the baseball bat-touting thugs of the starting slums giving way to mobsters with tommy guns, robot police with rocket launchers and lockdown barriers at the ritzier levels. Like Splelunky, the final levels are too ferociously challenging for me; I confess I’ve only made it to the final boss a couple of times. A complete run might take around an hour; perhaps longer if you focus on the fiddly stealth. Death comes easily but is usually your fault or, at least, entertaining. The wide array of starting characters, each with significant impacts on your playstyle, encourage “just one more go” rather than a ragequit. The pixel art is chunky, charming and clear, the soundtrack upbeat, jazzy and easy to get stuck in your head. The art all ties in nicely with the gameplay’s cheery, silly feel. Streets of Rogue primarily wants you to have a good time in its playground causing mischief, and largely succeeds.

The game is limited somewhat by repetitive level generation and a finite possibility space. NPC interactions with your shenanigans are fun to try to manipulate, but mostly boil down to some degree of everybody dying and everything being destroyed. It’s simply that later levels tend to send hordes of well-armed police after you if your transgressions are detected. Charming, bribing and threatening people to get what you want offers a less entertaining alternative to mayhem, while I found the stealth time-consuming and, again, less fun than running riot.

Streets of Rogue is not quite an essential roguelike, then, but is easy to recommend as a novel concept, joyously executed. I gladly spent many hours in its company and suspect I will keep it around for some time to dip into for an hour or two of inconsequential catharsis. If you enjoy Streets of Rogue’s top-down roguelike tactics, be sure to check out the peerless FTL and Invisible Inc., or Dungeon of the Endless for something a little weirder.

One of the biggest things that puts me off of many Roguelikes is how restrictive they can feel. You go from room to room, clearing out enemies and cursing every mistake you make. Healing and upgrades are limited and if you aren't skilled enough your enjoyment is determined by the roll of a dice.

Not Streets of Rogue.

Every floor in this game is a miniature sandbox, with several objectives for you to complete before you can move on. You can tackle these objectives in any order you want and in a variety of ways. Need to eliminate someone? You could just attack them, but you could also threaten them to leave, befriend them and warn them to leave or arrange for them to be killed by other NPCS.

Every character has own tools and drawbacks that encourage approaching problems in different ways. This is reinforced by the "Big Quest" system, where each character is given an additional objective to work towards throughout their run. Don't like any of the characters? Make your own custom character!

Ever unlocked a terrible upgrade in another Roguelike and wish you hadn't when it ruined a run? Streets of Rogue lets you customize what traits and quest rewards appear during your run! The ability to swap out unwanted traits and remove negative starting traits using an Augmentation Booth is also a welcome addition.

Still not sold? Think it might be too easy or too hard? Enable Mutators! These modifiers let you tweak the game to your liking, doing things like removing those pesky disasters or HAVING A DISASTER ON EVERY FLOOR. Now I know what you're thinking: "Will they disable unlocks and achievements?". Only if you turn on Sandbox mode! Everything else is A-Okay!

This is the best Roguelike I have ever played.
And they're making a Sequel.

I've played Streets of Rogue for over 1000 hours offline. It has infinite replay value for me. The gameplay encourages satisfying strategies that are so fun to pull off fun. I highly recommend all 3 of the Streets of Variety mods which make every run even more varied. I also recommend playing as the cop or the soldier for your first runs. My current favorites are the shapeshifter, the slaver, the zombie, and the investment banker. You can create some awesome characters too.  The only other games I put in the same tier as this when it comes to replay value are Slay the Spire and FTL with the Multiverse mod.

The game's good. It's basically top-down Deus Ex. Less ventcrawl, more sneaking around, plethora of interactables, gadgets, etc. The classes are pretty fun - I have the most fun with Doctor and Shapeshifter, but really anything can change your approach - such as Zombie(Everything is hostile, but anyone you murder comes back as a friendly zombie, letting you start a zombie apocalypse) or Cop(You only gain exp for taking down the guilty, and especially high rewards for successfully arresting them, etc.). 

The game offers both breadth and depth that is seldom-seen in modern videogames, all without being too crunchy on the numbers. High emergent gameplay. Oh, and it's also very fun with friends, whether they're wild wreck-everything sorts or prefer to play slow and tactical.

One of the main appeals of video games as a medium is the idea that you can do whatever you want, especially things you cannot or should not do in the real world. To become someone else and experience a different life. And I believe that few games embody this mantra quite as good as Streets of Rogue. No game has ever allowed you to role-play out your wildest and weirdest dreams quite like this. Without even needing to go into full detail, know that you definitely need to give this game a try, it's truly unique and there is so much to do here.

The main appeal of Streets of Rogue has got to be the freedom of choice you get on how to approach your situation. Its an RPG like no other, with unparalleled freedom of choice and unpredictability. You're thrusted into this city, simulated in full, with various shops, administrative buildings, a population and its own internal conflicts. You're given simple but difficult tasks to serve as guidance and from then on, its all up to you. The game encourages creativity and gives you a plethora of options to choose from. It would be false to say that you can do anything, as that will never be possible, but damn does this game get close. Do you want to:

-be a stealthy ninja, backstabbing guards left and right Assassin's Creed style (this game is officially more AC than new AC games)
-be a lowly thief and pickpocket random people on the street and sneak into people's homes and rob them
-be a maniac soldier and gun everything down on sight, asking questions never
-be a hacker, breaching systems to gain access to forbidden areas, insighting robot rebellions and bringing refrigerators to life
-be a gangster, killing the rival gang for dirt money
-be a the bodyguard of a whiny celebrity
-be a cyborg law enforcer, slaughtering unruly citizens in the name of justice
-be a hyperintelligent gorilla, forming a gorilla army
-be a vampire, hunting people in dark alleyways
-be an alien and mind control the populace to do your bidding for you, helping you build your spaceship
-be a shapeshifting demon and possess others in order to frame them for crimes and spread anarchy

These are just some of the options you have before you and there is a ton more nuance to each that are far beyond the scope of this review. Just dive right in, experiment and see what you can do. Also every task can be approached in a multitude of ways - violence, stealth, trickery, diplomacy, bribery and much more. Pick the most optimal, pick what you find the most fun or just pick what your character would do in this scenario.

The game also features a co-op mode and you can definitely feel how the level design is based around different people using their different abilities in synergy to accomplish goals. And the cool thing is, even if you play alone, you can still take advantage of this by recruiting NPCs with various abilities and instructing them what to do to help you. Truly limitless potential.

And if all this variety wasn't enough, the game is a roguelike too lest we forget. The map will always change so exploration is always necessary, there will be random item drops, unpredictable events and different outcomes every time, so the replayability is truly limitless. The be all, end all social RPG.

So to summarize, Streets of Rogue is an amazing game with tons of content, it's made with lots of love and there is a ton of fun and a ton of different kinds of fun to be had here. You are genuinely doing yourself a disservice by not at least giving it a try.

An amazing RPG styled roguelike with an addicting gameplay loop. Every character plays different from one another at their core, but there are many ways to play the game per character as well. If you read a lot of Steam Reviews, you might notice that there's a lot of game that has short positive reviews that usually has interesting description that really hooks you in (example: You can be a trex that rides on a jet ski while dual wielding an AK-47), but when you tried, it is technically "true" but it's not as fun as what the review implies. Well for Street of Rouge, I can say it mostly will be as fun as the reviews said.

It's really is a fun game. It's a roguelike where the basic gameplay is you select a character (or you create your own!) from a list, those characters have their skills and negative traits. Then you will be given missions in each stage before you can go to the next in a randomized level. What makes it wonderful is that you have freedom on how you want to complete the missions. For example, if you have a mission to get an item from someone, you can either:

- Kill them
- Pay others to kill them
- Pay them to kill others, in hope they are killed so you can loot the item from their corpse
- More of a pacifist? Threaten, bribe, or exchange with other items
- A thief? Pickpocket them
- Shapeshifter? Become them and get the item
- etc, etc...

This is also set in an environment that feels alive. Characters that are rivals will fight. Mobsters seeing you will threaten you for money, but will back off if they see cops, and so on. Oh also, mods and Co-op. Yeah, this game supports those fun stuff.

Music and Art are okay, those do their purpose without detracting from the gameplay.

So yeah, hard to find a reason not to recommend this, it is also frequently on sale, although full price is very worth it. So just go get it already!

I'm not sure I understand all the rave reviews. I kinda hated this game from the outset. Felt like I was doing something wrong and there was nothing really drawing me in to continue dying stupid deaths due to one random uncontrollable factor or another. I tried to push through and get a few hours into the game, and learned a little more - enough to progress a little further; but overall this game is just ridiculously and frustratingly difficult and punishing. Some times you can speed run through and complete all the objectives in the first or second level with no real resistance, other times, a thief randomly steals your upgraded uzi and proceeds to mow you down with bullets while you are helpless to do anything but hate this game for exactly what it is. It would be nice if you could unlock buffs or level your character little by little after grinding through runs, but there is no such ability, so every run you are starting from square one. With no increasing advantage to help you progress more easily through successive runs, the game just feels obnoxious and frustrating. It IS fun to cause chaos by doing things like freeing captive gorillas then watching them obliterate their captive scientists, or inciting gunfights between rival gangs, but you only do that so many times before wanting something more.

I recently picked up Streets of Rogue again after not playing it for quite some time, and I must say, it's still as enjoyable as ever! The game is incredibly simple and easy to get back into, even after a long hiatus. The mechanics are straightforward, but the random elements keep each playthrough fresh and exciting.

One of the standout features of this game is the diverse cast of characters. Each one has unique abilities and playstyles, making every run feel distinct and engaging. I particularly enjoy selecting a random character and adapting my strategy on the fly. While the game may not be very deep, this simplicity is part of its charm and makes it a perfect choice for a quick gaming session.

As for the story, it's true that there isn't much to it. The premise of becoming the mayor is a fun idea, but it doesn't really impact the gameplay in any significant way. However, this doesn't detract from the overall experience, as the focus is clearly on the gameplay itself.
This game can easily be described as the Best Game Ever.

I was originally introduced to this game by a friend showing me the free demo on itch.io, and most of my gameplay time is from that demo alone, as I played and replayed it (a first for me!) Buying it on Steam was the clear next step, and I didn't hesitate to pick up the character pack at the same time. 

First and foremost, its variability: no two playthroughs are ever quite the same. Coming in a very close second and third are how much co-op gameplay changes how I choose to approach the same scenarios, and how populated and lively the levels feel despite being comparatively small areas. The tongue-in-cheek and sometimes fourth-wall-breaking humor makes even those moments when everyone on the map hates you fun. It's also SO nice to have a new game that supports local/couch co-op!

I am now ready and waiting to buy SoR2 as soon as it comes out (also a first!) and am confident that it will be as much fun to play with friends as the first game.

Streets of Rogue is like a wild mashup of Binding of Isaac and Nuclear Throne, mixed with the anarchy of GTA, and a sprinkle of Deus Ex-style RPG elements. It's a crazy fun rogue-lite game that gives you tons of choices and lets you go nuts with experimentation!

The game's all about player freedom. You've got a bunch of diverse characters to choose from, each with their own unique abilities. Wanna hack security systems, bribe guards, use disguises, or set traps? Go for it! The game encourages you to get creative and strategic, and there's no shortage of ways to approach levels.

One of the best parts is the emergent gameplay. You can interact with the environment and NPCs in all sorts of unexpected ways. The RPG elements let you make moral decisions that affect the story and the game world, so you can really shape your own adventure. Plus, the game's got a funny sense of humor with quirky characters, crazy weapons, and unexpected events that'll keep you entertained.

But watch out, because permadeath is a thing. Every decision counts, and the challenge is real. It's addictive, challenging, and totally unpredictable, but that's what makes it so damn fun. Streets of Rogue is a unique and thrilling ride that'll have you hooked from the get-go with its blend of rogue-lite gameplay, open-world madness, and RPG elements.

So much fun! There's nothing serious about this game. If you're looking for something like The Binding Of Isaac, Hades, Risk Of Rain 2, or any other Rougelite, you'll be disappointed. Streets Of Rogue is its own fantastic addition to the genre.

There are many different classes to unlock and each plays a bit differently. If you want to be a hacker and be sneaky you can. If you want to be a thief and pick pocket your way through the levels, you can do that too. Be an alien or gorilla who can't communicate with the human NPCs? Yup. Or maybe you want to be a soldier and blast your way through the levels. You can also create your own custom classes. 

There is nothing I've found that's boring or repetitive about Streets Of Rogue. The more you play, the more new challenges and play styles open up. This game is a freaking masterpiece.

[h1]A unique, well working (and challenging) roguelike.[/h1]

In Streets of Rogue, your mission is to complete 1 to 3 (or fail while trying to complete) objectives on each block and then move up to next floor doing new tasks in ever more dangerous blockade than the previous, with ultimate goal to take down an evil mayor. Upon completing these objectives you are awarded with money or item that can ease your job depending how well you manage to use them. During a run you also gain experience and levels and in each level up you get to pick a perk that may or may not be very helpful to you, once again depending how well you take advantage of it.

There's also a huge amount of classes you can select from and start your run, from simple homeless person who just gets more xp to doctor who refuses to use firearms but carries infinite supplies of chlorine with him/ her, making stealth takeouts essential part of that classes playstyle.

What also surprised me very positively was how "boss floors" were handled and how well they worked. In each third floor there's going to be a disaster presence, from simple riot where pretty much everyone is ready to beat the s*** out of you to killer robot hunting to destroy you minus leather jacket and black sunglasses and M1911 with top-mounted laser sight replaced with rocket launcher. These disasters give just the right amount of extra tension before moving to upper class floor(s).

One thing I mention too is that while there's lot of options for player to improvise this game ain't easy, you really have to think have you are going to complete missions and run if you want to stay alive (and yes I admit I used mods [or more accurately used dnSpy] to make this game easier for me, given I'm more used to play roguelites with permanent upgrades than roguelikes where your progress after defeated run is mostly wiped out).

Overall had a lot of fun with this game and will definitely use mutilators to make future playthroughs even more challenging. Very excited for Streets of Rogue 2 that was announced not too long time ago.
This is what would happen if Dwarf Fortress and Enter the Gungeon had a baby.

Take a pill to make you a giant and smash your way to victory!

I can't recommend this game enough, it's a bloody good time and I'm very excited for the next one!

[h1] Name a game more ludicrous... [/h1]

[b]What It Is:[/b]
A roguelite based in an underground city with frantic combat, tight controls, and extremely customizable experiences on each run. Want to be gorilla strong and smash through walls? How about charming everyone in the area? Hire a gang to do your dirty work? Or just go in action movie style guns blazing? You can do it all in this crazy as heck game.

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
You can really choose to be almost anything you want in this game. SoR is a procedural rogue-lite and you can choose to start as one of several classes, or create your own class. Each class has tools which aid them in completing objectives, but perks you get along the way can help you become better or something completely different.

[b]Difficulty:[/b]
From very easy to extremely hard, it has a range of challenges available.

[b]Graphics:[/b]
All of the parts of this game have so much character. TinyBuild could have easily phoned in some procedural character generation for the citizens, instead many of the unique citizens like shopkeepers, thiefs, police, robots, gangsters, mobsters, etc. all have their own sprites and they look fantastic.

[b]Audio:[/b]
Cute explosive chaos is the best I'd describe it. It's definitely well done, and nothing here grates my ears at all. It's sort of what you would expect a 16-bit title to sound like if it was made with 2018 sound quality.

[b]Replay Value:[/b]
Plenty. I mean oh so much. You can make any class you want in the game and it's quite hard so imagine the fun you will have each new run. Personally, I made a DOOM GUY class that regens ammo on kills and starts with a machine gun, but I also have a spy who hacks and has a tranq gun. I'm sure you can see how this drastically changes the gameplay, and makes for a lot of unique circumstances each run.

[b]What I Like:[/b]
It requires a lot of planning to come out on top in this game, and the sheer amount of different things you can do is quite impressive.

[b]What I Don't[/b]
Honestly, the challenge floors. I always have them off. They just aren't that fun.

I'm not sure why I waited until I have 100%'d this game to review it, Because I knew it was amazing nearly 80 hours of playtime ago. I could attempt to compare SoR to thinks like Hotline Miami, GTA2, Monaco... but really SoR is so much more and there's really no experience like it. It's actually shocking how so much of this game is perfect with a solo dev. The moment to moment game play, the light but engaging rpg mechanics, the graphics, the music, the mood. 

According to steam achievements and the in-game unlock screens I have almost nothing left to do in this game, but I already have a dozen new runs planned in my head and I'm certain I'll get another 20 hours out of it. Barely a week or two goes by that I don't check for even a crumb of info on SoR2. If you're even a little curious get this game. 

I'm not joking when I say it may be tied with Terraria for the most mechanically perfect game ever made.

(Original review from some time in 2017 after maybe 20 hours of playing) This game is great, the utter chaos is hilarious, from starting mob wars with the police by mistake and being able to put all sorts of crazy syringes and other drugs into drinks and air filters. The custom characters are awesome and can lead to even more chaos.

This game is a lot more fun to play than it is to watch, at least in my experience, keep that in mind when watching people play if you're deciding whether to buy the game.

Can't wait to see what the future updates will lead to.


Edit 27/12/2021.

Played with a dude called "Romulus" who went around as the Emperor of Rome, summoning powerful guards to do his bidding as I served him as a robot. 
Later on it became challenges for me to overcome as he sent stronger and stronger opponents alone and then in groups to prevent me from my goal. This went on for many levels and ultimately ended in dead by time bomb.

I cannot recommend this game enough, for all the love and development it has seen over the years. Eagerly awaiting the sequel.

Edit 1/3/2023

Still coming back to this game from time to time. Still holds up, still has all the same chaos and wonder its always had. An absolute gem of a find all those years ago. Looking forward to the sequel immensely, will be an instant purchase based on this game.

Buy the game, enjoy the chaos.

I can't even put into words how ridiculously, amazingly dumb this game is. So instead, here's a non-exhaustive list of the crazy shit you can do on your quest to become Mayor:

Shrink a building full of people and then stand outside the front door, casually stepping on them as they try to flee.
Possess a Zombie and start an apocalypse that you're only vaguely in control of.
Charge up a sneak-attack so powerful that it literally turns anyone in the game into tiny giblets, completely unarmed.
Use a Leaf-Blower to slam someone against an explosive generator, killing them instantly - or into a bottomless pit.
Cut yourself on a window to make room for sucked blood.
Pickpocket everyone in sight and use the money to buy, like, a Rocket Launcher or something.
Fill a Water Pistol with Rage Poison and pit a Goon against their client in a battle to the death.
Sneak illegal weapons into a wrestling match.
Assassinate a famous Musician with a banana peel.
Knock on the door, then slip into someone's house as they head back to bed...
Buy rounds for everyone, smell good, and y'know... run for Mayor like a normal person.
Arson!
Knock on the door and arrest whoever answers.
Enslave a Slaver to Enslave the Slaves the Slaver Enslaved, you Slaver Enslaver.
Bust ghosts for a quick buck, or just punch gravestones and run like hell from the spirits you awaken.
Go on a Werewolf hunt.
Possess someone's friend and ask nicely for whatever you need, then cut your host/witness on a broken window to dispose of them.
Silently breach walls to get in and out without a problem.
Trip someone into their own deadly security system.
Lure someone into their own deadly security system.
Turn into a Gorilla Kaiju and unleash a world-killing blow to obliterate the Mayor and their guards in a single punch.
Plant a landmine in some schmuck's path to set off an explosive chain reaction.
Eliminate all crime in a badass mech suit.
Lure a killer robot to take out your enemies for you.
Fist-fight a Gorilla.
Throw a Refrigerator at a Cannibal.
disarm a laser with a can of imitation food.

[h1] Fantastic game [/h1] 
Great music 
 This is the first thing you will notice , from the title screen on this game has an addictive soundtrack that fits very well.

Solid Controls
 Either Mouse and keyboard or joypad , both have good controls wither it's shooting, moving, melee or interacting with the level the controls are on point.

Fun
If it's not fun why play ? Streets of rogue is always a good time, single player you can focus on unlocking achievements , new characters or speed running, multiplayer is pure chaos and adrenaline , trying to avoid a killer robot while your hacker friend distract's a guard by sending a refrigerator thru a wall so you can rescue a gorilla in exchange for a cheese burger, that's just a normal quest in streets of rogue.

Replayability
Tons of characters and even custom characters that you can mix and match special abilities on.
Hacker plays different from Gorilla players different from Commando plays different from Doctor and so on,  

Each one has the same main goal of reaching the final stage and becoming the mayor but how they do it is totally different, this isn't just a slight change of how you shoot a gun, they can have drastically different play styles.

My only complaint is not enough level variation, the level layout changes but the order of levels stays the same , it would be better if sometimes instead of slums you started in a different starting areas like a junkyard or warehouses , maybe go to sewers instead of a park etc (not so much shuffling the order of the levels but swapping them for new levels so that it isn't the same each time)
But this is a minor complaint since each of the areas play very differently from each other.

TLDR great game, Looking forward to Streets of Rogue 2.
Fun to optimize but also fun to run through without a care in the world.

Possibly the only example of a roguelike immersive sim. It has really fun, simple, splashy combat on top of a slew of non-combative ways to solve problems. Each floor is a little arena with quests that must be completed to progress and the game gives you a ton of different tools and scenarios and you can get really creative with your problem solving. If there's a combination of items and interactions you can think of then it probably works better than you expected. The custom character building lets you add a ton of diversity to runs, challenging yourself in unique ways by tying benefits to restrictions. All of this on top of the sleeper best soundtrack of 2019.

I don't think I'm going to do a long review for this one, but I feel I do need to toss it a thumbs up. 

I bought it originally just because it looked like some fun as a local co-op experience for parties and what not (you can also play it online mp). That's how it sat in my library for a long time, only really played heavily in that role. I always enjoyed it, but rarely had a chance to boot it up as other games or activities simply rose to the top for one reason or another. 

A friend of mine recently got me back into it and so I beat it a couple times solo. Its a solid little game with lots of Quality of Life design choices that are nice, and a good approach to rogue-lite / rogue-like gameplay. 

If you want something with a good bit of replay value at a decent price, and you like rogue-likes / rogue-lites, check it out! It's definitely worth its current sale price of $6 CDN, and I'd say its worth considering even at its full price if you see yourself really sinking your teeth into it, alone or with friends.

Streets of Rogue is a fun roguelite with RPG elements, where the main point of the game is to let you pass the levels using any means you want: you can kill enemies, knock them out, convince them to be your allies, hack computers to assist in your work... the possibilities are countless and they are in your hands!

On the side of temporary progressions, there are many items to be found, bought or cloned, in addition to having a level progression between phases. 

Already in the permanent progressions, there are perks and rewards to be unlocked and also new classes for future matches!

With a view from above, you guide your 16-bits character through a building. You are asked to kill someone, the barman. So... the most straightforward option seeming like the best alternative, you hit him. But then the bodyguard in the corner see you so he and the barman teams up on you, and you are forced to flee while taking some heavy hit from a bat.
Healing yourself the best you can (with the small beers you found in the garbage), you come back with a better weapon you got after beating up a guy who asked for nothing. But it isn't enough, and you end on the street, dead, after going through the wall.

You want to tamper with the aeration of a building to make everyone inside flee, but a policeman sees you, then his colleague sees him attacking you, and their colleagues as well. And after 30 seconds of chase, you inevitably end lying down in a pool of your own blood.

But don't let this stop you!

After going through several games, you'll learn the tricks, how the AI works, how to use items, which upgrade to take. And soon you'll find yourself tricking the AI and laughing at their own blunders.
This game is funny. The stupid humor is yours to judge, but the chaotic aspect of the game is just GREAT. Seeing guards dying because of their own security, policeman shouting-out with gangsters over one missfire, a thief getting rolled over by a train just after fleeing a guy they just stole from will just make you break into laugher at the goofy side of the very well made AI.

The game go on like this: you enter a stage, you have task given to you (kill this guy, get this item, free this guy), and you can go to the next stage after completing these tasks.

But you have so many ways to accomplish them!

It mainly rely on the character you play. Thief steal and has access to infiltration tools, but cameras stay a weakness and his fighting prowess aren't the best. Gorilla can't use gun, but his charge deal heavy damages. Vampire can easily kill people one by one with his special attack, but this doesn't work against groups. Slaver? You're are a scum of a human being, and you will ENJOY being one. Enslave people on the street to send them do the work for you until their (explosive) death.

You just have to get the hang on the game. But this will not spare you from dying from time to time from some stupid sequence of event. And frakly, you'll hardly get tired of it. It's a great game.

Any time I've played through Streets of Rogue, I've *always* gone with the "obliterate everything route", but simply altering my method of doing so through whatever mechanism was provided by the class I picked.

Recently I've been trying to pick characters as I play that have more social type of goals and sticking to that playstyle now realizing that is the intent.  With the Bartender for example, you have to serve 5 drinks per level to characters.  Initially I thought it was a pretty boring/slow character as I was having trouble even finding or coming up with enough money to even buy the drinks.  Once I took a moment to look in my inventory, I saw that I had a drink mixer that lets me make custom drinks out of various consumables (injectors for example) that gave me more options.  Some I could give to quest targets in a level to kill them without even attacking them conventionally which made Bartender MUCH more enjoyable than I had initially realized.

These recent runs have given me renewed interest in the game, and I'm excited to try out the other play styles available.  Also even more excited about Streets of Rogue 2 than I was before!

The short version:
This game is chaotic and fun, however, it might not be everyone's cup of tea. Somewhat of a rogue-lite. Lots of blood and destruction and tons of ways to play, would recommend

The long version:
I can't fucking explain it. I fucking LOVE this game. And I don't even LIKE rogue-lites/rouge-likes that much! This is one of my favorite games by far. I got on it after the whole hype about but it's fucking amazing. I got every achievement and I still wanna play more. You can really play the game however you want. Wanna be a homeless guy that beats the shit out of anyone? go for it. Wanna be a bartender and serve (not) poisoned drinks to people? yep! The replayability is crazy. The game allows you to play in a stress-relieving way where you create the most broken character known to man and blast through the game with ease or challenge yourself with a difficult set of modifiers. Or just play the game normally. There is DEFINITELY a learning curve to playing the game, but once you learn it, you'll STILL suck balls because you should've used that item there and you should've held onto that other one, etc etc etc. There's quite a bit of luck and you can lose hours of progress within seconds because a fire extinguisher counts as a gun (and so does a jerry can). All the times I've alt-f4'd out of the game I've only come back with more confusion than the last, but hey! It's a chaotic game and that's what it's all about. Nonetheless, I have fun with it and can't wait for the sequel.

Conclusion: THIS IS A GREAT GAME!!! Definitely one of the better games on the site and is a buncha of fun, especially if you have friends. (Though they are not required to have fun.)

I was expecting something else, something more akin to an RPG. I literally had someone compare this to a tabletop RPG. It's not like that at all. This isn't a pixelated Divinity: Original Sin 2. It's presented as if you can 'do anything', but in reality the game consists of entering/exiting places to get things, destroying things/people and having people follow you places. Every run will feel identical because the randomized missions are all one of the things I said above. It likes to tease the idea that the game is so flexible and expansive and customizable, but really, basically everything simply manipulates one of those three mechanics.

It's a roguelike game where everything is randomized, so the layout is always different, missions and the rewards for the missions are always different. Different doesn't mean unique or interesting. All of them are one of the three mechanics I mentioned: destroy this, rescue this guy, get this thing from this place. Also, for each class they have an individual overarching 'big quest', but again, is simply a variation of the same mechanic ie. 'don't kill 100 people.' 'get a lot of money.' etc.

You can select a class which is a simple avatar change, and a few automatic traits and items given to you from the beginning. Some also have unique abilities like Doctors can chloroform, Thieves can pickpocket, etc. but again all of the abilities are 'destroy something/someone', 'someone follow you', or 'enter/exit place to get thing'. There are also the generic increasing stats, combat benefits and the like, but its all very flat. You can also purchase more options using the in-game currency, which is 'chicken nuggets'. To me it comes off that he wrote the punchline before he came up with the set-up. "wouldn't it be funny if the currency was chicken nuggets.. tee hee... ok but how do I justify that? uhhh uhhh outlawed...." Wouldn't chicken nuggets be a terrible choice because, you know, mold? Nope, the joke is more important, I guess.

The combat is you move the reticle around with the mouse and right click, then a little fist, or whatever weapon you're carrying, flies out next to your avatar and if you aim in the correct direction you'll damage the enemy. There is recoil, the enemy does random things, moves randomly, and will flee - which is annoying. There are some options like explosives, swords, guns - you'll find the usual fare. I liked the inclusion of the banana peel, but once they fall down, you chuckle, then it's pretty lackluster. 

To me the graphics look less like charming pixel art, and more like mediocre, simplistic, flash animation. Nothing really animates, it's more like everything is floating around, things appear and disappear, nothing feels cohesive. The explosions look nice.

Apparently, this game is made to be played co-op, and I can see how having another person would make the game more interesting. Because that person would be providing the interesting elements. Since I have no other person the game isn't interesting to me.

The most enjoyable part of this game was the video that resembles the promo for a WWE match.

The idea of having different solutions to missions is a great one. However, if that's a core part of the game, why do I find myself brute forcing everything and hoping I don't die before I finish the floor missions? Not enough gold to buy items to be creative or food to replenish health. Why do melee weapons have ammo/durability? Why is a baseball bat with 100 "ammo" and 10 "ammo" both destroyed in 2 hits? Why have I only experienced 3 mission types? Are there more? I'll never know cause there's nothing about this game that made me want to sit down and find out. Even at a super sale of $5 USD, I'd rather have a Starbucks.

7 hours into it, this game is incredibly fun.

Screwing around with all the zany characters and their abilities is a delight. Sure, some characters aren't as interesting as others, but the way in which the game accommodates the playstyles of each specialized class is top notch, and is definitely the reason to play. You have characters great with hand-to-hand combat and guns, but struggle to put a sentence together. You have characters that rely on recruiting allies in order to be more effective. You even have 100% viable stealth and hacker playstyles that work perfectly. The randomly generated environments are able to suit all playstyles effortlessly without feeling like a homogenized mess.

The items are very unique, albeit not as abundant in number compared to something like Isaac (which works in this game's favor). You've got solid snake boxes that allow for swift sneaking action, a tranquilizer pistol for a nonlethal approach, special grenades, food items, random syringes and so much more.

The character's special attributes and abilities are fairly well-balanced, and the ability to create your own character is just the cherry on top. I created an abomination that had a bunch of negative stats, which game me even more points to give him mind control powers and other crazy stat bonuses.

There's a fully functional level and chunk editor to spice things up if the generation is getting boring.

There's Workshop Support.

There's even MULTIPLAYER WITH UP TO 4 PEOPLE!

I'll definitely be grinding this game in the coming weeks, and I'll update my review if my opinion of it changes. But for now, this game is at the very least a must-try - it's on sale during the time in which I'm writing this review, so knock yourself out. The amount of content is staggering, and I hope that the game gets more and more content in the future.

I must admit, I did pirate this game before purchasing and would have over 200 hours on it easily if they were added to my Steam hours. Still went and paid full price for it here because this is certainly a game that deserves it.

It's one of the most fun games I played in a long time. That goes for both single-player and multi-player runs. It gives you total freedom (within the scope of your own skills and knowledge) on how to tackle the different situations. 

Want to go in, arms flailing and guns blazing? You can.
Want to go in, silently as a ghost and quieter than the sound of a cat's footsteps? You can.
Want to avoid going in, sending your minions/friends/unwilling servants and reaping the rewards afterwards? You can.

Do expect for odds to change considerably in a very short amount of time, both for better or worse as chaos engulfs you and your plans.

Multiplayer works extremely well. It can cement bonds even further, or brake them and cause you and your friend to be yelling loudly at each other in a vain attempt to discover who's fault it was that all went to shit.

If you're here wondering if this game is worth $20, I'd have to definitely say it is. The concept is simple, but very well executed, you start as a character who you can either choose from the in-game roster or create your own, and while each character has their own skills and quests, you can play however you like, you then need to clear each district on a quest to become mayor of the city (there's 5 districts containing 3 floors each: Slums, Industrial, Park, Downtown, Uptown and mayor village is the top floor making 16 total floors), this usually takes over an hour, and considering how different each character feels while playing, you'll get a lot of time out of this. Completing quests of characters and missions unlocks more items and abilities, so you'll rarely run out of content, and if you do eventually get bored, there's tons of Workshop Characters, Campaigns, and new buildings to spice up each run, I've been playing this game for a long time, and I still find enjoyment in the gameplay (especially with my custom characters). 
If there's anything to be taken from this long review, this game has a lot to offer, and the developers are working on a sequel, so go ahead and try this game, It's a great game to jump into every once in a while, and can be very challenging (I still haven't beaten some of the harder Workshop Campaigns), but is certainly worth a try.
