I saw Streets Of Rogue was a co-op free to play game with overwhelmingly positive reviews so I just installed it and went to play it with my brother expecting a game similar to Streets Of Rage or Little Fighters. A game that took itself seriously. Then when the tutorial was forced, my brother patiently sat and watched as I completed the tutorial. We both kept looking at each other as we quickly realized a something important about this game.
This game does not take itself seriously, and neither should you. Fortunately I can say I mean that in a positive way.
Starting to learn Streets Of Rogue is slow, but Streets Of Rogue is not a slow game.
My brother and I still don't understand exactly what affects the 'electability' statistic and multiple runs have ended suddenly leaving us with our mouths hanging open, yet we both agree we have a blast playing this game. 

There are two things that set Streets Of Rogue apart: the immense time, effort, and care that has gone into designing this game, which clearly shows. The other thing is that each class has a "Big Goal", which gives this roguelite *extreme* replayability because you play so much different depending on your big goal.

There's a wide range of big goals that range in difficulty as well.
You're probably going to like this game because even if you don't like how some classes play, there are others that turn the game upside down. Whether you want to sneak around pulling heists as the Thief, corner the market as the Shopkeeper, be utterly evil and dominate people as a Slaver, make friends through violence with the Zombie, arrest lawbreakers as the Cop (I guess enslaving people isn't illegal, but that's screwed up), or just tell jokes to become famous as the Comedian with the well-known line "Derpa derp derp derp. DERPA!" (Whew, that is a knee slapper there. Still brings a tear to my eye it's so funny), there's so much to do and so many ways to play that Streets Of Rogue is definitely going to hold your attention for quite a while :)

I might be slightly obsessed.....

Endless replayability, amazing modding community with a near infinite amount of content, over a dozen unique characters with interesting ability dynamics, fun mutator system that allows you to have the run of your dream. I have no complaints, this game is a masterpiece of roguelike sandboxes.

The only thing that might be a criticism of the game is that a lot of the characters are quite unbalanced. The game is much easier using certain characters, and becomes extremely difficult with others. Personally I don't see this as much of an issue since all of them are, at the very least, fun to use, and I think this is at least partially intentional, but I could see someone getting frustrated about their favorite character being super difficult to get through the game with.

This game should be kept secret from anyone keeping a career in municipal politics. While I will admit, it is fun in a video game to stage a coup d'etat so that you can give the mayor a coup de grace, you shouldn't do this in real life.

This game delivers pretty much exactly what the trailers promise: morbidly funny action RPG, parodying CyberPunk and maybe a bit of the old Paranoia role-playing game. There are a huge number of character classes to unlock and try to beat the game with, and each class has a genuinely different feel (with the exception of the two gang members who are purposefully clones of each other). I especially loved the Hacker, hiding in an alley behind a building I was trying to sneak into by turning the security system on its occupants, then changing the odds on a slot machine to milk it dry. 

Game design encourages chaos - everything you do seems to have consequences, and I learned to think twice before using explosives or starting a fight. Character progress is enough to keep it interesting but doesn't take too much calculation - you get a small selection of traits each level-up, pick one. 

Not all of the jokes hit home - there's a broad spectrum from subtle and clever to plain old silly. That's okay too - there's so much going on that I before a joke that doesn't work for me starts to bother me, I'm into something else crazy (why not fill a watergun with Giantizer and shoot a bunch of zombies when they break loose in one of the frequent disasters that plague the city?). I don't do much multiplayer but I can definitely see how this fits social play as well - one-upping each other on the creative destruction sounds like a good time. 

I'm jazzed for the sequel. Have fun!

300 hours and a sequel announcement later, I guess I'll say a thing or two about this game.
It's a roguelite game where each level is a wacky, highly lethal little sandbox of a city district and you can make some pretty crazy interactions happen if you know how the mechanics work. It's great fun to pop open and play without any special preparation or real stress.
My only complaint is that at about 200 hours the game started feeling pretty samey. Even with challenging mutators, the best way to win is pretty straightforward. As for the sandbox element, I started running out of things I hadn't already tried out at around that mark.
The modding community on the official Discord and chunk packs from the workshop kept me going for another hundred hours. There are some mods that shake up the gameplay pretty well, even if they tend to be a bit buggy, and there are chunk packs that provide unique challenges that require more foresight than the basegame chunks.
All in all, I'd recommend giving this game a spin. I don't know if the sequel will be any good yet, but I know that this one is fun, so I'd still recommend the first game.

Fun rogue-lite game. It has you going through four or so sections - procedurally generated with their own objectives (plus class-specific objectives) per "level." You go from the Slums, to the Industrial level, to the Woodland area, to the City area, to the Upper Crust area. Each level is increasingly difficult and has unique enemies and situations to deal with, such as the Woodland area being overrun with cannibals and gorillas, while the City has mobsters that will try to steal your money.

You play as any of a bunch of classes with basic stats and special abilities, and can unlock some more of them by doing specific things in-game. The Soldier for example has good shooting abilities, starts with a machine gun and explosives, and has a specific class-objective on each floor to destroy all generators on the level. While the Vampire on the other hand has the objective of finding a hidden Werewolf on each floor to kill. Classes are unique and can let you play things relatively peacefully, with stealth, or through pure carnage.

NPCs will react relatively realistically. Cops that spot criminals will attack them, and you can trick people attacking you into attacking others to get them killed. You can make noises to attract enemies into traps, or hire followers to assist you (which you then use as decoys to escape), or take a pill that turns you into a giant and smash through the wall of the building your target to kill is hiding in. You can hack computers (with the right classes) to turn off security, buy items and such from NPCs as well as vending stations, and so on.

Each floor has missions shared between any players in co-op to complete, ranging from freeing a prisoner and helping them escape, to killing targets, to getting items held by certain characters or in safes, or so on. You have to complete these missions to go to the next floor, and they give rewards for completing them (items, or money, or such). You can spend money to buy items from vendors, or to revive other players in co-op, or to bribe cops, or so on.

All in all, it's a fun game. I have enjoyed beating it twice so far with a good friend of mine, and will probably play through it a few more times before I get bored.

Edit: I have now beaten it as a Vampire, Werewolf, Doctor, and most recently as a Mafia member.

I personally think it is more than worth the price, but especially in co-op is fun. Despite the rogue-lite nature it probably won't interest you for more than 10-50 hours since the amount of variety you'll get "in practice" isn't as deep as would be ideal, but there's still a lot to be enjoyed here.

TL DR: Fun roguelike with great replay value and customisation.

I hate roguelikes. I never saw the fun in starting a game from scratch based on the RNG not being in the players favour, but Streets of Rogue gets a pass. The game has customisable options making the game easier for people who are absolutely terrible at the genre like me.

Pros:

+ Vast variety of ways to play the game and a lot of customization.

+ Great sense of humour.

+ Great music.

+ Addictive and fun.

+ Turning into a giant and smashing through walls with a giant axe was a highlight.

+ Break into computer, open locked doors and safe? Sure! But don't read the emails that would be rude.

+ The deliberatly stolen line from Deus Ex about wandering into the womans bathroom was welcome.

+ Sandbox mode lets you cruise right through the game doing missions at your liesure without being forced.
(It's this player choice that really makes the game stand out in my opinion)

CONS:

- Information overload. A lot is crammed into the game and there is a lot of flavour text it can get overwhelming.

- The setting is a bit too dark (No daytime)

- Difficulty spike floor 5.

- It's hard to concentrate when you have allies and you are under attack by more than one enemy. You hit your allies by accident in the pandemomium and you can be dead before you know it.

- There is a continue option, but it's limited to only 2 continues, and you resume with low health if you entered the mission with low health.

Overall, I definitely recommend, especially on sale if you are not so keen on roguelikes like me, but if you love the genre, by all means its worth full price. Looking forward to the sequel.

I think this is what some people would call a "watercooler" game. You and your friends will be talking about the kind of dumb s**t you get up to in this game. "Oh I had to assassinate a gangster on stage one with no items, I noticed his rival was sitting in the same room so I got them to look at each other and trigger their turf war. Problem solved!". "Well I had to kill a guy in some sort of maze like building, I had 3 window cutters, 2 lockpicks. So I dropped some rage posion into the air conditioning system and let his friends take him out. Problem solved!"

There's so many different ways to play the same game it's completely insane how much you can do and troll the NPCs in this game. Let's start with a door and your target is on the other side. Knock on the door, target answers, shoot to kill, problem solved. Stick a bomb on the door, knock, RUN, boom, problem solved. Just punch the f***ing door down then punch your target to death, AS A GORILLA!!! Problem solved! F**k the door shoot through the window until dead. Destroy the window and throw a bomb in. Use a flame thrower, rocket launcher, freeze ray, shrink ray, or freeze then shrink them and stamp into pixels. Drain their blood as a vampire. F**k killing them, put a slave collar on them! Punch them once, run and hope they accidentally shoot the police and then it's the Law's problem... solved!? There's sooo much you can do in this game!

The rogue-like nature of the game and the different types of characters don't just add challenges, goals, and replayability, they force you to get creative and that's when the magic really begins to happen. I literally completed the game without killing anyone and asking the end boss for the "key" needed to complete it. The boss was like "ah you seem cool" and gave me it! The game is dumb, fun and just dumb fun. The best part is the devs are working on a sequel set in an open world with vehicles.

An amazing roguelike with endless replayability, Streets of Rogue is one of the best indie games i have ever played.

The game takes place in a city that has been turned into a dystopia by a corrupt evil mayor, you are a part of the revolution and its up to you to stop him! You will be dropped into the city and forced to perform various tasks whilst avoiding the law and surviving.

Classes have varying different playstyles, each class has its use and gimmick. There are hundreds of items to help you complete your tasks. The Npcs that roam the city, are funny, fun to fight and can create hilarious scenarios, where one fight between two individuals causes an entire riot to break out.

Meanwhile all of this is accompanied by an amazing soundtrack. The fast-paced, jam-packed music really keeps you on your toes throughout everything.

For about 20$ for a fun experience with near infinite replayability,  you should definitely give this a try!

I'll definitely be giving the sequel a try too!

I have played this game a lot and made a couple of levels in the easy-to-use designer that comes with the game. At first I thought it was like sweets, a dessert after EU4 or Pillars of Eternity but the charmingly simple graphics only suggest the hidden depths of fun.

I grew up in the 1980's (think "Stranger Things") and most of the games were very simple and on cassette tapes. It took about 30 minutes to an hour to fully load a game (or felt like it). I had one that my brother gave me that was about Baseball. Once, I got so bored of my collection that I stooped to play it (all respect to sport's lovers) but the character just stood on the base and tried to repeatedly hit a ball (the size of a pixel). I wanted to walk up to the pitcher and beat him to death. I couldn't.

But Streets of Rogue does let you. Imagine all the side-scrolling beat 'em ups from the 80s-90s (streets of rogue has a top down feel), and then imagine that you can go any one of the bars along the route, buy an ambiguous drug from a dealer and then hire a thief to break into the bar's back window to break into the safe. 

You can return and buy some health replenishing whiskey from the owner, with his own money, to then disappear into a town full of slums, night clubs, gang-hideouts, police stations, churches and prisons. Or you could just go into the pub and shoot them dead with a modded shotgun, take their stuff and use the bar-tender's own key to break into the safe.

Yes. I can hear you thinking it now. This sounds cool. Well, I'm 117 hours into it. Grand strategies are usually my thing but I was blown away by the imagination and sense of fun of the developers. There are five levels to each set game. You start in the slums and work through outer, inner and finally to the Elysium of the game. There are the wretched poor (cheap to hire) "Go and hit that man over there, would you commoner?". Vampires will creep up on you. Potential werewolves are hard to spot. Cannibals jump out of the bushes, like true pervs, and zombies will turn a town in under an hour. 

The resistance becomes active when you buy the DLC and get the Demolitioner. She is basically a hardcore activist/terrorist (depends what side you're on). There's two gangs that are in a constant turf war. Mobsters who will shake you down for cash or that you can bribe to sway the Mayorial election your way. 

There's many more characters and loads of ways to play each level. It can be as smooth as silk and then turn into a heady storm of destruction (unless you're playing the Doctor(Hippocratic oath)). You get to be all these characters (or make your own), with their own stats, special abilities (think thief- think pickpocket) and overall bespoke mission that must be achieved on each level. Each level has it's own missions too: acquire document, steal item, release prisoner, neutralize folk, destroy object etc.

Growing up with low graphics, memory and processor meant that my imagination had to fill in the gaps. Streets of Rogue really hits that spot. Each game has its own stories to tell. It suggests so many procedural, branching plot-lines that it's strength as a solid RPG is supported by the extent of the imagination of the player. 

So, if you want a fun way to occupy a billion half-hours then I truly recommend. It's really fun. I like hunting shapeshifters, they look like normal people but have a red tint to their eyes. You have to kill their host and then this nasty little (tiny) person runs away to claim a new victim. If you kill them they give you a nice payday. 

So, what will you do when you meet the Mayor? Befriend him, blackmail him or blow up his house with TNT? That choice, and a thousand others, await you in every game. Kudos to those who produced something truly and brilliantly amusing. I'm really looking forward to Streets of Rogue 2 too. I'd love to see a good road map. 

Round-up: So I love EU4 and Crusader Kings as dinner but Streets of Rogue is the best meal of the day with LSD and chocolate sauce on. That's brunch, by the way. Takes the pressure off both meals. Buy the game and if Streets of Rogue 2 has multiplayer we could meet up and heist a bank together. I suggest you play with 'rogue vision' and 'continue' as mutators. Have fun and tell me what you think.

On top of the 30+ hours I have on steam I have also sunk 60+ hours into this game on switch and, in my opinion, this is one of the best indie games that I've played in a long time. It has a certain video game-ee feel that not many other rouge-likes have. I love games like Gungeon and Hades, and don't get me wrong, those are fantastic games, but they also feel kinda (for lack of a better word) formulaic in their design. Go into this room and kill these guys then go into this room and kill these guys. Streets of Rogue also has very similar objectives but it gives you the freedom to explore those objectives in any way you want. Sabotage the ventilation system to lure your target outside, blow up the walls of the building to kill them easier, kill them with a refrigerator gone rogue, there are so many ways to experiment in each level with the wacky items and weapons that the game feels fresh every time you play it.

The 600 hour estimate of playtime in the ad is a bit too omtimistic, but you'll definitelly get your money's worth out of this one IF you don't mind roguelike mechanics too much (you don't have to like them). 

[h1]Why this one stands out[/h1]
Most (not all) of my points can be summarized as "Variety" . Here are the main few:
[list]
    [*][b]Sandbox-y[/b]. This is the biggest advantage this game has, because it gives you several ways to perform the same task.
    [*][b]Multiple classes/characters, with distinct playstyles[/b]. For example, soldier is an average starting class, a robot is built for OP melee, but runs on a rechargeable battery (puts some pressure) and a doctor is not allowed to kill, but can permanently put NPCs to sleep.
    [*][b]Different playstyles are supported[/b]. This is the first roguelike I play where the main goal isn't just killing everything that comes close to you (although you can!).
    [*][b]Procedurally generated levels and random quests.[/b] This is a relatively small point, but it essentially means, that even if you always play the same character, playthroughs will feel slightly different.
    [*][b]Random loot[/b] This is another relatively small point. Loot varies and RNG can either give you a massive advantage by getting exact weapons you need or limit your options by getting a few bananas.
    [*][b]Custom character[/b]. Once you get bored, you can mix and match abilities and drawbacks of other classes to create a custom one. 
   [*][b]It doesn't take itself seriously.[/b] Vast majority of games can't pull off meaningful lore or plot, but they still try.... That makes games that can laugh at their own flaws so much better. Here's a quote: 
The Zombie doesn't actually want to eat people's brains. I mean that's pretty gross. However, society expects it....
[/list]

[h1]Difficulty[/h1]
It's definitely not easy to start out. Everything, including weapons and armor in this game breaks, so you can't just go in and kill everything, unless you can do it with fists (and that takes some practice). It takes a little while to get accustomed to the rules of the game, but I would say the difficulty is fair. 
I did get frustrated a few times, like when I was playing a slow, calculating stealth class and then the floor filled with slime (which pretty much means you have to do things fast or die) and essentially killed me. I came back to the game, though which says a lot how good it is.

[h1]Drawbacks[/h1]
[list]
    [*][b]RNG[/b] I mentioned RNG being a good thing for keeping the game fresh, but it comes with a chance that you will be places in an unwinnable (with specific class) stage, or trip you up towards the end of a playthrough.
    [*][b]Steep learning curve[/b]. It takes like 5 minutes to get the core mechanics, but the game doesn't tell you much about anything else. For example.: you'll find machines like ATM or Loadout-o-matic (or something like that) and it's not immediately clear what they do (even if you interact with them).
   [*][b]Some characters feel useless[/b]. That is not to say that they ARE useless, but this is another thing the game fails to explain. Characters like Bartender do not appear to serve any purpose until you learn some of game's mechanics.
   [*][b]Roguelike[/b]. As I previously mentioned, I am not a fan of roguelikes in general and this one shares most of common complaints about roguelikes. The problems are alleviated by game's great design, but restarting over and over again for stupid reasons is still annoying.
[/list]

As mentioned before I would recommend this game to anyone who does not hate roguelikes. It's a unique one.

I am a 38 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 11 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

This game is like no other. It's an immersive sim rougelite. What this means is that, unlike in other rougelite games, combat is not always the best option. Matter of fact, frequently it's not even a good option. Instead, you could sneak and steal to get your objective, or maybe outright bribe someone for it. 
And unlike other immersive sim games, the map is different every run. This (alongside the impressive roster) means that every run will proceed very differently. Add to that mutators (toggleable options that can drastically change how the game behaves) and you have a game with insane replay value.
Also it has Workshop support, with a build it chunk and campaign editor. That's right, you can create and play hand-crafted experiences if you don't particularly like the randomness of a rougelite

This game is so good and it's criminal that it was not the game of the year for 2019.  

A game that's actually a game, has good controls and gameplay, very much an open world in the true sense of the world in that you can do things however you wish in very stealthy, normal, or chaotic ways (or anything between).  A game with real challenge, with a lot of ways to experiment with the formula, and tons of unique playable characters that really make you re-evaluate how you are going to play.

You can't get any better than this these days.  A game like this is one in a million.  Honestly, this and Terraria are the two best games that have come out since the year 2000, and I'm not exaggerating.

This is a game I've had on my wishlist for a long time now. I can't believe only just recently have I decided to purchase this game because it is absolutely spectacular! This is a very unique game compared to most that share its genre. It feels more like an RP game at times because each character is based off of someone that would live in a city and they each play differently from each other. (Obviously characters such as the Gorilla and Vampire don't count, but it's still fun to play as all of them) Although the game gives you an objective and is mission based, you are given total control on how you complete those missions and along with the procedural generation of levels makes the game incredibly replayable. The huge amount of unlocks such as weapons, items, traits, and mutators allows for a personalized experience of your own. With a very ambitious sequel in development, it makes me even more excited to how the could possibly make this game even greater? Overall, this is one of the most fun and interesting rogue-lites I have ever played and I just can't wait for the sequel! Pick this game up, it will change your perspective on all things ROGUE.

This game saved my life.

I am 42.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.       Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥️♥️♥️♥️♥️♥️♥️ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

Get a job to steal a priceless teleportation device from a government lab. Hack into a refrigerator and make it explode, drawing everyone's attention to the noise. Before they arrive, place a holographic monkey in the debris to distract them with it's hypnotic moves. Lockpick the front door, and make your way to the room you blew a hole in. Surround the door with landmines. Slip past the security cam using a smoke bomb, and toss a rock in the hall to disarm the crushing-spike. Guard posted in locked room, no problem. Put a bomb on the door, knock, and run like hell. Steal the device from room secretly repainted, and run out door. Walk out of the door and quickly get mugged by the mafia, who then shoot you down in the streets for not having enough cash. Love this game.
fun

Streets of Rogue is a decent enough game but mostly comes off as frustrating and annoying.

On the positive side, there're plenty of characters to unlock who all have slightly differing stats, traits, special abilities (some have none), and a big quest. The Cop has the ability to arrest people and wants to arrest/kill a certain number of people each floor. The Vampire only gets health back by using his special ability to suck blood from people and wants to kill all werewolves. The Gorilla has high stats but can't speak to people, shop owners don't want him in their stores, and his big quest is to free all other captured gorillas.

There're plenty of unlockable traits and item rewards from objectives. You can select which traits and items you want to show up but must keep a certain minimum number for each. They'll take a bit to unlock as you don't earn that many chicken nuggets (the currency for unlocking stuff) even on a completed run.

The last big thing is that the levels feel somewhat alive as even when you're offscreen, people are wandering about doing whatever. If a cop sees someone commit a crime, they'll go attack that person. If the blue gang sees the red gang, they'll get in a street fight, etc. You'll occasionally hear stuff going on offscreen and occasionally stumble onto some dead bodies and items lying around. Sometimes people get killed by random level obstacles.

The game has a lot of problem. It's split into 5 zones consisting of 3 levels each + the final level. The zones are different, but mostly in just annoying ways. The 2nd zone has hazards (explosive/poison barrels, minecarts) all over the levels that you have to watch out for. The 3rd zone has cannibals hiding in bushes that will pop out and attack you if you get too close. The 4th zone has gangsters roaming in packs of 3 who will randomly decide they want to take your money. There're also sewer grates all over the place where thieves will randomly jump out of and rob you. The final zone has roving robots that will attack you if they spot you for long enough. Anytime a robot or cop is engaged with you, the level throws up huge barriers blocking you in with your enemies.

Besides that, the game is incredibly repetitive. To finish a level, you need to complete 2-3 objectives. These objectives are all pretty much the same. Kill this guy, get this thing from this guy (usually by killing), press these buttons, destroy this object. Even playing as different characters doesn't change much up. If you're the cop, you're gonna play mostly the same as every other character, just make sure to arrest some people each level. If you're the vampire, you're gonna play mostly the same as every other character, if you find a werewolf, kill them. If you're low on health, find someone alone and drink their blood. Playing as the zombie and want to make zombie hoards. Sure that's fine for the first 2-3 levels, but you're going to be doing this for another 12 levels and it's time consuming. By 4-6 hours in, you've pretty much seen everything.

There're a lot of items but ultimately you won't ever use the vast majority of them, simply because you forgot that you have them or because they're not really as useful as you would like them to be. I've got this hacking device, surely I'll hack a computer in the future. Odds are you never will because there's rarely ever a need to. I've got these window cutters, I'll sneak into some buildings. Odds are you never will unless it's the only way in without causing some sort of mass riot. Your inventory will constantly be filled with stuff you think you might need in the future, but probably never will as it's rarely necessary. You're better off just selling most of it.

The melee combat in this is terrible. To start, every time you or someone else get hit, they go flying 10-15 feet away. There will often be large scrums of 4-8 people, so good luck keeping track of where you and your enemies are when everyone is flying around the room. Because of this, melee combat often devolves down to you just spamming the attack button in their direction or a circle around you. Hitting enemies can cause them to go flying into walls, destroying them. This means everyone outside gets to see what you're doing and often causes police/anyone allied with them to come flying in and start shooting/attacking you. There's no reason for this to exist other than the fact that if you could fight people one on one constantly there wouldn't be much challenge. So breaking walls was added to randomly create chaos to fuck you over. 

You can get/hire people to follow you around as a crew. By default, you're able to attack people in your group or allied with you. If you decide it'll be fun to form a gang, odds are you'll hit most of your crew in a fight against one person. In any sort of large scrum you'll almost certainly accidentally murder your whole crew. There's a trait you can level up and get that prevents you from hitting your teammates, but you have to be fortunate enough for it to randomly show up. Some classes like the zombie start with this. Even more fun than this though is that your crew will often incidentally hit someone not involved in a fight and now that person is hostile to you. This will often cause a 3 v 1 fight to turn into a 3 v 15 fight as half the level is now hostile at you, despite you not even doing anything. You're better off not having any followers since odds are at some point, they'll do something to get you killed.

I've already mentioned some of it, but there's a ton of random nonsense that will annoy/frustrate you or simply get you killed. For instance, every 3rd level in a zone has a random mutator that causes some event. This can include things like a killer robot shooting rockets at you all level long, a gang war, police attacking anyone outside, or after a minute or two a sludge starts filling up the level and you lose 2 health each second you walk through it. One of the mutators causes random status effects every 15 seconds. One status effect is "Dizzy" which makes you lose complete control of your character as he wanders around in a small circle. Have fun if someone is hostile to you and you randomly get the dizzy status... cause you'll be dead before you get control back. The third zone will sometimes have landmines randomly placed around so you'll sometimes stop somewhere to do something and get blown up. Expect most of your deaths to be a result of some random nonsense.

Then there's the annoyance of constantly having to be alert for any number of things. Oh, here comes a thief down the street, better change directions or he might randomly rob me. Oh, here comes a vampire down the street, better change directions or he might randomly bite me. Oh, there're some cannibals, better walk another way or they'll attack me. Oh, here comes a zombie. Oh, here comes a robot, gotta run away from him or wait for him to go somewhere else, oh look land mines, oh look explosive barrels, oh look poison barrels, oh look wall thompers, oh look a switch that activates pits, oh look grates that shoot out fire, etc.

Only bug I can remember running into is that occasionally some person, in a building with no windows, would magically see me through a wall, turn hostile, and come running out of their building to attack me.

Streets of Rogue is somewhere around an above average game that is fine for killing some time, but it quickly gets too repetitive. It seems like it wants to encourage you to try doing interesting stuff, but there's either no reason to most of the time, punishes you for doing so, or just frustrates you with the random annoying garbage that occurs.

Always loved the game and the concept. The pixel art can be tiring to the eyes, but it is simple enough to play longer instances than other pixel styled games.

In all seriousness, god DANG buy this game right now!! It has no rights being this cheap right now so get it quick!
If you want an actual reason why this game is good, everything about it is so charming and fun! The dialogue, the strange people you meet, the item descriptions, and even ways to kill people can be quite funny (Yes I died to my own banana peel I threw on the ground myself before)
I'll admit myself, I actually didn't think I'd like this game when I first started back in 2020. Everything felt a little slow to me and I was even considering just getting a refund but I gave it the benefit of doubt and decided to just keep on going. Boy was I glad because it ended up being the best thing ever. There are many different classes to choose from fitting different play styles! You can play as the Soldier who has lots of weapons so you can easily barge into places and kill everyone for your mission, or if you don't like that the Doctor allows you to play it more sneakily and safely, not being able to use most weapons but having the ability to knock out foes from behind with just a single click! Along with having a tranquilizer gun! Playing as a Gangster? Recruit your gang members across the maps and get them to do your biddings for you! (Admittedly they do get more scarce later on in the levels lol) Are you a cannibal? Eat the dead bodies to restore health! Especially when they are cooked! Are you a comedian? Tell jokes to the poor passerby and they can kill for you... or kill you!
You also get a lot of items in this game as an award for completing missions (or sometimes you find them in the trash lol) which you can use for your other missions, like infiltrating a vent with cyanide and killing everyone in a building! Or infiltrating it with "Rage Poison" instead and having everyone who takes it in kill each other! Or putting a boom box outside in a floor of deadly ooze that slowly kills all the people that run to it as they slowly dance to death! Also, every time you level up and get to the end of a level, you can unlock new abilities from a random list that'll help you even more!
At the end of every three levels there will be disasters that will spice the gameplay up and will force you to think quick! Finish the level before the zombies get to you, the killer robot is out to kill you, there's literally a war going on oh my god don't get killed, DEACTIVATE THE BOMBS IN A FEW MINUTES BEFORE THE ENTIRE LEVEL EXPLODES which is my personal favorite for how my first time getting that one I was two seconds away from blowing up everything!
Especially with every level being randomly generated, this game can offer a lot of variety and uniqueness that makes it really enjoyable with replay value! I find myself coming back to the game a lot because of that!
God this game is so fun and multiplayer gives you a whole other experience lmao, I'll admit I don't know how online is today but the absurd but hilarious people I randomly met before on random servers I hopped into were the best thing ever, it would be so chaotic but really funny and fun seeing everyone just kill and blow up everything haha, if you have a friend, co-op will give you an interesting time!

Overall, this game is quite the experience especially with how cheap it is right now. I think my decent chunk of playtime says a lot about how much I think this game is good and to be honestly I didn't realize I played it that much, just get this game right now dangit!!

If you're the kind of gamer who:

- Loves the rogue-like genre,
- Wants options on how you complete missions,
- Needs a replayability factor for hours of gameplay,
- Is looking for a new setting with lots of danger and excitment,
- Wants a funky but not obstrusive soundtrack,
- Likes a dose of humor and insanity with their games with all the situations that arise,
- Enjoys a fair amount of customizability with their experience,
- Craves a challenge at times OR just a casual playthrough at others,
- More content being added fairly often (as of this point),
- Needs a fun multiplayer AND singleplayer experience,

And can deal with:

- The 'stealth' being a little bit too difficult sometimes (The game often favors a smash-and-run play type).
- A FEW minor bugs here and there, especially in multiplayer
- Sometimes feeling like a death was unfair because of the chaos that arises,
- The game not being... oh, wait, it's finished! And is super fun all around, with a sequel on the way!
- Killer robots

Then Streets of Rogue will give you some fun experiences you won't regret buying. I've loved this game from the very first run, becoming a gang-member and getting into a turf war only to be exploded by a rocket-weilding robot. Although the stealth option isn't the best yet, and you often find yourself dying in ridiculous circumstances, this game offers challenge and fun with every character, level, mission and item. It's well developed and is only getting better, which is worth the price. If only we ran on chicken nugget currency...

I also didn't know that when the Mob shakes you down for protection you can offer them a slave as payment or that you can use a cardboard box to disguise your identity in public. I discovered these things through experimentation. Heck, the game even checks if you have been caught under a cardboard box by someone before to determine whether they will fall for the same trick again!

Also, special thanks to whoever made the executive decision to include an "Are you sure?" for trying to leave a level before completing necessary Big Quest objectives. Saved my skin twice.

You know what? I've held this review off long enough. Streets of Rogue is not only a masterpiece worthy of every bit of praise it receives. But it has the honour (at the time of this review) of being the only roguelike I have actually finished.

Streets of Rogue's premise is so simple, I can sum it up quickly, yet so complex, I can keep playing again and again and again.
The city's mayor is corrupt and you need to overthrow him. But before you can do so you need to clear a series of missions given to you on each floor of the city.

How you clear those missions is entirely up to you. Need to take an item off someone? You could pickpocket them, bribe them with money or a rare item, buy it off them, enslave them so they have to give it to you, hypnotise them into giving it to you, gather some goons and weapons and threaten them... ... ... or just straight up kill the guy and take it. Whatever works.

The only limitation you have is defined by your choice of character. All of which have a skillset that completely affects how you play the game. You could be knocking people out quietly to avoid killing as a doctor. Stealing bodies to disguise yourself because everyone hates you as a shapeshifter, offering drinks safe and hazardous as a bartender, obeying the law as a cop, turning security systems on their owners as a hacker, hunting werewolves as a vampire, you can even be a zombie and turn the entire map into your very own apocalypse.

And if that's not enough, you can even make your own with all the skills you've unlocked.

There's a lot going on and I often wonder how the developer, Matt Debrowski finds time for everything. When  I emailed him about my issues with the werewolf, he happily responded and explained what I was doing wrong. Turns out you've got to lunge like there's no tomorrow once transformed.

Seriously, this game's so good I've bought it twice. (on PC and Switch) and if the regular updates on the upcoming sequel are anything to go by, we have a lot to be hyped for... ... ... so... no pressure then.

Streets of Rogue is deceptively simple - you have melee and ranged weapons, special abilities, an inventory, money, and so on. All you have to do is get through a number of floors, populated with civilians, gangsters, cops, and much more.
But then you discover you can bribe some enemies, even win them over to your side. And then you find a posession stone, and suddenly you can possess anyone, say, the police - who now trust you with their keys to the cells. So you free a handful of criminals who run amok, creating just the diversion you need to move on.

And so, so many other things. It's a true joy to cause havoc in this game. Commune with animals, and let gorillas do your talking for you. Or play as a zombie, and turn the whole population into green friends!

Speaking of friends, the game truly shines in coop multiplayer. There are endless strategies to explore, and cooperating is a mixture of delicate planning and aggressive creativity.

Between the wide range of items, perks and NPC's, and the more than reasonable price - just buy this game. It's condensed fun, through-and-through. Plays well with Steam's remote play too!

Streets of Rouge is a very unique rougelike title. A lot of the difficulty is variable and this game values the player's choices on how hard they want the game to be. Not many rougelikes offer what is essentially a difficulty slider with a lot of buttons in favor of making the player die over and over again. Granted you can die in Streets of Rouge as easily as any other rougelike, but I've found this one to be the most enjoyable that I've ever played. Gameplay is somewhat simple, but nuanced enough to where anyone can quickly pick up the game, and the immersive sim elements are very entertaining to watch play out. The levels are very interactive, and it makes the game feel like a large sandbox that can kill you.

This game's somewhat limited, despite having user generated content and a workshop. If there was an easy way to mod the game and publish those mods on the steam workshop instead of a third party website then I believe that the game would become far more replayable than it is now. Another issue I have with the game is that going through the same five regions tends to get really repetitive. The Binding of Isaac made sure this was less of an issue by extending the run's endpoint after beating an important boss on top of adding alternate areas with different gimmicks to occasionally replace the ones that you'd run into. One last thing: this game is heavily underrated. While I've noticed the game has streaming integration, it doesn't really have enough players or an active community behind it. I think that a decently large update being released for free that adds on to all of the good mechanics already in place while also adding newer content would help it greatly.

I personally think this game's worth the money, but if it's not for you then I understand.

Large roster of wacky characters and bloody ridiculous number of items/traits/gameplay mutators. It's remarkably replayable. Definitely recommend putting effort into unlocking new characters so the game can really open up to you. The character pack DLC isn't an absolute must, but I recommend it.
There's a lot of unique, very niche item and character interaction. Did you know that jumping into a contaminated body of water refills your empty water pistol? Or that fud can be grilled over a lit barbeque to triple its effectiveness? Characters that are shrunk can limbo underneath laser detectors.
With NPCs, there are a lot of behaviour patterns that are hard to learn but rewarding to be aware of.
Wandering thieves and vampires will strike if you're in their sight for too long and mobsters will mug you. Drug dealers take drugs in combat. Slum dwellers will pick up stray cash on the ground. Rare shapeshifters hide in the bodies of random citizens.
The soundtrack is gorgeous, Craig Barnes nailed every level. I often listen to it outside of playing the game.

Since I bought it in 2017, it has consistently been my best game owned. Very well polished.

Awesome procedurally generated landscapes that provide a shmorgasboard of events, friends, foes and hidden prizes and risks that will keep you collecting nuggets. Learn your characters abilities and leverage the world to your benefit. Whether you're charging the finish line as a herd of gorillas, taking on the streets as a Crepe or Blahd or creating chaos and taking all as the hacker, there's a lot of fun to be had. If the mayoral election is too lofty an goal, the daily runs are great fun and you should definitely check out the workshop items for some seriously badass custom maps. In all, a great way to spend 10 minutes or 10 hours.

This game is outrageously good for all the reasons other people have said. Procedurally generated city environments with a focus on neutral NPCs to interact with, emergent gameplay with countless interconnected mechanics that make every mission beatable with a huge range of strategies, goofy kitchen sink setting that cares more about being fun than anything else, etc. You should probably already know if you want to get the game (you do) based on that, but there are two underrated features that I think are worth mentioning which provide far more content than you might expect.

The first is the level editor. For whatever reason many fans of the game don't even seem to realize one exists, but it's amazingly powerful in terms of what it allows you to add to the game and the variety this brings is... well, not infinite, but close enough. You can fully build levels and campaigns from the ground up, which would be cool enough on its own, but what really makes this shine are the chunk packs. These add additional buildings and terrain to the level generation that can be mixed and matched for any of your normal runs. If you're even a little familiar with roguelikes you should realize how great this is, new level layouts are the lifeblood of the genre and this makes them functionally limitless (you don't even have to do work yourself, plenty of packs exist in the workshop already that collectively add thousands of new locations to visit).

The other underrated feature is the mutator system, the obligatory modifiers that vary the rules of a run. It's not unexpected but it's worth mentioning just how many additional gameplay modes these open up. Miss Hotline Miami? Turn on low health for all, now you have access to infinite randomly generated HM levels. Turning on disasters every floor and excluding all but one makes that disaster happen on every floor... obviously, but experiencing the entire game as a raging warzone or a mad dash to disarm bombs hidden around the city can be very fun and different.

Combining mutators and custom content can rework the entire game in some surprisingly versatile ways. At the end of the day it's still the same topdown roguelike as the vanilla game, but the point is that if the concept of this game appeals to you even slightly then the $20 price tag is a ridiculous bargain for the amount of content available. I'd easily consider this my favorite game of the past decade and with over 2,500 hours invested so far I still can't see stopping anytime soon, it's kinda like Minecraft but if every house you built got added to the world generation and then served as the stage for some really zany action movie hijinks.

Okay, the like 2 people tops who read any of my previous reviews probably expect more.

Alright, so, here's the deal: You're a member of a resistance in some chaotic layered city. The mayor has banned chicken nuggets. It's time to overthrow them, going from the tiny wooden buildings and rampant crime of the slums at the bottom to the gold-lined Mayor's Village at the top. Sounds pretty simple, right? Of course, the leaders of the resistance have things for you to do on each floor before you move on. Retrieve some compromising evidence, rescue some poor sap, 'neutralize' someone, push some buttons in a secure building...

You could, of course, do the simple yet perhaps boring thing of shooting everyone who gets in your way down as a Soldier, well equipped for such business. Or maybe you're a Thief who's more skilled at sneaking around, taking stuff right out of people's inventory, and running away. A doctor with a vow of non-violence and a rag doused in chloroform? Or perhaps a slum dweller, with nothing to your name but a bottle of whiskey and the promise of getting stronger and richer if you somehow pull off reaching the top.
The tools you have available will define how you approach problems. Hire some gangsters to do the dirty work? HIre a thief to open a path more sneakily? Burst in and fire away like a maniac? Or maybe you've got some oddball items to deal with the current situation... Poison in the vents could do a lot,, if you avoid the cops' notice, or you could switch places with your target while surrounded in traps in a secure building filled with guards. Then again, perhaps a bit of bribery will do the trick.
If all else fails, there might be the chance to start some gang violence, the two local gangs truly hate each other. They'll fight on sight!

Truly, a bit of creativity goes a long way, when the streets are (mostly) safe for you to plan in.

Though sometimes, they're not so safe. On the last floor of each district, chaos takes hold. A bounty on your head, forcing you to be careful as any shopkeeper or person you might want to hire could be wanting to collect instead, a riot in which everyone outside will strike at anyone they see, a zombie apocalypse, a killer robot with a rocket launcher slowly pursuiing you... A lot more trouble awaits on those floors... But perhaps some opportunities, too. Zombies might be able to do what you can't, with some baiting, and the upside of having a rocket launcher predictably fired at you is that you can kinda direct where dodged rockets will land, maybe opening a big hole in a building that would otherwise have required you to slip through security.

From there, all that's left is optionally accomplishing your character's personal goals. Buy a house in the posh Uptown, eradicate the opposing gang, avoid killing, steal stuff beyond what you're instructed to, that kind of stuff! And if you're nice enough to the people who aren't... Indisposed, by the time you leave the floor, who knows, perhaps when the time comes, you can simply be elected mayor.

And then there's multiplayer, up to 4 people playing different classes!
Perhaps a Soldier providing the power, and a Scientist offering oddball tools and syringe buffs? Both types of gangsters, able to manipulate both gangs but having to avoid each other while you do so lest your followers attack the other? A hacker to deal with electronics, a thief to open doors and safes, a doctor to knock people out- Wait, is this Monaco now!?
The options for teamwork... Or madcap chaos that gets in each other's way as the Zombie player starts a mini-apocalypse each floor and the Soldier fails to exercise restraint when using explosives.

And that's before you add mutators to customize the experience! Maybe everyone, including yourself, is squishier. Maybe everyone has guns. Maybe everyone has [i]rocket launchers[/i]! Or maybe the zombie apocalypse is upon us. Or perhaps breakable weapons aren't your jam, and you'd like them to be unbreakable? Quite a bit of customization, especially when you can also create your own character with a customized inventory, with a points system for a semblance of balance... That you can completely ignore if you're willing not to unlock anything while playing them, because maybe you really do just want to mess around with a really OP character.

So what are you waiting for? It's time to see what emergent gameplay can really be.

Streets of Rogue isn't a bad game but it doesn't really have a strong hook. Its one of those roguelites where buying new unlocks dilutes the pool of things you can get randomly in the field and makes it harder to get what you want which, unfortunately, makes unlocking upgrades a kiss-curse.

It IS fun which is why I gave it a thumbs up but I only played it for a day or two before I got bored. You can do a lot of interesting things but the number and variety of interactions is not what the trailer hypes it up to be. Its also one of those games where you can be doing great for hours and one wrong throw or miscalculated angle (or hell, random event) could instantly end your run.

For $10 or less you'd certainly be able to get some enjoyment exploring and trying out new things but it didn’t have the staying power of a roguelite with a true progress path or the raw indulgence of skill progression from a true roguelike.

Streets of Rogue represents emergent chaotic roguelite fun. Utilising a range of special class skills, tools and the environment, work your through an immersive interactive city, level by level, completing a range of missions and avoiding dangers.

Much of the fun comes from the emergent behaviour of other characters as they interact with you, the environment and each other. Even after >100 hours of gameplay, this game still throws up the occasional surprise scenario.

EDIT: I just discovered the dev, Matt Dabrowski, was once-upon-a-time involved in the ZZT community, which is an awesome headfuck.

Yes

Ton of different fight scenario's that most of the time you're able to foresee and execute. 

Examples: I could toss a grenade in through the window after I break it; I could put poison into the air ducts to weaken or simply kill everyone inside; Go in guns blazing!?; Bare knuckle it up, or I could place an Explosive device near an outside wall to my objective, give the enemies an invisible kiss and run far away while I watch them get blown apart in a smokey aftermath of carnage. 

Tons of playable characters and even some to unlock! Most if not all have different abilities so you are able to come at every individualized map how YOU want too! For some players, the pacifist route might be the way to go, or even silent as a ninja, killing nothing, but taking everything.

There are perks you gain in-between levels depending if you leveled up during the current map you're on that help enhance who you are, and how you play to give everything a little added spice.

You also have the ability to CREATE YOUR OWN CHARACTER! You have a certain amount of points and ability points you can spend on any newly made character and this is where after you've beaten the game a few times and know your playstyle, you can create the ULTIMATE YOU!

Will you be the force the resistance has been needing, or will you become part of why it was created?

Play hard and have fun Gamers!

The only things I wish more of is more tasks and more playable characters, there's a lot of playable characters already but they all have very apparent difficulty differences than eachother so you never really play some characters more than once, you can create your own custom characters with their own sets of skills and abilities but I never really used that feature besides to unlock a couple of characters, there's also workshop custom characters as well but I haven't looked at many to say whether it's good or bad. Tasks do get a little repetitive after playing for like 100 hours but still feel fresh during runs (it never feels like you do the same task you did last floor but can be predictable at times). The absolute best 2D game for people who like immersive sims, chaotic games, or anything like the recent Hitman games where you carefully make a plan and then it explodes under pressure hilariously.

Some of the humor isn't great, it's a little weird on occasion, but overall if you want a game that has a lot of replayability, ridiculous consequences for ridiculous actions, or maybe you just want to free all gorillas and become Mayor, go for this game.

Guess I should not have waited a year to try it - I was under the impression you had a city map to explore, similar to but not the same as older 2D GTA's.  Instead it's just "floors" and there is no set character to RPG as, you just run around as different classes from a base (leveling them up and unlocking others) and then explore small "floors" with specific objectives and very, VERY basic interactions that the store page will make you believe has way more depth than it does.

This game could easily be a phone game, its so simple and basic and over-designed.

Watch a play-through and ignore much of what the store page claims - this is not some rpg-ish thing, you have limited options and very specific objectives on small floors and this might as well be a single-dungeon roguelike vs the ones where you at least have an over-world of some type.

Lots of replay-ability thanks to the unlock-able content and how different the experience is playing each character. After 100 hours, I still haven't played every character and I'm less than 50% of the way to unlocking everything. It's easy to introduce new players to the game, even if they don't game much. And playing is fun even if you aren't winning. Both local co-op & online multiplayer are super smooth. In multiplayer, a teammate can revive you by sacrificing money or health. So, when things go hilariously wrong, not all hope for the run is lost. In single-player, dying due to RNG or a ridiculous situation can be a little frustrating since you lose the run immediately and you don't have friends to laugh with over it. Highly recommend playing with friends! You have to play a lot more carefully in single-player, so it's slower and a little less fun, but I'm sure some players enjoy the additional challenge.

Absolutely worth it.  Perfect amount of risk and reward, as both success and failure rarely feel unearned.  Most of the time I flub a run, it is usually the result of greedily trying to get those few extra xp's, and the few times where chance is seemingly against you at every step, the comedy of just how out of control the situation can get really takes the sting out of having to try again.  Combine this with being able to tailor your own experience with mutations that alter the stages and rules that govern them, and the ability to create and share maps and characters with others through Steam Workshop, and you have a formula for a game that has much more longevity than you would expect from something that relies so much on random generation.  Phenomenal.

I appreciated this, because some of the defaults are truly awful (in particular every third stage has some random crazy thing, which is meant to mix things up but IMO should be off by default as they totally change the feel of the game). Best game ever. Period.

I have over 500 hours on the Xbox edition, and bought it again here just to support the developer and do even more stuff to contribute to the community!

The trailer might seem like your generic "Do anything! Be anything!" type of deal. You expect it to over-promise and give you only one slice of pie, *just like a certain game released by a certain critically acclaimed triple AAA game developer studio*

cough cough Cyberpunk 2077 cough cough

But, strangely enough, the trailer is kinda right. No, sorry, REALLY right. There are LOTS of stuff to do in the game. I'm too lazy to list them all, but there is a lot. TONS of characters to play around with, with each of them having unique traits that distinguish them from one another. Don't like them? MAKE YOUR OWN! Got tired of being alone? PLAY WITH UP TO 3 FRIENDS! Getting bored of the building layout and characters? INSTALL SOME WORKSHOP ADD-ONS! There is just so much you can do with this game!

The only cons I can think of is the multiplayer, both online and local. Online might be a bit toxic at times, and local only supports split screen with only 2 people, 3 and 4 people makes it so every person is on the same screen. It kinda restricts movement by teleporting players back near everyone else, and it might be hard to follow your character admits the chaos.

Other than that, I HIGHLY recommend playing this game. It's only 20 bucks for hundreds upon hundreds of hours of fun!

A game about trying stuff out to learn of new interactions, then putting them to use to pull off crazy low risk high reward plans. The penalty for messing up is the pure chaos that is an unexpected combat. I'm truly surprised by how thorough the mechanics of this game are; there are so many weird and wonderful edge case interactions and they just make sense. I've yet to find a situation where some random idea I had didn't work. Oh, and the music slaps.

I do Recommend it with the caveat that you may not play if for too long. 
Once i'd completed the game (which happened to be my second run) I've started struggling to become motivated to continue it. 
Thats not to say I think its a bad game at all, more that you see how little progression there is and in so, it makes future runs feel somewhat samey.

It might not look like much on the surface, but Streets of Rogue is one of those games that has high replayability and is one that you can always come back to and have fun. The gameplay itself promotes creative thinking as you run through the levels and try to complete your objectives, whether that being taking out an NPC or clicking some buttons within a time limit. With a large cast of unique characters and a ton of items that do all sorts of things, I would recommend this game to anyone who likes character progression. You choose how you interact with your environment, NPCs, enemies, and there is no "correct" way of completing the missions. Overall, similar to Enter the Gungeon in terms of progression but definitely worth your time and money!

Btw I would say it's worth like $15 instead of $20 but that's just me.

As a game to play solo, Streets of Rogue does not thrill me. It doesn't engender the absolute disgust that, say, Heroes of Hammerwatch does, but I still probably wouldn't play it solo very much.

As a game to play co-op however, Streets of Rogue becomes absolutely bonkers. Have a vampire grab someone and start sucking their blood, causing their three friends to turn around in shock and prepare to attack, just before a gorilla with a battleaxe lands his charge-up swing and reduces the friends to a fine mist? Absolutely. 1337 Hackerman bullcrap while an ayylamo and a zombie distract everyone? Go for it.

I just beat the game for the first time, and I have to say that Streets of Rogue is good.

Like... 

REALLY good. It is shocking to me how a game that I have never heard about in the years it has been out is as good as it is. I am actually upset that I didn't find this game sooner!

Usually a game that promotes as much freedom as this game does usually has the caveat of, "Just shooting the guy is the best way to solve the problem." Not this game. Combat, stealth, diplomacy, and wacky antics are all equally viable.

Streets of Rogue also doesn't seem to promote the fact of just how many playable characters there are, and how unique they all are. It is absurd how much variety there is in the characters. Even characters who seem like they should play similarly like the wrestler and jock play far more different than I could ever expect. If you play as a zombie, it is gonna feel like you are a zombie! And in the statistically unlikely case none of the classes in the game feel like they quite click with you, you can create your own custom character!

On the subject of customization, if any aspects of the gameplay don't jive with you, the mutators allow you to enable or disable many option settings for the game. Don't like the third level? Have it not show up! Feel like characters have too much health? Lower it! Feel like the game isn't fast enough? Raise the speed of everything!

It has been a while since a game left me gobsmacked by how good it is. Get this game, it is too good to fade into obscurity. Legitimately one of the best roguelikes I've ever played.

Truly one of the better games to come out in sometime, Streets of Rogue is such a diverse mix of content that it truly is its own thing. It adds a bit of humor while tying it into a whole lot of gore! What's more, it is something that can be played with friends!

Probably the greatest thing about Streets of Rogue though is that you can very much play the game however you wish. Want to play it stealthy? Want to be socialable? Maybe you want to have a huge following of helpers? Maybe you just want to kill everything! You can probably find something that suits you here. Also, there is a workshop so you can make custom characters too.

I believe though that it really is just how replayable this game can be that is the biggest draw. Because of the plethora of characters and ways of gameplay you can explore there is a lot to come back too.

The page pretty much explains what the game is about. There are folks who complain that it gets repetitive after a while. I suspect most of them try to solve the problems with different characters in the same way each time. The delight is in embracing the role-playing potential for each character. So rather than bulldozing the entire map with a thief armed with a rifle, ditch the rifle. He's not that kinda guy. Do what an albeit stereotypical common thief would do and get a crowbar or window cutter instead. Get in, take what you need and get out unnoticed. Played this way, replayability is tremendous.  Controls are buttery smooth, too. Worth every penny.

The criminally underrated roguelike that undoubtably deserves a greater spotlight. The game has been created almost solely by Matt Dabrowski, who inserts his charm and creative flair into every ounce of each procedurally generated world. The unique roster of characters, combined with clever, intertwining mechanics leaves a sixteen level game extremely replayable and endlessly fun. Every character is entertaining in their own right, allowing the player to sneak their way through an entire level, or become an anti-social vampire or perhaps even instate a zombie apocalypse. The choices are truly endless.

Therefore, each run provides a new and engaging experience, similar to that of Gungeon. While not as dizzyingly expansive and polished as Gungeon is, Streets of Rogue is definitely worth every dollar it costs. If you appreciate the fun, timed bursts of entertaining of other roguelikes than this game is certainly a must to add to the steam collection.

Infinite game changes keep it interesting. Easy to play, hard to master - the perfect mix. Plenty of sarcastic humour and opportunities to play both stealth and attack. Good as a multiplayer game as well. Love this game.

You can complete the different missions and the main game in a ton of ways; want to be sneaky and stealthy, the game offers that, you want to go balls to the wall wither muscling everything out or go on exploding everything, that too you can do, you don't want to get your hands dirty? you can pay, trick, or force NPCs to do your bidding, that and the plenty number of playable characters each with their unique play style will offer you the flexibility no other roguelike to this date can offer.

The game has personality and enough content to keep you coming back, I can't recommend it enough.

I'm a new player of this game, but it's probably one of my favorites already, I've put in 15+ hours within my first 2 weeks of owning the game. The randomness of it is great, especially if you have a party of 3+ It's amazing how quick you can get into it. And don't get me started on it's comedic nature. This game never seizes to throw some comedy in. I completely recommend this to others. Currently, I have over 50 hours in it. Yes, sometimes the game can get repetitive, but the saving grace is downloadable chunks and chunk packs from the steam workshop, which breathe much more life into the game. Anyone can upload chunks and chunk packs, even full campaigns onto the steam workshop, which is great for variety. You can also download other's uploaded characters, to try out new styles.

Let me start by saying this game is amazing. The best way to describe it for me would be a combination of Enter the Gungeon, Broforce, and RotMG. That doesn't give an accurate description, but the closest to it I think. This game is unique, fun, hilarious, and replayable. I am only 24 hours in, but I know that there will be much more to come. The game has some serious role-playing ability if you're into that (in my opinion). This game has a wonderful sense of humor. I'm not recommending you buy this game, I'm begging you to please buy it.

Streets of Rogue is described best by itself as a "megagame", and at its core, its a game about the Sigma Grindset; everything, including people, are merely assets, a means to get to the top. You truly feel as though you can do anything, since there are a limited number of rules, resulting in everything that is there, be fully interactable with every other thing. Now, that's not to say that the limited number of elements is restrictive, since there is still a degree of variability in which you might commence a certain action. For example, the main thing you can do with a generator is have it blow up after a few seconds of taking enough damage. This can be done by many ways including, but not limited to, shooting with a gun, punching, hitting with a weapon, or even enslaving an npc and have them hit it for you. Once the generator has been hit, the sound will grab the attention of the landowner and any goons they might have in the vicinity. Then, the resulting explosion of course kills people in the vicinity, but also destroys wooden walls and will get the attention of nearby npcs. Every element of Streets of Rogue is fit together so perfectly to create a detailed simulation that the player can then go about completing their missions in any way they could think of, further enhanced by the variables that different characters provide and the gear they might have on hand.

   The overall gameplay of SoR is that of a rouge-lite, meaning you go through randomly generated levels and earn permanent character, gear, and trait unlocks through achievements and bonus missions on each level. Each level you need to complete 2 missions: these are either neutralizing someone, getting an item from somewhere or someone, or flipping switches inside a building. While these seem really repetitive, the variation that is inherent to the game as well as the freedom of approach you get, make these missions really fun, especially in the later levels when the stakes are increased and new elements are added. There are also optional "big quests" you can complete for xp that are unique to the character you're playing and will require you to do the same thing each floor such as destroy all generators or kill certain npcs. XP allows you to level up and choose from a randomly selected pool of traits, these give you new passive abilities that let you create and refine your own build as you play. There are 3 floors each stage and 5 stages. Each stage has a different gimmick to it which increases variety and adds new challenges for the player. Getting to the end solo on an early playthrough is very difficult but with unlockable characters that allow to find a playstyle you like combined with the new gear and traits you can put into rotation make it easier, but still intense. The game is also extremely fun co-op and can be delightfully chaotic but I don't have a lot of experience with it.

Streets of Rogue is an endlessly fun, very complex game that provides a fun sandbox to explore. If you enjoy rogelikes, immersive sims, or even just think the concept sounds cool, SoR is worth a play, especially at $20. Additionally, if you enjoy the game, I would say the character pack DLC is worth it since it gives you 6 new characters, 3 of which are basically playable npcs, and 3 being really unique characters that significantly change how you play. Mech pilot sucks though.

Would I recommend Streets?

This is a fun, rouge-lite game with tons of tongue in cheek humor and fantastic replay value. Between the randomly generated levels and variety of characters with different strengths and play styles, most runs will be meaningfully different. The core of the game centers around picking a character and using that character's abilities and items to complete a few objectives per floor. True to the basic rogue formula, you have only one life per run, but each run through the game only takes 45 minutes to a couple hours depending on your playstyle.

The real draw in the replayability, which comes from random level generation, and the myriad of character classes. Each character has a special ability to make them unique and guides their play style. For example, combat focused players might choose the soldier, who starts with weapons and grenades and has a special ability to heal when low on health. But combat does not need to be the core of the game; you can pick a character such as the bartender, who can mix drinks which can then be given to characters to make them friendly to you (or kill them depending on what you put in the drink!). This variation in characters plus the randomness of levels and items given to you creates great replay value.

The game sports pixel art graphics which fit the theme and gameplay style well. The music is top notch and I recommend the soundtrack.

This game is also great in co-op, where you can pick characters who complement each other to making penetrating the city and deposing the mayor much easier. If you find co-op makes things too easy, there are also mutations you can add to the mix to change gameplay elements such  as increasing enemy difficulty or adding a time limit to each floor. Or you can just be wacky and give everyone rocket launchers!

This is a game that really grows on you the more you play it and fiddle around with the innumerable characters and approaches you can have to the game. There's just tons of options here for people to find a playstyle or playstyles they'll enjoy that lead to all sorts of shenanigans. It's a silly game, but it stays grounded enough that things make sense and you can predictably approach things. It's just really open-ended and fun. 

The presentation is colorful and zany with fun, bombastic music to match the tone. It goes hand in hand with the easy-to-pickup nature of the game. If you are not feeling like playing anything else, why not jump in and do a few levels in Streets of Rogue? The stakes are low and the game isn't too punishing, but yet is not too easy either. It strikes a good balance that makes it fun.

I really recommend to everyone. It's got a lot to offer, especially for the price. And I hope to see a lot more from the developer!
