I bought this game for $5 and still feel my money would've been better spent elsewhere. Combat, mission structure, level and character design, everything here is obnoxiously repetitive and boring. It's "roguelike" elements are laughable at best and tedious at worst, with multiple playthroughs feeling near-identical due to the copy/paste formula that serves as the backbone for this entire experience. Sure, there is a wide roster of characters with varied-playstyles, but the mechanics are so mind-numbingly basic that any nuances between how each character plays merely serve to distract you from the fact that you'll be playing through the same levels, completing the same missions, killing the same enemies, and really just running through the motions time and time again.

I feel compelled to write this review because this game currently has an "Overwhelmingly Positive" reception on Steam. I simply can not fathom the appeal of the gameplay offered here. Running around a randomly-generated (and hideously ugly) map and spamming M1 is not my idea of a good time.

This game is pretty unique to say the least, you are basically dropped in a sizeable procedurally generated town and must complete/fail quests to progress (if you fail them you don't get a reward, but there's no other penalty), but the game grants a lot of freedom on how you play it.

You gain XP from just doing stuff (practically everything gives XP) and get to pick a new trait on level up which grants passives.
You also can select a class and even make one to start the game with, they vary quite a lot as do their playstyle, they affect your starter traits, items and most of the time also come with an unique ability.

The game really lets you play however you want, stealth, full on assault, charisma checks, etc.

This game is utter fucking insanity, the variety of viable playstyles, character variety, and sheer madness of the gameplay itself are incredible. I definitely recommend picking this game up, maybe play it with a friend or two. The custom character creation is really good, too. It lets you combine the traits and abilities of every class in the game to make whatever the hell you want (within reason).

Streets of Rouge is basically like GTA Online on crack and it's exactly that, crack in video game form as it is very addicting and wild (idk I never tried crack lol) but what exactly is it?

The game is a rouge-like* with every level being non linear and each having three missions plus a special mission if you find the person. How you finish them is completely up to you. Use your items, pay someone else to do it for you, maybe even do it yourself! You get to play as all sorts of characters, with each providing a unique gameplay style and a big quest (completing a big quest unlocks a super secret ability). You'll eventually start earning chicken nuggets to pay for more stuff to play with such as new items or traits for custom characters. Mutators spice up the game and could even help you turn it into GTA Online (turn on "everyone carries RPG" mutator) or even better, 2020 mode (I'll let you figure that combo out). Overall my opinion of Streets of Rouge is awesome, there isn't a game I played that's like this and I'd pay full price for this game (getting this game during a steam sale is also cool).

My IGN-based review:
10/10 - better than crack

This is one of the best games ever made.

One problem I always have with games where you have classes is that they don't really change the game too much. In the Endless series, for example, you can still play the game relatively the same with the same objectives regardless of whether you play the "economic", "diplomatic" or "military" faction.

Not in this game.

I have something like 80 hours in this game and I still feel as if there is so much of this game I have not played - because nearly every of the 30 ish characters are different.

Let me give some examples. 

You want this game to become a gang war simulator? You can play as the crepe or Bland, who can automatically make others join them and have the optional objective of wiping out all of the other.

You want to be a sneaky baka? You can be the assain, walking behind a bunch of people and 1 shoting them without anyone knowing you were ever there.

Or play a sneaky thief, using tools you buy from other thieves to avoid having to interact with anyone to get what you want.

Play as the mob, making the game into an extortion simulator, play as a zombie and track down every NPC as they try to hide in their homes, play as a hacker to turn of all the annoying police checkpoints so the citizens can't call for help, or play as a slave master to enslave people and force them to do your dirty work for you. 

All the characters change how you act towards a situation and how you account for the NPCs, which makes this game have endless replayablility. 

Plus I have encounted no bugs with the base game (although it of course gets a bit weird when you install like 10 packs to change up the world).

Streets of Rogue is...
Eeeh... Hmmm...
Mission based beat 'em up in small open levels...
Something like that.

Describing Streets of Rogue in simple way is very hard, so it's better to explain how you play this game, so you get the most accurate picture of this game.
So here we go:
You are part of the revolution group. Your target: The Mayer in Mayer City.
Choose your character with many possibilities and own personal side mission.
Every character has their own possible play-style, skill and possibilities after level-up.
Character examples: Thief, hacker, soldier, assassin, cop, fireman, comedian, street bum, werewolf, vampire, robot, scientist.

After character selection your game starts and you enter the slums.
Your goal is to complete stage's mission in order to get a permit to advance to the next stage.
For extra XP you have your personal mission based on your character.
How you do these is up to you:
Use bombs, be sneaky, gather a gang, shoot everyone, talk with charm, use bribes, make enemies fight each other.
Or have a accident, that solved your problem for your amusement.
Just don't get killed, okay.

Complete three stages to get into the nest area, that is different in some way from previous.
Each place has their people living there, doing their own stuff.
They can be friendly, neutral, annoyed, angry or murder happy dangerous killers, that want you dead.
Also there's people, who sells interesting stuff, like weapons, items, food, drinks, drugs, medical service and other stuff.
You can also hire people if you have money (and they tolerate you).
Just be careful to not get into trouble with police, as they are tough and armed.

Level up your character, learn new skills, get items and money, arm yourself, hire allies.
Then maybe, MAYBE, you manage to save this city from The Mayor.
Or become the next terrible mayor.
Or die by setting yourself on fire or getting eaten by cannibals.
I don't know.
Try again if you fail, since many things in this game are random or can be added / mutated.
Bring your friends also, so that there's some great team work (failure) to experience.

Positive Things:
+Big game with lot's of stuff.
+Many levels & different missions.
+Solo or Multiplayer ( 4 player co-op).
+Split-screen Local Multiplayer.
+Custom Character Creation.
+Randomness, so many fun randomness.
+Good sense of humour.
+Make your game easy or hard. It's your choice.
+Looks good.
+Many ways to play and challenge yourself.
+Stable game, never have crashed for me.

Negative Thing:
-Randomness CAN make things difficult for you.
-This isn't a easy game, but not in a bad way.
-This is kinda one of those games, where you create your own fun.
-Needs the use of imagination and sense of humour.
-Doesn't contain AAA-game style graphics.
-One live, no continues (although multiplayer has 'revive' system if at least one player is still alive).
-Need many controllers for local multiplayer, which can be a hassle to set.

want to rip and tear your way through the city machine guns blazing? You can do that.

all that, along with some great music, and some pretty good writing makes for a very good package that's worth every penny.

highly recommend getting it.

Streets of Rogue is a rogue-like game with a pixelated art style. In this game you go down floors and you have to complete the main objective on a floor to move on to the next one. You can complete other quests for more XP but they aren't required. Some objectives include infiltrating a building to rescue a prisoner or acquire something confidential (like an incriminating photo), or you might have to just kill a guy or a group of people. There are so many characters to play each with their own unique weapons, utilities, stats, traits, and a special ability. For example, I enjoy the Doctor who can knock out people with a Chlorophorm Hankie on a three second cooldown but cannot use any weapons apart from throwables like rocks and banana peels. I definitely would stream this because I think that it is quite entertaining. You sometimes get random events that happen on a floor. I one time got a zombie apocalypse floor where zombies infected literally everyone on the floor and I had to complete my objectives fast before it became unmanageable. I really like this game and I can't wait until I understand the mechanics more so I can exploit the hell out of them. 8/10 will most likely play religiously.

With roguelite games being a staple of the market these days, it's hard to find one that really stands out. Streets of Rogue definitely has the core concept of proceduraly generated levels, randomly placed powerups and light amounts of permanent progression, (gained by spending chicken nuggets in between). The way it stands out, however, is the freedom you get to use these benefits. Pre-generated classes with a vast amount of unlockable ones make for increasingly different playthroughs, each character having their unique ability and side-objective to complete or ignore at your leisure. 

Despite being developed by one person, Streets of Rogue continues to deliver a unique questing experience each playthrough. It accomplishes this by allowing you a large amount of inventory space and incredibly varied effects between each item you hold, with no cap on how you can use these items in tandem with one another. Each XP level you gain during your playthrough allows you to choose a feat from a randomly generated list, which can be more varied as you spend chicken nuggets on more traits to add to the pool. These concepts aren't things too alien to the industry, but put together in this manner, not to mention with the excellent coding ability of a single individual, it makes for a unique experience that'll keep you coming back. The Resistance needs you!

This game exemplifies player choice and emergent gameplay almost perfectly. You can turn this into a strategic puzzle game by playing hacker and thief and other passive classes, or a Hotline Miami style action game by putting on a few health modifiers and playing as the soldier or other combat classes (which still allows you to earn unlocks). Each class has a very distinct style and it's not just limited to "fight" and "don't fight" playstyles as there's a huge spectrum of actions you can take to try and survive your run.

It's very rare these days that a game surrenders itself to you and just lets you play whatever way you want and acknowleges it as a valid way to play. You can probably cheese this game because of that, but the game is so fun that I've never been compelled to do that.

Lastly...the dude has faithfully updated the game regularly with free content and bug fixes for years consistently. Support the game!
What Cyberpunk 2077 should've been.

Started from nothing at the bottom of the slums. Worked my way up past stuck-up goons, psycho cannibals, and the high and mighty upper crusters, I a humble soldier, got to the mayor village. It spent a minor lifetime, all in one go from the very bottom, having come close to death at least half a dozen times (including 1 HP one time), but all thwarted by preparation and excellent defensive items. Even once I died, before I remembered I had resurrection. My heart was pounding. I had to focus. One slip up, it's all over. I had acquired a cyanide pill some ways back. And I wasn't going to waste it on just anybody. I was patient. And I waited. And then I saw the mayor and his huge posse.  I failed this task last time. Not so now. I shoved the cyanide pill into the vent, and watch as the fearful and incompetent authoritarian turned into pink sludge. I casually walked inside, and adorned the hat. That's how I became mayor. But now it's your turn. How do you plan on doing it?

This game has everything you could every possibly want in one and more. If you are even remotely interested in this game, buy it for your own sake. I haven't come across anything like it, and for one of the most complex, interesting emergent games ever, it's even more impressive that it was for the most part developed by one guy. So yeah, unless you're a gaming philistine and need the shiniest, prettiest graphics or else you'll die, go in and have a blast. Each playthrough is vastly different. I just completed the game and I don't think I've even uncovered like half of what this game has to offer, and none of it is filler. It's all phenomenal, truly. Get it.

[h1]a Rogue Lite with a Mix of The Extreme chaos of [i]Grand Theft Auto[/i] meets the Career system of [i]Final Fantasy[/i][/h1]

[i]Streets of Rogue[/i] is an arcade style rouge lite game that can keep me interested for a good while. while I waited for the game to go on sale, I must admit that after playing for 12 hours this game was worth the 50% off value, as though it provided more than its share of moments to remember, after awhile its ability to keep my interest only stands out when I invite friends over to play co-op.

Pros:
- Enough unique characters/classes and variety to keep you hooked and try each one out at least twice to learn their abilities, secret objectives, and interactions with other NPCs, objects and items.
- Chaos; "[i]wanna start [spoiler]a zombie apocalypse?[/spoiler][/i]" "[i]wanna go [spoiler]full on ape?[/spoiler][/i]" "[i]wanna cause [spoiler]a robot rampage?[/spoiler][/i]" Streets of Rage lets you do this and so much more, I would add more to the list but half the fun is discovering what you can do and I was able to cause these three scenarios within the first 5 hours of gameplay and unlocks. 
- Multiplayer availability, with the addition of remote play (via Steam) there is no excuse why you shouldn't invite your friends to play along with you. you could play cooperatively and use strategy to complete missions, or you could play the "[i]Fun Way[/i]" and do your own thing while everyone else causes mischief due to miscommunication and pure insanity.

Cons:
- Although there's plenty of character unlocks, its equipment and item variety are not lacking but feel too similar sometimes, specifically the melee weapons as too many use slash and stab motions, personally (and perhaps they are later unlocks for all i know) I would like to see weapons like nunchucks, a whip or flail that provide an extended rage but at the cost of less damage than their closer ranger counter parts.
- Sometime you can be playing a blessed run and then be cursed by some unstoppable madness that is out of your control and just ends your run there and then. To be fair this game is one of many games that are [b]Chaos Incarnate[/b], but when you lose a run to something out of your control it can be a buzz killer and sometimes puts me off from playing another run for the day.

For my overall rating, I give Streets of Rogue a [h1][b]7/10[/b][/h1]

[b]tl;dr[/b]
Great and funny sandbox game with rpg elements. Various ways to achieve your goals on quests and many many ways to mess around (in a pretty weird way, if you prefer). Achievements: possible

[b]Story[/b]
While there is no real story and you mainly go for short missions, it still feels like you’re aiming to achieve a great goal.
Well, in the end you have the possibility to be elected Major after all.
Frankly, this game does not even need a real story. As someone who is no fan of too much sandbox, I really appreciate the numerous possibilities Streets of Rogue offers

[b]Gameplay[/b]
You can play Streets of Rogue with keyboard/mouse and also with a controller. In my opinion the controller configuration feels intuitive. I use a steam controller and most of the time I change something in the settings. This time everything felt good from the start. Maybe you want to switch some things to your likings, but all in all, this is designed very well.
When you’re playing solo, you get a bit of slow motion when browsing the inventory to make it easier to eg switch weapons. Of course, this does not happen in multiplayer.

LIke I have mentioned, there are plenty ways to do the missions. If you want have to free some prisoners, you can for example
[list][*]kill the policeman and unlock the cells
[*]hack the computer (if you have a hacking device or you’re a hacker) and unlock the cells
[*]steal the key and unlock the cells[/list]
This is just one example about possibilities. There are many more ways to achieveme many different goals.

One of my favorite happenings was when someone caught me in the act, chased me and tried to shoot me, they sometimes accidentally hit another npc. That way npcs start to fight. If the npc belongs to a gang or maybe to the police, a real mess is coming up. I happened to cause a war between around 15 npcs from time to time. Afterwards all were dead and I just collected the loot they dropped. Win.

By doing mission you earn chicken nuggets (the ingame currency) which you can use to unlock further features like mutators. Mutators change the game’s settings and make it partially easier or harder.
You can also create your own class. Just be careful: If you custom class is overpowered, achievements will become disabled as long as you play that class.

The sole downside for me so far is that it is sometimes a bit annoying to connect to friends. When inside the same home network, it was sometimes necessary to directly connect to the ip.

[b]Looks[/b]
As you might have already seen from the pictures, the graphic is rather old school. I really like nice and beautyful graphics, the current graphics fit the game perfectly.

[b]Achievements[/b]
It is totally possible to unlock all the achievements and in contrast to some other games, it is also a lot of un.

[b]Pros[/b]
[list][*]lots of possibilities to achieve your goals
[*]nice humour
[*]convenient controls
[*]you can unlock mutators to make the game harder or easier
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[list][*]sometimes it took some time to connect to friends, which is annoying
[/list]

[b]Conclusion[/b]
Streets of Rogue is a sandbox rpg-like game that offers you numerous ways to achieve your goals. By playing, you will unlock various classes, each with their own strenghts and weaknesses and also with their own personal goals.
While it is already fun to play solo, playing with friends is even greater because you can spread literally swarm out and cause chaos.
The controls are made very well and fell good to play.

I can only recommend this game. It is just great.

This game is a lot of fun to play with other people, which is primarily what I do. But it's also nice to play when I just want to veg out and not concentrate for a little awhile. It's really fun.

The game has a lot more mechanics than I originally thought it would, as well as an immense variety of ways to mod the game/characters. The characters themselves are fine, but you're also allowed to custom create your own characters using any abilities/passives/items you want. There's no real difference between solo or multiplayer so you can enjoy the game with friends as well. I'd give it a 9/10. A lot of the replay value is entirely based on how creative you are, despite the fact that each map seems more or less randomly generated. I still wish there were more options than there currently are, even after buying the DLC. Despite that, as far as I recall, it's the best sandbox rpg I've played. I recommend it, though you will notice a somewhat large difference in customization options based on whether or not you bought the character DLC.

This is my favourite game and I'm going to explain why, though there is not many hours shown I have played it on my switch along time before. The game is genius, at first your experimenting with the huge variety of characters, exploring the sub-systems and messing around, gradually you start getting better and rather than trying to do all the cool (but silly stuff) and start attempting to beat the game, even then then the game is brilliant as you work your way through the floors, seeing all the new challenges, from the ponds and cannibals of forest to the highly policed streets of uptown, every level makes the game better (except for stage 2, industrial which seems only to exist to trap and set me on fire :-). 

The game has quite a high level of difficulty (well I am not particularly good at games so probably easier for most) because if you make mistakes, use up your healing or fumble a shot things can quickly escalate, this encourages patience. Fortunately the range of characters helps with frustration by giving you different ways to tackle things, some of my personal favourites being the soldier, who's wide range of explosives help him get into buildings/around obstacles and firepower helps him get out, the werewolf, the only character who I've beaten the game with and a character who's playstytle changes from sneaking around carefully avoiding violence, to massacring 5 supercops in a blood-bathing werewolf attack.

The next great thing is the level of customisation. You can change pretty much anything! The settings of course offer a lot of customisation, where you can turn anything from blood and gore to screen shake off, but this is all pretty standard, in the mutators, character creation and level designer is where this game really takes off. Mutators allow you to change features of the gameplay to your liking, want the whole game to be a zombie apocalypse, you can, want to not have melee weapons breaking, you can do that as well. This allows a level of tailored fun that I wish other developers would commit to because games are meant to be fun and this allows a large amount of people to enjoy this game, and optimise the right amount of difficulty and chaos to your liking.

To be honest some may not use character creator but to me it is one of my favourite parts of the streets of rogue experience. It allows you to create pretty much any crossover you want, do you like 80s action movies, why not include rambo and diehard. Creating pretty much any character you want is already a tempting promise but combined with the level editor, there is practically endless replayability.

Now I have enjoyed playing streets of rogue immensely and really want to say thank you to matt (the dev) for making such a polished and brilliant game. I hope if anyone reading this review is convinced this game is worth buying, because it is. This is my first review and I wholeheartedly recommend this game, the most underated gem I've played in a long time.

I paid $16 for Streets of Rogue, I can safely say after 100 hours in it was money well-spent. I've been burned more times than I care to admit by pixel-genre rogue-likes, but this game is one of the good ones. It also happens to be a fair amount of fun, and has replayability.

There are something like a couple dozen characters you can play, and while the general gist is similar, some of them play completely different. I've now done over a hundred runs and am improving my success rate, but you don't even have to do the whole run in one sitting. You don't even have to do the whole run in one run either, if that even makes sense. As you beat the starter areas enough times, you can actually choose to skip them. While I've never done this, I like the way it's implemented, and I can see where it could be handy.

The writing is super-cheese, but it actually works. I'll be the first to admit that the tutorial, which many found funny, did not immediately impress me. I'm really glad that I kept playing because this is one of those hidden gems like Slay the Spire, Rimworld, or Terraria.

Not that it plays anything like any of those games! What they have in common is that they're all made by indie devs that just focussed on making good and [i]complete[/i] products. Yes, the game has a DLC character pack, but it is not required, was not immediately available from content trimmed at launch just to sell a DLC, and did not come at the expense of the community. The guy is still making fixes to the base game.

You know what, I'm gonna go buy that skin pack right now.

Excellent silly pixel-art action game with plenty of genuine replayability.  Challenging enough that I'm still playing it, but not impossibly hard.  The world comes with a collection of comedic and absurd rules which are internally consistent enough that they fit together and make for intuitive gameplay.  I'm still trying to win with all of the classes.  :)

Streets of rouge is a rougelike where you pick a character from a pretty wide selection (considering that this is an indie game) of classes and progress through a randomly generated set of levels, completing random tasks like stealing an object from a safe or blowing up a generator, with the final goal being to overthrow the mayor. This game is extremely fun and has great replay value, especially because you can play it pretty much however you want, that is to say that every objective can be completed in any way you like, from sneaking in to a building to just blowing everything up. The art is pixel-y, which might not be everyone's cup of tea, but I personally don't mind it. The game is also just funny, for example, most items have descriptions which are often just jokes and the 'hints' in loading screens are great (one of them is 'Eat healthy food. Not in the game, in real like. It has no effect in the game'). I think something that sums this game up perfectly is that one of the options to get rid of the mayor is to sneak into a building, steal a recording of the mayor saying something mean, and playing it in public, causing the citizens to get rid of him for you. So yeah, I recommend this game.

TLDR: if you don't mind pixel art, and want a very open ended rouglike with a lot of humour, this game is for you.

This game is so much fun to play. The premise of the game is to remove a corrupt mayor from a city (as you have joined the "resistance". You do this by accomplishing various objectives on 5 seperate stages each with three substages (or less if mutators (modifiers) are involved). You can pick from a multitude of premade classes (or make your own custom classes) to play through randomly generated maps. The maps are an amalgamation of smaller chunks, each chunk assigned to a particular building layout, or area. Workshop support means that the number of possible combinations is increased.

Basically, this is the best game I think I have played ever.

I am a big fan of roguelikes and this one really provides every option that a roguelike should.  Most roguelikes will only really give you customization of what your character has and items.  This gives more.  Every character is unique and most characters have their own special abilities that can allow them to come out alive from certain scenarios that others can not.

This game is also very chaotic.  One minute you could be fighting the entire police force with banana peels and the next you could be trying to buy cyanide pills to serve in a cocktail.  This game creates crazy scenarios almost every level and it will always be up to you how it is resolved.  It makes for incredibly intense levels that feel very fun to play and progress through.

So, I recommend the game.  Will most people play as long as I have? (114.3 hours as the time I'm writing this)  Probably not.  Most people seem to quit around the 10 hour mark, but I promise it will be worth your time and money always.

Fun an chaotic game. You basically go through a city with different characters (every level is a part of the city). There are thieves that steal things, gangs that fight each other, ghosts, police, firemen... You can be different classes that are good at different things and has different abilities (like a gang member or a zombie that infects more people). Then you try and go through the game and it's basically a chaotic sandbox where people fly through walls, get shot by rocket launchers or get turned into giants who walk through walls. It's really fun, especially in coop.

Even in alpha the game is absolutely feature rich and more or less pretty bug free!
Lots of games promise you the ability to approach any situation in creative ways, but the creativity in this game is really something else. From playing ding-dong-ditch with explosives to causing someone's refrigerator to literally run through a wall to create an opening, even the same tired missions can be fun again and again for hours.
it fun ;p

This game is basically everything I wanted in a game - the wide variety of choices from character to gameplay approach, the perfect pacing from chill exploration to frantic combat, and the best part is the sheer amount of shenanigans possible, especially in chaotic multiplayer.  

Pixel graphics are clear and expressive, with plenty of character in the sound effect and animations.  The gameplay can be difficult even on veteran runs, always providing a solid challenge with nuance in each character.  

I couldn't rave about this game enough, so I had to get my friends to play and even bought copies for them.

Playing alone I've been able to enjoy myself for 40+ hours in this game. There's a massive amount of characters which I have only beaten 2.

Although I think where this truly shines is when you're playing with friends. The chaos is multiplied, and it all works out most of the time.

I must mention that even though there are tons of playable characters, I did start to get burnt out. It might be because I'll binge games in just a few days. But in any case, your goal is almost always the same, characters simply change how you go about achieving those goals. As always, it has integrated steam workshop which helps with adding variety through community content.

Overall, it was a very fun and entertaining experience.

Indy game dedicated to gameplay.

Ode to old school types from the 90's, where artists and developers created a lot from very little.

If you like indy games, old school 'gameplay first' games, you might like it.

Top down 2D rogue-like, twin directional type of combat(movement/aim separate). Melee is more nuanced than gunplay, as you can block/parry melee with melee, but traits allow for all kinds of wrinkles(things you add to your character rpg style in your current run). The variety of classes and custom classes will alter your approach. Some will be very rogue-like, others are more smashy smashy, or a mix of both - or something else entirely, such as the Comedian whom will acquire followers so you can tell people to do what you need instead of doing it yourself.

A lot more fun with friends or randoms! Team orientated. Lots of replay and content for 20 dollars and I haven't personally touched or tried any mods yet, which potentially can add tons more including endless levels, from what I hear. But vanilla will keep you busy for a while.

If it's ever on sale for less than 20$, huge value!

I was initially skeptical of this game. [i]How could a game seem to scratch every itch some of these players have?[/i] I thought. Well, then I played it. Then I played it some more. 

Streets of Rogue really is unlike anything else I've played. It's such an amalgamation of different mechanics that shouldn't work when smashed together but absolutely do. It's the definition of easy to learn but difficult to master. I can't stop playing death after death. Every new life feeling like I've learned something new. Some people have put hundreds of hours into it and I can see why. I definitely recommend this game. At this price it's pretty much a steal. I've spent 3x the price on games I couldn't stomach for ten minutes.

Simply, its a fantastic game.  Do you have friends? Great! Play it with them. You easily get double the fun from an already fun game. SoR has a decently in depth character designer where you can pick starting items, the look of your character, and traits your character starts with. The game IS a roguelike, so dont expect to win your first run, third, or even fifteenth, the fun is in playing, in dying, in losing, not beating and winning the game.

Graphics are person to person, same with music and gameplay, i cannot judge that for other people, there are numerous streams out in the world, if you think youre interested, watch a handful of them :)
Nothing to write home about, but fun nevertheless.

With the deus ex franchise on hiatus this is the closest thing to a deus ex game that you can find. As it is a roguelite, the "cities" (called floors in this game) are very minimalist and randomly generated for each try. There is also currency used for permanent upgrades as you go along, hence why this is a roguelite, not a roguelike. Honestly, I recommend it. Unlike the more recent deux ex games that push you into taking a stealth approach, this game at least has separate characters that each have loadouts and traits pushing you in a given direction depending on the character you picked. While this does allow you to play the way you wish depending on the character you picked, it does mean that you won't be able to change your gameplay style in the middle of a run. Your character defines you from start to finish.

The game is a bit lacking in hooks to keep you playing beyond unlocking new characters but its still decent enough in this regards. Overall, I recommend this if you're looking for a new deus ex game or you're looking for a roguelike and you're bored of issac, hades, enter the gungeon, syntetik, dead cells, and noita.

I encourage you to learn the basic game mechanics before jumping in as they can be immensely helpful, and this game has a lot of mechanics you'll be learning run after run.

An over the top action adventure game where you play as a member of the Resistance of a dystopian city to try and claim the mayordom for yourself. There's a lot of different solutions to problems, a wide variety of classes that play very different and have their own victory conditions, and a bunch of different random events and mutators to mix things up. It's ridiculously and extremely replayable.
This game quickly becomes repetetive. It is fun for a few hours, but the levels seem same-y and the AI is not smart as advertised, making the game feel empty.

Absolutely not worth the pricetag. The game promises such a different game every run but it's the same cycle.
Walk in
Neutralize target/Flip switch/Free NPC
If you feel like it, do character quest (so like open a chest or kill someone)
Leave
Repeat
The game's progression feels useless, you lose melee weapons super quick due to durability and the only ammo must be bought.
The melee combat is horrendous, you walk around and swing wildly and hope you hit someone.
Allies are useless and just get themselves killed, stealth is impossible with them.
The stealth is horrible, you just gotta run when the goons aren't looking at you.
There are so few enemies and so little variation the game gets dry, quick.

After playing more:
My refund got denied and I wanted to add on more of my experience:
If you wanna win easily on the last floor, you need as many people to like you as possible (electability)
Problem is, there isn't a visual indication when they are annoyed (and will bring it down), you have to hover over them to see it.
Then you have to kill all annoyed people.

You either have tons of money, or are poor. Debt is very misleading (If you kill the lender, your still in debt), and there's no reason to take it.
The rooms feel the same, and a large amount of buildings aren't randomly generated (jail, basic goon hideouts, apartments, etc...). 
The character you choose pretty much forces your play style. No swapping allowed unless your willing to spend 300+ money.
There's little difference between killing someone, knocking them out, or sneaking past them.
Death can happen anytime with 2+ enemies, no matter how much you gear up (all armor is temporary).
Guns do so little damage (Shotgun is 12 dmg on a close range hit).
There are so few weapons (Guns: Shotgun, pistol, flamethrower, Melee: Baton, Baseball bat, Axe, Sword, Knife, and a few others).
Inventory management is a pain, and every mission gives more non-stackable junk to add onto it.
It feels like there is no reason to do missions, or stay around the floor risking it for vaults/chests.

My suggestion: The developer(s) could probably learn a lot looking at other similar games and taking elements. For example, look at SS13. Make a lot more systems more in depth (such as syringes! They're so simple! Add some depth for dedicated chemists!). Make weapons/abilities combo with each other like Gungeon, so players have to plan out what weapons to choose. Weapons are also 99% useless anyways, there is no reason to run n gun because regaining health is so hard and dodging is so finicky. Make classes less restrictive, they're classes not entire play-styles, and I hate playing a bunch of the classes due to the needless restrictions (though some add fun challenges, that's different).
There also needs to be a lot more variety, the city doesn't feel like a city at all because half the NPCs don't move or wonder on a certain path. Non-cops should roam around, interact with each other, talk, etc...
Quests need a huge overhaul. The entire game is based around quests! Maybe make them multi-stage, add more different options on how to complete quest (steal item from civilian by killing/knocking them out vs steal item, charisma check the civilian, draw them out of their house and sneak in (not doable for small houses)). I'd love to see SS13 (again, I know, but it's a similar game)-kinda interaction with more systems and some sort of building/disguise system.
Later levels having some sort of sewer system would be nice too, it feels impossible to escape cops and the gutters aren't usable by players (unless a certain class can, but then I bet it's just like the trees/bushes).
Minions could be expanded also, maybe some sort of relations system ("You sent my friend to their death/are walking into a death trap, I'm gonna leave unless we're real good friends" kinda thing). Animal minions would be cool also, and maybe better control over them if you want to use them as a distraction.

Those are just a few ideas I have that I feel would expand the game in a significant way, trying to break the "fun once, bland later" problem with most of the game's gimmicks because they never go into much depth other than stealth (which is mostly negated because the doctor is completely broken).

TL;DR Gameplay is stale and based off of your starting character, weapons don't vary enough, the random generation doesn't change anything, big quests are lame, doctor is omega boring and never gets stronger, guns are weak.
It does kill time though.

This is one of my all time favorite games. Everything you see in the trailer is true and there's so much more.

Behind the scenes it's a procedurally generated twinstick rpg, but the setting and diversity of classes make it a billion times more immersive than any other game of it's kind. Every character in the game has their own way of thinking, life goals, likes, dislikes and alignments. Player involvement with them can change their life completely, usually by destroying their property and killing them, but such is life.

Unlike your standard rockstar/ubisoft open worlds full of civilians, this world is inhabited by 20-30 different classes of workers traders, entertainers, medics, law enforcement, criminals etc. You soon learn to recognize each type and deal with them accordingly, depending if they are at home, at work, just walking around or running from violence. Not to mention that SoR hacker is a billion times cooler and more fun to play than a Watch Dogs hacker.

The diversity and placement of characters is quite unique, nobody is truly "a monster that just destroys everyone else" with a possible exception of zombies (which are actually pretty nice if you're a zombie). And every class can be pacified in some way. You hate cannibals always trying to kill you from the bushes? You can mind control them, zombify them, sometimes charm them or just play as a cannibal. Police bothering you just because you constantly break the law? Bribe them, befriend them, play as the police, there are so many options, it's insane.

Oh and it can be played in co-op which increases the number of options and potential chaos by a trillion percent. Anyway, buy it and play it. If you saw the trailer, you probably already know if you're going to like it.

A very fun blend of Hotline Miami's melee combat, Nuclear Throne's ranged combat, Deus Ex's stealth/hacking and GTA's criminal crazyness, with plenty of randomness. Despite borrowing the best out of those games, Streets of Rogue is still a unique game.

It offers multiple ways of completing objectives, many customization options, many things to unlock which greatly improve the game's replay value. Decision making is crucial for your survival. Much like a puzzle game, you will have to calculate your chances of survival before acting. For beginners, it's a bit hard and you will die often, but it's never a frustrating experience because you keep learning by your mistakes and usually always gain enough "nuggets" to unlock new stuff that'll be useful next time. Most of the time, your death will be hilarious and will make you laugh, you'll call yourself stupid for doing whatever got you killed and you will move on to start yet another game. As your gaming experience starts building up, you manage to reach higher levels which of course get harder and harder. Even when you finish the game ( which you will find is quite short when you do finish it ) for the first time, you will always want to start over and over again. The randomness is key to this game's success because nothing is ever the same in Streets of Rogue.

With great music, a simple yet effective game design, great action/reaction AI, hilarious content, multiple unlockables, character/level creation and challenging gameplay, you have many, many hours of fun ahead of you. This game is a must buy for all those who enjoyed the games I've named earlier.

A unique and amazing game.

The concept of a roguelike set in a city works surprisingly well, and the game executes it almost perfectly. It has a lot of content, even without the community made stuff. It isn't perfect, though. The game is pretty unbalanced when it comes to different characters, and there are a few exploits that can make certain situations trivial. That being said, a lot of the challenge comes completing the game with many characters (which all change up the gameplay significantly), and the largest exploits have been fixed. The only ones that remain are small, and take a long time to find. lastly, the game is very accessible. There are many ways the game lets you alter its difficulty, including mutators, custom characters, and skipping areas of the city.

Overall, I highly recommend Streets of Rogue. The only reason you might not want to buy the game is if you're a fan of harder, tighter roguelikes. Even then, if you're intrigued by the idea of the Streets of Rogue, give it a try. I had a lot of fun with the game, and I still come back every once in a while.

I'm going to keep it short because if I made a long review it would be at least 10 pages. This is an alarmingly good game with immense replay value. The few flaws it does have (mainly surrounding created characters) are nothing in comparison to the sheer chaos and entertainment of the game itself. Nearly every playstyle is viable so long as you're willing to be creative. Character archetypes range from murderhobo to pacifist to team builder with plenty in between and off to the sides. DLC characters add to the game meaningfully, though some are better than others. It's important to note that each character is unique and some are far harder to play than others, so if you have trouble try another character.
My one real criticism is that it doesn't have a proper modding API for code. As much as it does have plenty of custom content (new level pieces, characters, campaigns) I'm the kind of guy who loves adding new features to games and tweaking existing ones. I know it's a Unity game so implementing such a thing is pretty difficult without just giving out the code but if this game could take code mods it would be basically perfect in my eyes.

All I'm gonna say is, I have hundreds of games but this is one of the cleverest, funniest ones I have, hands down, and it keeps getting fixes, new characters and updates - so, here I am again downloading it once more for a bunch more playthroughs. No DLCs or any money ripping nonsense, super fun, super playable, just buy it already, you'll be glad you did.

Very good and fast-paced roguelite. 

You pick a class, spawn into town and get told to do a few things. Kill this guy, steal this thing, rescue this loser. Its a very basic premise with a lot of fun to be had thanks to the large variation in class ability and items.

Classes range from your basic 'hit stuff good' classes; an ape that can do double melee damage, a jock who can destroys walls, etc, to the weaker utility classes; a hacker who can make fridges run through walls for him or doctor who 1 shots unaware enemies but doesn't use weapons. 

So say your goal is: kill this guy
The ape could just walk in, hit him, done. But everyone around has guns. You don't have the hp to tank all those shots, so you look around. You see a vent. You put a random syringe in the vent. Poison. They all walk outside, slowly lose hp to poison. All gathered together. So you hit them all at once. And they all die. Problem solved.

The doctor, instead, just knocks on the door. A guy answers, gets annoyed, turns away. 1 shot. Repeat. Easy.

But say things go wrong for the doctor. Its a struggle for him to deal with this. He's absolute ass in a frontal fight. So you eat some 'sugar' (cocaine) and run the hell away. Problem solved. But that area is dangerous now; they all want to fight you. So you never go back.

The way the classes interact with the world and the npcs in it is where the fun is. There really is a lot of variety here. 

However, this can get pretty annoying some times. Every 3 levels you get  a 'special' zone. With restrictions like 'all cops aggro on you for being outside and all doors are locked' or 'the floor is slowly moving lava'. These events tend to just screw the weaker combat classes. You get forced to move fast as classes who are designed to take things slow or fight as classes that struggle to fight. Its annoying.

Where the game falls to pieces is balance. All the above is assuming you are playing classes to their strengths and weaknesses. But what you can do, with few exceptions, is just use guns. 
Melee weapons have default 100 max durability, break nearly instantly and need to be replaced entirely when this happens. Despite this they do mediocre damage. And, of course, are only useable upclose.
Guns use ammo. They run out, you keep the gun. They have ammo dispensers built into maps; melee has nothing like this. They do very high damage. And stunlock. And are safe. Even if you have 1 gun skill (the lowest) you are still often better off shooting than melee. The balance is that bad. And ammo is so cheap, its trival to never run out. 
In general, the game is too generous with money; its also trivial to carry around more instant healing than you will ever be in danger of losing.
Most importantly, there are 'clone' machines. For a price, they 'clone' an item. You get +1. And there's an item called the 'giant' pill. It makes you giant  with house sized melee range, only take 1 damage per hit most of the time, walk through walls and nearly instakill. Its incredibly trivial to just spend your cash cloning these, ignore your class and walk over the game. Removing all challenge. The item is absolutely broken. Its borderline god mode. 

Now let's talk progression. In run and out.
In run progression is... lackluster. You gain exp for doing jobs/killing/picking locks/etc. Get a maxed bar, you gain 1 level and fully heal. Then at the end of the stage you get to pick 1 ability. And most of them are not worth caring about. They are incredibly underwhelming. So underwhelming that, despite the hours I have in this game, I struggle to remember the majority of them. 
A big problem is they are very specific. 
Like: You can recruit 5 people. But I'm not recruiting anyone. Because allies are stupid. Any class that IS built around recruiting will usually already have this. So offering it to me is just pointless. Same for any other follower based trait. 
Or + unarmed damage, reduce how much melee slows your movement. I'm a character with 4 in guns. Why would I want this? 

Every 3 level ups you get a 'special' levelup. If you have no right click ability, you get +1 to a random stat offered. I dislike this. It homogenises classes. I don't pick the ape to shoot things. 
If you don't have  a right click, you get an upgrade to it. I like this. It furthers the uniqueness of the classes... shame it rarely pops up as an option. And there's no mutator to guarantee it or remove the + stats.

So the further in the run you go, the more the classes feel the same. Which is boring. 
You can also spend cash to upgrade traits you like, but most can't be upgraded. Or remove those you don't, to also make classes feel more samey. But at least this doesn't take 1/3 level up options. 

Outside of the run you spend nuggets to unlock mutators, new items and the like. Its very basic. Play long enough, you get everything. Not much to say here. Its liken the absolute minimum level of metaprogression needed to call this a roguelite.

The final progress is 'super classes'. Every class has special goals to do per floor area (areas are made of 3 floors). Kill x people, kill < x people, hack this thing, etc. Do this without fail every time and finish the game and you get a super class.
Mostly these are just the regular class with all their right click upgrades. Feels very lazy.

The final thing to cover is stages. They all follow the same basic structure; a box with buildings in it. But have their own gimmick. 
First area is easy, second has cannibals aggro on you for no reason, third fills every building with 20 million traps, fourth has mobs aggro on you for no reason and fifth fills every building with 20 million traps and also has robots aggro on you. And the 6th is just punching 1 guy in the face.
I dislike the areas where people just pop up and pick a fight with you. Its just annoying. There's really not much to them beyond that. They're basic but functional

Every f**kin games in this decade are tagged with "roguelike/roguelite" zzz
So, u're bored with steam's flagships like FTL, Hades, Enter the Gungeon, Don't Starve, Darkest dungeon, Slay the Spire, Dead Cells etc... and feel like they're all good but something is still missing.. give Street of rogue (SoR) a try.
At least, this little shit makes me LAUGH in stead of RAGE-QUIT.
 
Im a skeptical and thoughtful buyer. Just played 1h of this game when writing this review, but I did researched almost all reviews on the net/reddit/youtube, watch 5hs+ gameplay on YT. These are my habits when I buy any game, so I dont have to regret it later.

Some insights for anyone considering to purchase this little gem:
- Acceptable Pixelated graphics. I dont bite pixel art style, and this is my biggest concern on buying SoR. It turns out OK, because I'm immersed enough into the gameplay and forget about the art style. 
- Fully supported controller: Im getting old and lazy now,  so I only play on couch with a controller. SoR did it job perfectly.
- Gameplay: If u re looking for a topdown bullet hell like Enter the Gungeon, this won't suit you. Instead, think about GTA. SoR is Immersive sim + Roguelite + somewhat topdown shooting (If you CHOOSE so). Yes, the devs advertised correctly about SoR's strongest selling point: you're free to choose how to solve the missions, not just brute forcing.
- Replay value: Too soon to tell, but If u want to complete the game with all those characters, it could be 100 hours+ easily. Each character is unique and you'll find yourself play a whole new game with each char.
- Repetitive: Yes, the world and mission pool are kinda repetitive. But I don't really care. Like I said above, Immersion is real lol
- Deaths: You'll die alot. However, games like Darkest Dungeon/Hades/Dead Cells make me rage-quit (this was the reason why i bought SoR, to cool down my anger lol). SoR doesn't bring the crap out of me and make me LAUGH 50% whenever I die. This is, IMO, the biggest selling point of this shit.
Very addctive and challenging game. Built on creative problem solving inspired by Deus Ex, learning the techniques of the broad range of classes, and easy but cool retro graphics.

This game is just dumb fun, and I love it.

There's basically no story here, the world is amusingly confusing and incoherent, music is there but forgettable, and the pixel graphics are good but nothing amazing.

But holy cow this game is so much fun. The core of the game is pretty straightforward. You enter a world area, have objectives (like go here and kill this guy, or retrieve this item), and once you're finished you go the next level. Once you've played all the levels, you win. But what makes the game just so much chaotic fun is the different character classes. You have just LOADS of options, and they each will go about the objectives very differently. You can play a ninja and stealth everywhere, or a doctor who just knocks out everyone with chloroform for a more passive play style, or a gorilla who just melees his way to victory, or a zombie who just infects everyone and then just kinda does the objectives as an afterthought once the apocalypse is taken care of. The amount of depth in the game mechanics with these classes is surprisingly deep, and it feels like a totally different game in many ways depending on the character you're playing. With the ability to make custom classes there's just endless fun here. 

If you want something a bit more casual to play with endless sandbox potential and lots of dumb fun this game is absolutely amazing. If you're looking for a serious game, you're looking in the wrong place.
great game. tons of different ways to play it.

If you love chaos and gorillas you should definitely buy this game.

I have played many rounds of Streets of Rogue. Sometimes we die immediately and sometimes we go all the way. There's no way to tell what will happen because the RNG of each level can really get ya. I personally never found that to be frustrating though, because the game tells you who it is in the first moments, and every death is hilarious. 

The characters and unique strengths are also a blast. My favorite to play personally is the vampire. You spend half your time attempting your objectives and the other half attempting to corner victims away from crowds so you can discreetly suck their blood. Another favorite is the gorilla. You are super strong and tough but don't speak a bit of English. Also you spend a lot of time avoiding those pesky scientists that want to lock you up!

I wish I could name all the horrific deaths I experienced off the top of my head. I have blown up, been shot, been eaten, been smashed, been set on fire among other things. 

I prefer to play with friends because the assistance getting through levels is helpful and it's also a great time. You go through a lot of trial and error picking characters that compliment each other well enough to get through most of the game and even then the RNG will still get ya. 

I have played about 25 hours at this point and "beaten" the game 3 times. I don't see this as something that will get boring, maybe just taking breaks here and there. I even considered buying it on Switch to introduce my non-PC friends to it.

Streets of Rogue is a hilarious bundle of fun where you seek out to depose the corrupt mayor...while the resistance has you do odd jobs along the way. Despite the grisly world full of trigger-happy cops, opportunistic criminals and cannibals (oh my!), the atmosphere of the game is very laid back and rife with humour and eccentric personalities. 

The open nature of the game means most objectives often have multiple means of completing them, whether it's brutish direct combat, sneaking about or somehow even using the power of "friendship". The different classes are extremely varied, putting focus on one primary attribute or ability that can totally change the way you play the game. Meanwhile, there are mutators you can freely toggle that tweak the gameplay to be more hectic or simpler as you see fit. All this and multiplayer on top? It's very much worth it.

[h1]To make a long review short... [/h1]

This game has changed the way i see life in a great way, simultaneously ruining how i see open world games forever. Dude, i'm serious. Fallout New Vegas has been my all-time favorite video game since i was 12 and Streets of Rogue has blown it out of the water on the first day, in terms of replayability. [b]Honestly it's probably best to go in blind like i did, but if you want to know what you're paying for, read this review...[/b]

[h1]WARNING: THIS IS A "10/10" EXTREMELY POSITIVE REVIEW[/h1]

This review is entirely based on facts about the game, and how I feel about those facts. I haven't noticed many flaws at all, so if you're looking for things you might dislike about the game, i'm not sure this is the review for you.

[h1]-REVIEW START- [/h1]

First I'll just say that this is my first ever steam review after having an account for over 8 years. Why? Because this game is so good that i couldn't stop annoying my friends about every unique story i have in a playthrough, so here seems like the perfect place to vent. The beautiful thing about it's permadeath element is that the game is so open-ended, dying doesn't even feel like a penalty. 

This is a game where nobody is your friend. Unless you can get them to be. It's also a game where you have no enemies. Unless you want them to be. This game is not an RPG, it's an RPG simulator where really the only constant scenario is the city life, and even the city's environment changes plenty -- not to mention the extreme structural change of the maps every playthrough. 

So when i die, it totally does feel like a penalty, because my specific plan for a specific situation turns out to be an unredeemable failure. But EVERY TIME, that feeling of loss is fogged by the fun experience of discovering new possibilities in how your adventure could push forward, and then you're given a completely new campaign to the point of feeling rewarded! Also, you get some pretty tasty chicken nuggets at the end of every playthrough if you level up or do optional missions.

This game is a perfect example of the dream game I've wanted for a very long time, where you can be the widest variety of characters. Every playthrough is a unique story based on who you play as. It's truly mind-blowing especially considering there's well over 20 characters. Even if you play the same character twice, the events, locations, and characters involved in your journey are completely different every time! Take advantage of the game's super malleable system of custom NPCs/Buildings and you'll see what fun truly is.

It took me about 3 hours before i finally decided to make my first character and it was only then that i realized EXACTLY WHY this game seems to literally mimic real life: everything is 100% circumstantial, and nobody is the main character. If anything, you're the main factor of only your character's life.The world of this game is the most alive and real city setting I've ever played. Everyone in the game does their own goal to the point that sometimes I succeed my own quests by essentially doing nothing at all. Some dude i was supposed to assassinate got himself killed because i convinced him to fight for me by telling him a joke. Then he murdered me because his death involved being infected by a zombie. Why? Because this game constantly begs the question, "Why not?" while unapologetically toying with the idea that anything is possible. 

The best part in my honest opinion is that this game has local multiplayer, which essentially just drops your friends into the city with you. [i] But the four of you don't even have to interact the entire time. [/i] Weird selling point for local multiplayer, i know. But this just means that working together is another shackle removed entirely from the gameplay. Compete with eachother. Straight up fight or hunt eachother down, or play your own individual main quests just in the same city. If I had my friend over and he selected my Rick Sanchez character who has a hypno ray, freeze gun, and permanent police warrant among other traits and starting items, my Breaking Bad character Jessi would have a completely different drug dealing story. They both have crippling addictions in my copy of this game. 

What i absolutely love is that the change of character is usually far from the only reason that your playthrough is new when you play for the 100th time. Albeit simplistic story-wise, this game is what every open-world role-playing game wants to be. A game where you don't have to do anything, but you can do close to everything. Streets of Rogue is a legendary masterpiece. A beautiful, poetically functional simulation of a cartoony dystopian city life, and an intense benchmark in video game history. The only reason i ask for more updates is because this game should never die.

This game looked really interesting with its many classes and, on paper, many ways to go about clearing levels.
In reality you end up picking up the machine gun, and trivialize all content with it. There are no repercussions to going all murderhobo on everything that moves.
The 'story' is incredibly short, you can finish it in an hour or two. Levels are basically all the same, just with different tilesets and a few new enemies.
There are a lot of modifiers to unlock, but why would you bother if you can just beat the game easily with no unlocks?

I'm making this review because, at 43 hours, I finally beat it. I am not good at top down games, ha.

TLDR: Roguelike fun with a good sense of humor, Streets of Rogue is a fantastic pick up and play game that will have you saying, "just one more run" like any good roguelike should. TONS of characters to choose from, levels scaling in difficulty really well, and plenty of unlockables, you'll definitely get your money's worth from this game.

PROS:
-Plenty of content for a really low price
-Tons of valid playstyles
-Visually pleasing, if not simple
-Good humor
-Great music
-Plenty of destructable surfaces

CONS
-I can only think of one: multiplayer is kinda meh. It gets chaotic and locally you have to stick on one screen which is kind of a pain, but if you're used to these then the multiplayer isn't a con.

All in all, this game is WELL worth your time. I know I'm going to continue playing it for a long time coming. Great work, guys. Worthy of my favorites list.

Providing excellent gameplay and replay-value, I'd easily list Streets of Rogue as one of my favorite games. I tend to jump from game to game pretty frequently, and abandon games partway through, but Streets of Rogue keeps me coming back for more! Whether it's the fun challenge of the levels that get progressively more difficult, the multiple ways to complete quests, the heaps of unlockables (characters, perks, rewards, level mutators, and special abilities) there's always a reason to return and wander the levels. I also really love the old-school art style and the soundtrack is so great that I bought it and listen to it on its own at times! Over-all, this is an outstanding game, and I really do believe it should be a standard on every Steam-user's games list. It's just that good!

Game is smooth, replay value is very prominent, versatile gameplay styles for approaching the game with a large amount of strategy involved and progress is made even after failure with the ability to buy new traits and awards to appear in future runs. Game has all the staples of a good roguelite and does them very well. I'm very impressed by what Matt Dabrowski has created and having owned this game for 3 years and have sunk almost 300 hours into it I wonder why I haven't made a review for it yet.

My only super minor gripe is the multiplayer which I wasn't a huge fan of, but it's more unpolished but functional in my opinion. Other than that this is a banger indie game.

****End of Review; Shameless Plug Below****

For those interested I've had a long running let's play of this game composed of 50 episodes following the game from Early Access to the release of its DLC. The first 10 episodes were pretty blind and recorded on much older equipment, whereas the other 40 are more representative of the evolution of my skill level in the game and the evolution of myself as a Youtuber, featuring a semi-walkthroughs for every character's big quest and mini-showcases of custom runs and some of the different mechanics in the game. If you want to know more about this game check out the more recent videos in the series as they are more accurate to the game's current state.

This game is dumb as hell chaos in pretty much the best way possible. Like, you can absolutely play this as a methodical, tactical stealth game where you use your resources and wits to sneak around, accomplish your goals and disappear into the night -- and I love that that's a possibility, don't get me wrong. But you can also just kill literally everybody as a gorilla with a crew of gorilla brothers, charging around and destroying all the walls, policemen, scientists, and every facility in your wake, and it's a mess, and it's absolutely great. The variety of character types and strategies give this a lot more depth than you'd expect.

I really tried to enjoy this game but it's too annoying.  Why can't I save in the middle of missions, or for that matter, EVER?  For a game that starts its trailer with "This is a game about player choice", there really isn't much of it.  All it seems to save is the characters you unlock, but there's no real sense of progress.  When you die you lose practically everything.

And no, I'm not suggesting that you should be able to keep everything either, but the game doesn't even save your preferences for how you want your character to look for Pete's sake!  Even the traits you unlock don't stick with your character; it simply puts them in the pool of random traits you might have the chance to choose from when you "level up".

It's a shame I have to turn my back on this one because I love the gameplay in and of itself, and the visuals, and the concept.  But it's just too poorly implemented, IMHO.  Glad I bought this on sale.

One of your objectives is to neutralize someone inside a building, so you hire a thief to break into a safe located inside a bank. The safe has a hacking tool inside, so you use the hacking tool to disable the doors to cages inside a science lab, freeing the captive gorillas. This inadvertently causes a fight between five scientists and three angry gorillas. The police are provoked, gang members join in, suddenly there's a dozen dead bodies and a few wrecked buildings. Weren't you supposed to neutralize somebody? You buy a slave from one of the nearby slave owners and have them stand guard near the entrance. Buy some cigarettes from the drug dealer and stick it in the air filter. While everyone leaves, you set the slave's helmet to explode, killing the target and completing the mission. This is Streets of Rouge.

Streets Of Rogue is an incredibly short and bland platformer that never seems to do anything unique or interesting with it's gameplay or its story, what's supposed to be a race for former U.S. Presidential canidate Bernie Sanders towards the White House feels like a generic forgetful DSX reskin with worse level design. Each level is supposed to be a State, but nothing makes it feel like any of the states you visit are any different or even similar to their actual state (some themeing would have been nice, like the Arch in Missouri or the Statue of Liberty in New York), instead just feeling like another one of those "legally distinct" Mario clones. The platforming in this game ranges from mediocre platforming to just bad level design, especially with New York and the final level, D.C. (New York has several small platforms that you have to bounce on enemies heads on in order to try and fail repeatedly to cross in succession and the movement of Sanders is just slippery enough that you fall more times than you want too, and D.C has an particular section where the game expects you to skip a bottom platform and make a jump that you cannot seem to make normally.) None of the bosses in this game are spectacular, as they're just reskins of SMB1 Bowser fights, save for the final "boss" Donald Trump, who you just defeat in a cutscene and just finish the game in under an hour.

If you need a game to play that's free, just go and play Get Off My Lawn. If you need a good platformer, there's tons of great platformers out there on and off Steam. Skip Streets Of Rogue, and let time forget it existed.

Streets of Rogue. I love Streets of Rogue. If you've ever wanted a game with infinite replayability, challenge, and frankly ridiculous amounts of player choice - this is the game for you. At the £7 I got it for (thanks Steam Sales) it's a steal. It has a free demo on itch.io I recommend you try. If it has you itching for more like it did with me - buy this beautiful game.

I don't want to end up writing one of those steam reviews where the only thing they say is "Is good, recommended," but it is good. It's so damn good. This game is surprisingly fun. I thought it would be really boring. I bought it just because of the good reviews.

The timing of the music on the title screen, the humor in the tutorial and the wide variety of characters to play with drew me in. After trying the first level a couple of times, I started to grok it.

It took a while to figure out which strategy was best to get good progression, but once that was figured out, I was hooked.

There are many priceless moments and many ways to trick the poor NPC inhabitants of the streets of Rogue.

The music felt great at the start, but got repetitive over time, so I turned it off and only kept the sound effects.

It also took some effort to configure the wireless controller, and the game crashes if the gamepad loses connectitivty. But this is solved by never leaving the game for more than a couple of minutes, which is easier done than said.

All in all, a good 5/7.

Beats me up but I still end up coming back for more thanks to the solid core gameplay loop this game has. There's always something to unlock or discover, and even if you find it all you can still make your own crap to mess around with.

This game is also very skill-based, but it's easy for situations to quickly go from '1 to 100' real damn fast, thanks to the entire map being filled with NPCs that all have opinions of you and others, and getting in the way of their daily business while doing your missions can cause serious #### to go down. 

An example is knocking a thief that just jacked your item through a wall, into an explosive laser tripwire which ends up with the property owners chasing you guns blazing, except a stray police squad gets caught in the crossfire and you're left with either 4 bodies or severely wounded goons chasing you around the streets; all while some glorified hobos frisk the dead bodies for the tiny bits of money they may have. You just wanted your damn item back!

This entire situation can happen in like 4 seconds, and is just a small example of the crazy chain-reactions your (and other peoples) actions can cause. It really gives off the feeling that the game world is alive - and that it's chugging along with or without your input.

Along with the gameplay, the character selection is rather broad and allows you to go in guns/fists/swords/axes/grenades/flamethrowers blazing or just opt for a stealthier approach by knocking people out, hacking key terminals, using a plethora of sneaky thief tools and sabotaging air filtration systems with drugs. Or just being a sneaky #### and somehow slipping by everyone unnoticed. 

Most of your actions give EXP, so you'll never have to worry about your playstyle being 'not viable' when it comes to EXP gain; but you can still get screwed over if you try to play a frail nerd that hacks computers like an extremely aggressive 800-pound gorilla without the player skill to back it up.

Speaking of skill again, a-lot of the 'skill' in this game comes from just knowing what crap does & what to avoid. You can usually use your brain for most of it, but some of it is just 'fool me once' type crap (god damn cannibals popping out of manholes). The other portion of skill comes from playing to your characters' strengths and weaknesses, and efficient management of resources (health, ammunition, money or durability of weapons/armor, usually 3 or all four). There aren't that many things that can stop an observant, patient and clever player that plays around time constraints/current dangers while thinking ahead about how to best approach their next objective, which solidifies the fact that this game is heavily skill-based despite a big chunk of it revolving around RNG. The devs seem to have struck a fantastic balance in this department.

There is a plethora of built-in modifications for the game, you can make your own characters using the stats/items/skills/traits/objectives from other characters, use mutators to completely change the way the game plays or make your own modular pieces of a level and watch them appear in your runs. Or just download more characters/pieces from the ever-growing workshop.

Overall it ends up being an endless cycle of completing objectives as characters from all walks of life in a chaotic, ever-changing level that requires you to be on your toes at all times. The world may beat you down; but you will always have your chicken nuggets to help you stand back up and unlock more crap to play with.

Admittedly, I'm a huge slut for roguelites. This is pretty much everything I expect from a game like that, good replayability, secret paths and objectives, really fun gameplay.

Starting the game off as a beginner seems like a daunting task since you don't understand everything at the get-go, and the tutorial doesn't explain a whole lot, but in a way, I see that as a good way. Mostly because it doesn't hold your hand and allows you, as a player, to chart your own course and figure out your own path.

Speaking of gameplay, if I had a gripe, it would probably be with combat, since shooting and melee fighting feels just a bit clunky at times, especially if you engage another enemy in melee or hand-to-hand combat. However, I like the inclusion of hitting enemies into walls, only for them to break if your strength stat is high enough, never gets old. Though I have to mention that fighting people/zombies/robots isn't all that necessary and that you can get through the game without laying a finger on anybody, however it's very hard to do that.

Buy it on sale, it's definitely worth your money :)

An extremely fun multiplayer roguelike with plenty of variety, full of endless mayhem and chaos!

This game is hilarious, purely chaotic fun. A rogue-like mainly based on your own play style and choices rather than items. "building a run" comes in the form of traits that you get by levelling up, as all items are either ammo-based or consumable. Local and Online coop with up to 4 players that runs very smoothly, online coop members will find that they load into levels a little slower but other than that don't have any disadvantages compared to player 1. Tons of characters each with their own distinct play style. Missions are not very varied but there are countless ways to approach each quest. If you get bored of the base game, there are mutators to play around with that can change your run, anything from making certain floors not appear, to zombies appearing every floor, to rogue vision, which only allows you to see what your character could see. Custom characters are a feature with very little restrictions. Also workshop items such as new floor generation, other people's custom characters, and entire new campaigns are downloadable straight from steam. If you are looking for a game that's a little different, but still part of the rogue-like genre, then this is the game you are looking for. I can see myself playing for hundreds of hours without getting bored.

Streets of Rouge is a crazy, 2d game where you have to complete objectives by ANY means necessary. The game has crazy features such as: Random events that can happen on each floor, special perks to help or hinder you, cannibals and many more.

The game is very open to how you complete your objectives, need to steal a note from a guy, you could either:
-Bride him to hand it over
-Pickpocket him (If you have that skill)
-Silently assassinate him and take it
or
-TURN YOURSELF INTO A 50-FOOT TALL MONSTER AND KILL EVERYONE IN THE BUILDING!!

The game also lets you make your own characters with a variety of clothes, skills, weapons and abilities.

If you like strange games where you don't know what could happen next and like to improvise then I highly recommend this game.

In short Streets of Rogue is an extremely fun, long, game, in which you control the pace.

Streets of Rogue is a game I sunk dozens of hours into when it was a demo build on Itch.Io and only had two zones instead of the 5 or so it has now.

Now that it's a complete package it's an absolute riot of a top down roguelite. Manic energy and a dynamic, reactive world filled with chaos define this gem. Certain characters don't like each other, so use those conflicts to gain access to certain areas. You can buy items with status effects imprinted on them, and then inject them into air vents/pools of water to create instant death zones or a royal rumble where everybody is electrified. Your choice at game start of a number of different characters, from hackers to slum dwellers to gorillas, will inform your playstyle throughout the game.

It feels a lot like an immersive sim (your Deus Exes and so on) except transplanted onto a top down roguelite with dashes of the tool-based problem solving of a Heat SIgnature, but don't let that description fool you: This game is a unique gem and well worth full whack. And it even comes with up to 4(!) player coop!
