Matt Dabrowski and Craig Barnes are geniuses. Excellent gameplay and top tier soundtrack. This game is a more of a roguelite. While death does mean starting again from scratch, there is a currency that persists and unlocks different items for use in future runs. 

You play as one of many crazy themed classes like Cops, Hackers, Shapeshifters, Doctors, Vampires, etc making your way to the upper levels of society to remove the Mayor from power and don his Mayoral Hat. Each class has it's own major goal, limitations, and strengths that make you play different. Doctors can't use weapons, but they can sneak up behind people and chloroform them. Hackers can turn even the most harmless appliances into deadly explosives, or takeover the security system in a bank.

There's a puzzle element to each level (usually divided into 2 - 4 missions) where you case a building and have to decide on the best strategy with your own limitations in mind. You might be able to sneak in and out by never letting security cameras or people see you, or you can go in guns blazing kill anyone who tries to stop you, or you can plant a bomb on the door and give it a knock to see who trips it, or you can possess the body of the buildings owners to walk around with impunity...the possibilities are numerous and always fun to execute.

Get this game.

It's an interesting game and was mildly entertaining for a few hours. There are many characters to unlock and you can create custom characters as well. However, the gameplay is very, very repetitive. Each character brings a mildly different level of easier or harder to the game with the core mechanics staying the same. i.e, it's always a good idea to stay out of the sight of an enemy, but if you're a doctor you can take down enemies from behind if you sneak up on them... Or if you have a different trait, do a lot of damage from behind and also take down enemies instantly. There isn't a whole lot to choose from in terms of items either. I'd say the game is worth 10-15 USD at most but certainly not 20. It honestly still feels very incomplete. 

Also, I usually wouldn't say this but I'd recommend playing with the music off. It becomes very annoying very quickly.

You like roguelite top-down twin stick shooters like Assault Android Cactus, Enter the Gungeon or Nuclear Throne? Great. But you also enjoy a bit of thinking... maybe not always just shooting everything that moves, different ways of solving puzzles when you feel like it? A bit of Deus Ex? You enjoy silly humor that does not take anything seriously? Then this is the game for you!

In Streets of Rogue your aim is to overthrow a dictatorial mayor (who banned Nugget Chickens!) and end his reign of terror over the city. Shoot everything that moves or just try to approach this a bit more peacefully... and maybe win the next elections?

Words that come to mind when I think of the game are: addicting, highly polished, smooth gameplay, funny, frantic, silly, great soundtrack, many unlockable charackters, different solutions... 

To help you learn the basics it comes with an outstanding tutorial. I am not easily saying this, but the music is also really good. 

Up to 4 local or online players supported. Friendly fire possible. Due to the different ways to play the game, playing with randoms can be a bit... chaotic. Worked perfect with 4 XBox 360 and with 4 XBox One controllers. Cloud saves are supported.

[u][b] Conclusion:[/b][/u]
One of the best roguelites available. Highly recommended.

[h1]TL:DR[/h1]
	The game is a roguelite RPG where you choose a character that will change radically how you apprehend the run and what objective you will seek! fun and animated in pixel art. overall a fine game.
	
[h1]Full details[/h1]

This part will try to display as much as possible for anyone wondering about buying the game.

[h2]Intro[/h2]
As said in the tl:dr, the game is a action-packed roguelike rpg, that focus on the different character that will dictate everything about your run.

[h2]Story[/h2]
The story take place in an city divided in levels, ruled by a despotic mayor. After being recruited by the brave rebels, you follow a strict and hilarious tutorial and gets introduced to the rebel base. You are told that the most precious resource, now scarce, after a ban by the mayor, is the chicken nuggets! Your ultimate goal, to get rid of the dictator and free the city.
After being introduced to everything, you get to chose your character. 

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
The game play change drastically with each character.

[h3]Character[/h3]
Each character get different skills, equipment, advantages and disadvantages. Some can't use weapons, some can't even attack people. Some people are hated and are attacked on sight. Each character also comes with a story that is translated in the in-game objective to do each level.
There is also a tool to create your own character. The are dozen of skills, items to use and interact with. 
[h3]City[/h3]
The city is separated in 5 parts each divided in 3 stages, the slums, industrial area, the park, the Downtown and the uptown. Each stages are populated with random NPC, using the load out from the same playable character, and objective, building to loot, enemy/friend to recruit or kill. 
The combinaison of your character, the population, the building and the objectives, make an "unique" scene every runs. Each 3 stages, the floor is again randomised by a "disaster".
	There are thousands of different setups.
[h2]Visual[/h2]
The pixel art is really well made and the minimalist animation are enough for this kind of game. 

[h2]Sound design[/h2]
The music fits the overall mood, the sound from the different interaction, are ok.

[h2]Other note worthy point[/h2]
I didn't encounter any game breaking bugs during my 12 hours of play. The game still gets update to get rid of remaining bugs. 

[h1]Why I can't recommend[/h1]
I know that most of the things I said in the previous part was mostly positive but I don't feel like I should recommend this game. here's why.
I really like the time I spent in the game. But the random element, gets boring really fast. It kinda reminds me of the no man's sky beginning, the "wow 19^1°°°°°°°° planet" effect, fades after 10~12 hours, and you get the feeling of deja-vu. Same goes with the character, in my opinion, they don't influence the gameplay enough.
The last bit of complaint is focus about content. At the moment of writing, the workshop allows to share, custom character made using the in-game character creation, and some tile. The fact that the first DLC, added only 8 characters for 5€ seems kinda disappointing, I know that dev needs money to work and keep updating, but I fear that real mod meaning "adding content" for the character creation might never come and I think that it would save the boring factor.
Every time I play, this game makes me laugh.

Its cute, But not very interesting. 

Cons:
-Lackluster npc interactions
-Lackluster combat depth
-Ugly Art
-Lackluster Simulation of a 'city'
-Bad RPG Mechanics
-RNG  level generation has a lot of limits, specially shown here, not a lot of replayability, its more about challenging yourself to repeat the same tasks over and over with an excuse of not being "the same level". but its always the same thing. rng is never the be all of game design

You should know first, this is yet another game that tries to be a roguelike, and like many others, it fails. Its just not deep enough and way more focused on the combat than it should have been

Art:
Its disgusting to look at, its another fricking pixel game. One thing good about pixel art is that it works in low resolution properly, and it also easily conveys the characters. But we all know pixel art is used because how fast it is to make them.

Narrative:
Supposedly there is something, but the game is more focused on fun 'runs' on the missions isntead of focusing on the narrative. There are some quests, but they are just fetching, there isnt much explanation. You dont feel like there is a grander scheme, a plot, or a reason for anything that is happening, its all just pieces of randomly generated content without any thought or love. And like that it just feels like a mess

Design:
No death penalty, even almost no penalty for being a jack ass, so you just go and do stupid stuff. Also theres almost no proper npc interactions, they dont have any depth. So you dont even care about just doing some EXTREME VIOLENCE runs. Just kill everyone, unlock cannibal and thats it. You can play as the ape and keep killing everyone until you get a translator(strong attacks). And yes, the core design of the game is the combat, which is sad for an rpg, but meh, not like someone is gonna come to this game expecting something interesting.

Last Words:
Cool concept, not a lot of replayability. But despite the concept, there isnt much out there. Like many indie games, i recommend a redesign or way longer production time.

This game is unplayable.

It doesn't accept directional button inputs for menu movement, the analogue stick inputs feel weirdly delayed and sticky, and when I swapped the attack/special and weapon select buttons, it still attacked whenever I hit the shoulder button despite attack only showing as being bound to a different button.

This is what pushed me over the edge into refunding this, but there were already warning signs with the fact that it kicks you into a tutorial before you even see a menu screen and you can't change to a controller unless you're on the main menu. So I went to the main menu, the game crashed, and when I came back in I couldn't find the tutorial. So I had to actually look up online where the tutorial is, went to the tutorial, and it's assuming I'm using a keyboard and mouse instead of the controller I set it to (with the right button prompt type selected, mind). After I used the hacking tool, I noticed attack used the triggers which have a slight delay because it uses the full inward press to activate instead of a partial press (another red flag of poor design imo) and then my issue I stated further up happened.

I've got a ton of patience for jank as long as it doesn't make me motion sick, but this is a ridiculously bad first impression. There are what are considered very bad ports of games from the early 2000's on PC that still manage not to mess up this stuff.

I'm sure there's plenty of people who love the game anyway and more power to em. I just cannot recommend this game unless they put out a patch that tightened up these issues massively and there weren't any other horrendous hiccups like it.

The year 2020 is a messed up place. A corrupt Mayor has taken over the city, the police are either extremely corrupt or heavily armed, and people wearing red shirts are locked in constant violent conflict with people wearing blue shirts. There's also a killer robot hunting people, bombs falling from the sky, cannibals hiding in the parks and zombie outbreaks almost daily. Welcome to Streets of Rogue!

Streets of Rogue is a Top-Down-Action-Rogue-Lite game where you choose from up to 36 character classes; From Cops, Robbers and Firefighters, to Aliens, Robots and Gorillas (with more available through Steam Workshop and the in-game character creator). The goal of the game is to make your way through the city's 5 randomly-generated sectors to reach the Mayor's Villa and set things right. The sectors have 3 levels; In each one you're given a set of random tasks to complete BY ANY MEANS NECESSARY! With support for up to 4 players (both LOCAL and ONLINE), Streets makes for a great party game that doesn't require a lot of hardcore dedication.

[b]THE CHAD:[/b]
[list]
[*] [b]LARGE VARIETY OF CLASSES[/b] with vastly different play-styles and special abilities. Want to kill everything? There are a few classes that do that. Want to play a pacifist? Completely viable. Seduce anyone? Flex that charisma, bro! There's enough variations that you can have a new experience with each character every time you play. You can also create your own class using a simple in-game editor if you feel like something is missing.

[*] [b]PERK-BASED PROGRESSION[/b] keeps the game from becoming a number-grind while still conveying an increase in skill and ability. 

[*] [b]RANDOM LEVEL LAYOUTS WITH STEAM WORKSHOP SUPPORT[/b] means no two playthroughs are the same. There are a few oversights I'll cover a bit further down, but there's enough content that the areas never feel same-y or dull.

[*] [b]OPEN-ENDED MISSIONS.[/b] Neutralize doesn't mean you HAVE to kill someone, just tell them to leave town or knock them unconscious! Retrieving an item can have you kicking down the door guns-blazing, putting sedatives in the air-conditioning unit to knock out everyone inside, or just bribing the guards with beer! Multiple endings also mean you won't be completely done with the game after 1 successful playthrough.

[*] [b]INSANE ARSENAL[/b] ranging from basic tools and melee weapons, to typical modern firearms, to tasers, hypnotizers and teleportation grenades! No item feels completely useless in utility, worst case is that you sell them for money that can be put towards other objectives. Power-ups come in the form of syringes and pills, and grant random abilities like giant growth, electric touch and acid blood (not the kind that hurts enemies, the kind that boils your insides).

[*] [b]MULTIPLAYER[/b] is extremely well-implemented with both ONLINE and LOCAL co-op. Couch co-op is so rare in PC games, even with the abundance of console-ports of the modern era. While I was faster playing with mouse + keyboard, the game controls smoothly enough on gamepad that most anybody can pick up the game fairly quickly without having to learn any special techniques.

[*] [b]SOUND DESIGN[/b] is excellent. Weapons sound like they have weight behind them, explosions are heavy and the soundtrack is pure BANGERS. My personal favorites are 3-3 and 4-2, but the tunes all run together beautifully. 
[/list]

[b]THE BAD:[/b]
[list]
[*] [b]THERE ARE NO STREETS??[/b] Some areas have trains or minecarts running in a straight line across them horizontally, but the closest you get to an actual street are the canals running through Downtown. The floor is almost completely dirt/grass/sidewalk. I would assume there are issues with the map generation that made roads too janky to implement, but c'mon, it's in the game title!

[*] [b]THE MECH-PILOT[/b] is underwhelming. Part of the DLC pack (which has fun characters otherwise), when I first heard about the class I was hoping the mech would be more grandiose, but it's more remniscent of Iron-man than Mechwarrior. The laser weapon is a flashy pistol at best, and no alt-fire rocket launcher makes the class a gimped soldier.

[*] [b]NO COMPETITIVE MULTIPLAYER MODE[/b] means once you've perfected the art of teamwork with friends, the game becomes a little too straightforward and routine. A competitive mode such as a race, or missions with conflicting objectives (IE One player has to neutralize, the other player has to escort) would add a whole new dimension to the party formula.

[*] [b]NO PLAYABLE DOG, CAT OR JANITOR CLASS[/b] okay this is kind of biased but I assume the dev doesn't want people gibbing house pets. But low-skilled workers are still fair game! Also wish the Slum-Dweller had a panhandling ability of some kind, but now I'm nitpicking. The main takeaway here is that while the character creator is easy to use, there are still hard limits to modifying class abilities, big quests, character sprites, etc.
[/list]

Bad aside, Streets is a great game well worth checking out. With a humble price tag going on sale regularly, a steady stream of bug fixes, code updates and endless potential for expansion, Tinybuild has the foundation for a great franchise set up. The sequel has already been announced and is in development, but until then I would highly recommend trying out the original. And remember kids, if you find a syringe in the street, TAKE IT TO A DOCTOR FIRST so you at least know what you're poking yourself with.

Though i wouldn't play up the comparisons to other games as much as the store description does, it's somewhat accurate,
as this game mixes roleplay with gameplay mechanics in a way that WORKS SO, SO WELL. Couple that with the human element with unique and creative items with a plethora of use cases and you'll find what you think is cheese is just top tier gameplay.

The humor is mixed in such a way that it's not just funny, it's immersive, unironically so, in equal parts presentation and in circumstance. For instance, if you play as a slaver, people generally won't like you because your gameplay loop generally consists of enslaving randos on the street and using them as living, breathing, walking land mines. That or you're just a weirdo in leathers. The people in this game are superficial like that. 

It's simple to pick up and play but complex enough to where you can develop your skillset within the game by both study and character builds, and the system works well for a game with a plethora of characters to choose from.

My only complaint is that the character unlock conditions are kind of arbitrary. They aren't too extreme save for one or two characters that were a little tough to get, and you'll want to unlock them if you want to use their exclusive traits on a custom character.

Streets Of Rogue is more of a sandbox than most other sandbox games. That's where the appeal is - if you get the idea to do something, you probably can. The opening 10-ish hours can be boring before everything's unlocked, but the sheer depth of creative options, both before and during a playthrough, are unrivalled in this genre.

There's also the exceedingly immersive gameplay - nearly everything works exactly like it looks like it does. The slaves can be freed, the walls can be knocked down with explosions, the locks can be picked, the windows smashed, and so on. At no point will you be stuck in a situation so illogical that you can't think your way out of it.

Of course, it wouldn't be the same game without the robust and balanced(-ish) character creation system. Every item, every move, and every passive ability the pre-made characters have, you can use to design your own. Most of them have to be unlocked first, but it's entirely worth the effort. With it I've been able to create SOR versions of preexisting characters like Link and MC Public Urination, as well as OC like Safecrack Mulroney and The Surprise Mechanic.

Hopefully that answers your questions, to some extent at least. But now that I've typed this out, I'm going to use it as my Steam review too. I haven't updated it since before the character creation was added into a pre-release patch. This'll save time.

From what I've played of it so far, its one of top 3 go to games. Its the perfect kind of game to play whilst watching a movie, it doesn't bog you down with story and details so you can easily pay attention to whatever your watching, but equally its a lot of fun in its own right and absolutely won't get boring anytime soon.

Also worth noting, something I absolutely love about it is that it doesn't punish you for essentially having fun. It has the mutators you can apply to runs, and some of them are a little cheaty (eg infinite ammo, infinite durability) but help to make the game even more chaotic and for a lot of people just makes it more fun. Now a lot of games would give you those abilities, but limit or turn off progression whilst using them. This game does not (I believe theres only one mutator which does and I think that one is a literal god mode). You can make yourself insanely overpowered, and the game doesn't care, as long as your having fun.

tldr: Absolute chaotic fun

Streets of Rogue is a lot of fun and has a lot of customization, but it gets boring over time. While there are dozens of characters and items, there are only a few three basic missions: kill someone, rescue someone of retrieve an item. While you can play the game with different playing styles, the game itself gets boring after a few runs. Also, each mission affects only the level it's on. Adding chain events would let the player explore different sub-plots, and would make the game much more enjoyable. 7/10.

Fun Rogue-lite with a GIANT variety of options of play. Basically, each run involves completing set missions wherein completion gives you a random reward item or money and leveling up gives you a choice between various traits that change how your character plays. Metacurrency is gained each level up or completion of optional missions to allow for unlocking more traits and reward items. Traits and rewards can be turned on and off and the configurations can be saved with custom names lending itself to deck building to have a higher chance of getting what you want. There are a ridiculous number of characters, most with unique abilities that greatly change how you can approach each mission and unlocked by completing specific objectives. The list of modifiers is long and allows for a variety of large game-changing modes. Even without custom characters, custom chunks/environments, and workshop accessibility, this game has a ridiculous amount of replayability.

Storyline: 10/10
The storyline contains a lot of humor. I find myself laughing from how to creators approached the game's tutorial to how they "end the game". The commentary each character makes during the various floors and each character description when choosing who to play with are very well thought out. Loved it!

Controls 9/10
I play with an XBox controller. Playing with my laptop keys were too confusing and the simplicity of an XBox controller was much better for me. It's very easy to navigate the game, but I find my friends and/or myself accidentally overclicking sometimes which can lead to some unfortunate events during the game. Still I recommend using a game controller when playing Streets of Rogue.

Music: 10/10
I find myself humming along often when I play...much to my friends dismay when we play co-op. Great music and I love the different tracks per floor.

Artwork: 10/10
I love the artwork in this game. My favorite part is being able to customize each character in many different ways. My only wish is being able to keep our designs per each character so I don't have to keep making my favorite combos. The floors themselves are really pleasing to the eye.

Continued Features: 8/10
I think this is the one concern I have for Streets of Rogue. I have logged many, many hours during the short time I've owned this game. There's so much to unlock...from super characters to Steam achievements...but when you're done what else is there to do? I've tried playing with some super characters and it's just not as fun without an overall goal so I'm unsure if I would play this game much after I unlock all the characters available. Mods are available and accepted in the game, but I do hope we get more in the future.

Play Experience: 9.5/10
I've logged so many hours playing this game. I play solo and with friends and both experiences are fun and enjoyable every time. I would highly recommend this game to others and hope there's more packs offered in the future. I would definitely buy it and continue to enjoy many more hours with this game. If you want some action packed, yet relaxing game time, try this one out!

Streets of Rogue is like Monaco meets GTA, set in a modern progression roguelite container.

It is pure fun, and you have freedom in how you play it.  Wildly different playable classes give you so much variation depending on who you pick each run, along with your unlocks, and if you choose to set mutators to really mix it all up.

Want to be a gang member who can recruit any of their NPCs gang members around town to create a posse? Do it!
How about a bartender who can mix drinks on the fly, even into poisons, and hand them to any NPC (they can't refuse) to drink 'em?
A hackerman who can remotely connect to computers & electronic devices and mess with them, cause them to blow up, ATMs to spit out money, unlock all the doors & safes in a building, or turn on the gas & traps?
A stealthy ninja?
A clown who tells jokes so bad that they make NPCs attack you?
A vampire?
An incognito werewolf who can wolf out & tear up a place?
A wrestler who can throw anything?
A scientist who experimented on gorillas?
That escaped gorilla?
All that sound too "normal"? Be a zombie, where anyone who dies after you projectile spit on them or got into a melee fight with will resurrect as a fellow friendly zombie and go on to attack other NPCs until you realize you've turned the whole level's NPCs into fellow zombie friends!
And all playable classes have a per-level special mission, on top of the normal proc-gen missions, using their unique talents.

DISCLAIMER: During the time of playing Streets of Rogue (9 hours), I had actually not purchased the game, but was playing it through Remote Play with a friend. 

So, what's Streets of Rogue? Well, it's a top-down rogue-like game in which feature different classes. You can be a Soldier who can shoot up anything in sight, or an Assassin that can sneak attack anyone in one blow. Maybe you like to make things easy and hack the systems as the Hacker, or even take over bodies with the Shapeshifter. It's really all up to you, and the only limit is your choice. 

The game's function includes missions in which must be completed to progress each stage. These missions vary from neutralization to something more subtle like getting an item. However, each class has their own Big Quest, in which you can optionally take for more EXP and keep your run "successful". 

That's basically the base game right there and there's more to discover with the playthrough of the game, so I highly suggest you get your hands on this game.

NOTICE: This game was purchased during a 51% sale, prices may vary for each consumer during the season.

Where do I start to begin describing Streets of Rogue.... Maybe the point where I sent a fridge flying across the map like it was a SpaceX rocket? Or maybe the time when I poisoned a building full of people I had to get rid of via a potion that simply causes them to start fighting each other?

Streets of Rogue isn't just a 'roguelite' no no. If you read only the description you'll never understand what this game has to bring. If GTA got dirty with a rogue game and pixelated itself you'd have Streets of Rogue. The premise is simple, run through each level accomplishing certain goals that are deceptively simple. Except when you do these objectives there's several hilariously creative ways to go about it. It's a hilariously refreshing take on the 'rogue' style RPG's and I couldn't recommend it enough. I wish I could give a short verb answer to what Streets of Rogue is but there's just honestly far too much to explain. Every time I launch this game it puts a smile on my face. With a massive amount of 'class' selection and even more options with custom characters you'll never play the same game twice. Is it a repetitive game at times? Yes but that's what 'rogue' is. Is it a hilariously grand time that you CAN play with a few buddies? Absofreakinglutely. If you're a fan of Rogue-likes and want a more comedic game that's refined and impossible to put down you can't find a superior option then the Streets of Rogue. Truly, a one of a kind game. Nearly 100 hours sunk into it and I'm sure that will be a four digit number in the near future. I'd buy it at full price just because the game developer is that damn good. AAA Studios should get this crew's number.

Five years ago I was diagnosed with a rare personality disorder that necessitated the torturing of laboratory animals to mitigate. The suffering of those poor animals provided a fleeting catharsis, but my unwavering hatred of life itself ensured that I would return to claim the lives of more innocent creatures.
Anyway, just as things were starting to get really out of hand, I found this game. The extreme levels of sadism and cruelty one can perpetrate against the just and unjust in this game, rendered in a fun retro graphic style, has replaced the bloodlust that plagued me (and those poor lab rats) for so long. Whenever the  hideous voice screams from the abyss, I just play this. I haven't tried to kill anything in months, and I don't even miss it that much.

A blast to play. The game gives you a ton of goofy tools, goofy goals and goofy NPCs and lets you go nuts. Depending on your character class and preferences, you can be stealthy, go rambo, lead a gang, or switch between those styles at will--and that's just with the stuff unlocked from the start! I laughed a lot while playing this and had fun every minute.

The centerpiece of this game is the AI friendship/anger system, which is just complex enough to feel believable and allow for fun situations while being intuitive. Most NPCs are neutral at the start but become angry if you hurt their friends, fight inside their store, tresspass, etc--but they'll allow some actions if you make friends with them first, or even hand you your mission objective on a silver platter. The same rules apply to NPC-to-NPC interactions, so you can trick someone into hitting a cop or tresspassing to make the other NPCs gang up on them, and many items have the sole purpose of forcing NPCs to fight each other.

There's a wide variety of classes, many of which play very differently--encouraging violence, stealth, socializing, and gadgetry/trickery in varying amounts. Each class has a unique long-term quest to differentiate them further. There's also a lot of creative items and skills to help you out (many unlockable).

Graphical style is great, the music is phenomenal, and as I said above the humor is on-point.

Overall I strongly recommend this to anyone who likes Roguelikes.

Well, I haven't finished this game yet, but at 51 hours in, I think I'm pretty qualified to go ahead and recommend or not, and it's solidly recommended.

This is a super fun rogue-like that gives you a ton of options and near endless inspiration to continue.  Honestly, since the game itself is so simple, there are very few - if any - real negatives to it, so let's just dig into why it's as fun as it is.

1)  Charming graphics.  They're slightly less detailed than even the River City Ransom 8-bit characters, but that's just due to being much smaller.  The way they look and move is very evocative of the same style to me, though, and that'll always be a plus.

2)  The characters you can pick are ridiculously diverse with a ton of different abilities, quirks, weaknesses and such that developing a distinct playstyle for each is a challenge, but it's a MUST since unlocking the ability to start at a higher floor requires finishing the floors UNDER it with at least 5 different characters.

3)  You can create your own characters!  I did and apparently forgot about it, unless the Streetfighter is a standard character but from the wiki, it doesn't look like it is.  But that means I wrote the bio (character has "sausage fingers" trait):  "When you spend your childhood teased for your kielbasa-like fingers, unarmed fighting becomes a way of life." and I don't remember writing that.

(Addendum:  while writing this, I actually completed the game for the first time, with the ninja.)

4)  While I prefer a rogue-like that allows you to accrue actual benefits that stick with you, this is a good middle ground between that and the 'start from scratch every time' type.  You accrue chicken nuggets (don't ask, it's like hub-level cash) and can buy traits (perks for your character you gain on leveling up) that may become available for selection in your subsequent runs - it's a bit randomized, but still.  You can also unlock equipment that you can add to your loadout (1 item each time, I think) from another character in your hub level, but note that they don't offer you the FULL selection of equipment you've unlocked.  If you want a particular thing and it's not there, then you'll have to pay to change the selection.  Regardless, chicken nuggets are not hard to come by, gaining them on every level-up while playing, and from optional missions.  You'll also unlock (for free, but by meeting certain criteria) new "mutators" (cheats, basically, though most of them are for increased challenge, only a few make it actually easier) and new character types, none of whom are overpowered.

5)  Great sense of humor.

6)  Pretty good music.  I enjoyed it.

All in all, if a brawler is your thing, and you like rogue-likes and the art style, you'll enjoy this, I'm absolutely certain.  Definitely recommended.

Just imagine you're chilling in your house watching TV when a fully grown ape bashes your door down and proceeds to violently beat you to death. You didn't hear anything before the assault and now you stand no chance of surviving the vicious beast. Your last moments alive are spent wondering how things went so wrong, and as your soul leaves this mortal coil you see the ape pillage your fridge for a banana. 

Alternatively, imagine that you're in bed and just starting to doze off to sleep, when a guy just runs through your walls and demolishes half your house, leaving as fast as he arrived. You sit up in bed wondering what just happened; perhaps it was a dream? But the creaking sound of your floorboards and the groaning noise of your house collapsing on to you confirms the realness of it all. You feel a sharp pain across your torso as your broken ribs pierce into vital tissues, you try to scream but the weight of the collapsed debris prevents any vocal projections. As your vision starts fading to black, you hear the man return. He offers no assistance, no remorse or pity, however, he does reveal his motive. "It's just a prank, bro! Jeez, stop taking it so seriously you CRYBABY!". The last thing you experience was the soul-shattering noise of the multi-thousand 4K TV being struck by a baseball bat.

Actually, imagine that you're doing anything when a full-on war between the army and a bunch of inbred cannibals erupts right next to you. You try to run away but one of the cannibals wielding a battleaxe violently swings at you, bringing you to Death's doorstep. However, you are able to escape the crazed cannibals but alas, a stray bullet hits you and kills you immediately.

In summary, SoR is pretty fun but also terrifying as it brings out the urge to kill all I see as a bloodthirsty Gorilla.

*NOTE TO DEV*
Love the game, but here are 2 "issues" I found within the game. Please correct me if either of these 2 are working as intended:

1. It is almost never a good idea to negotiate or threaten NPCs because in order to do so you must stand within batting distance of the NPC. If the threat fails, you will immediately be attacked and hit by the now hostile NPC. This ruins roleplay as I am incentivized to just kill NPCs for quest items instead of threatening them or negotiating with them. I'd rather get the first hit on the NPC than have the NPC hit me first.
Sure, if the threat fails the NPC will announce their hostile turn, but at the same time they've already hit you. There's no announcement of turning hostile, pause, then retaliating. It's an instant punish on the player if it fails.

2. When playing with Rogue-Vision mutator, you cannot see through the eyes of people you mindcontrolled. This results in a lot of guess work when the NPC you control turns a corner or enters a building.

Keep up the good work!

[h1]Streets of Rogue[/h1]
I have played 2 roguelites before this one I think.
I really loved "Enter the Gungeon" (EtG) but struggled to feel the same towards "The Binding of Isaac" (TBOI).
Both are generally considered hard by some. The general difference while still being similar in many aspect is why they are difficult, I dislike when RNG rather than skill is needed. 
This is why I love EtG as you can beat the general game everytime with starting guns. You might get OP runs in both respected games, but for TBOI having good skill is often not enough without RNG. 
What is the point of restarting till you get something good rather then let the game throw curveballs that stimulate your knowledge of the game without being unfair?

This is why I love "Streets of Rogue" (SoR). The difficulty aspect is completely dependent on you. 
Sure, this means that it lacks a higher natural difficulty curve and might feel less rewarding, but "too hard" is not a problem with this game.
Depending on what class you play you will have to adapt your way to play.
Some feel easier while others are frustrating. 
You can even make custom characters and still make progress if you balance them out. 
Typically you can make them OP or underwhelming to stimulate difficulty. 
Of course you could just for fun exceed the values if you don't feel to make progress.
Point being that with all cutomization options available you can greatly tailor your experience to what you feel is a difficulty enjoyable to you.

[h1]The progress system.[/h1]
M-missions and character level ups reward you with Chicken Nuggets. 
You accumulate them and can use them at the homebase after the run/s for unlocking more "traits" and "rewards". 
You can also use them to buy items to temporarily start with on the next run.
When you unlock more traits/rewards the game scales this to how much you must have in the pool as a minimum.
The cool thing is that you can edit out which traits and rewards you dont want to show up, to better suit them for your playstyle. 
For instance you probably don't want firearm boosting traits if your character can't use guns.
These settigns can be save and loaded at the base when you want to change them between what characters you use.
After beating all floors of an area with 5 different characters you unlock the option to start there by going to the elevator at the homebase.

There are also achievements for completing various misc. things aswell as completing the story in certain ways.
You will also unlock several characters. The unlock conditions are stated on the character selection screen.
I would have liked more achievements to be presents specifically for completing the big quests and story with each of the vanilla characters.
This is also a good way to keep more players engaged and increases replayability for some.
I might have unlocked all traits, most rewards and achievments after less than 30 hours, but that doesn´t prevent me from seeing myself continuing to play the game.

[h1]The Core Gameplay [/h1]
You start by selecting a class/character. Each vanilla character has their own "big-quests" they need to do on every floor and comes with their own traits and abilities.
As an example you might play as a police officer or a thief. One of them can arrest people and the other one can steal from people (abilities).
To beat their quests you will have to arrest enough guilty people as the police officer and steal enough from safes/chests as the thief (big-quests).
Apart from this their traits give the characters positive and negative artributes which typically feels logical to the nature of the character.
For instance the police officer is alligned with other officers and loses xp when arresting innocent peoples.
Most traits can be swapped or removed on floors for money. Most mechanics are trial and error, there are different vending machines etc.
Apart from character specific quests there can be a number of different quests on each floor. By doing quests and killing/saving people you get xp and level up.
Upon finishing the floor you get to chose to improve traits or add new ones essentially making you stronger for the more upcoming difficult floors.
You don't need to succeed with your missions, but either have to complete them or fail them.
After that you progress to the next floor and the next till you beat the levels of the floor and enter an new area.
Eventually after several areas you beat the game. 
While the traits, loot etc. on the floors can determine if you succeed to some degree, i never felt that RNG unfairly ended or made me OP during a run. 
Another mechanic of the game is that disasters may appear upon entering a new floor.
This can be really deadly with radiation, ooze spreading or make everyone be affected by random status-effects every couple of seconds etc.


[h1]Replayability[/h1]
I initially after 10 hours of gameplay struggled to see the 100's of hours of replayability some talked about.
Fairly quickly the main game was beaten and while things are randomly generated and runs will vary some, the end goal was done.
There are many character to try and do the same with but it doesn't feel that exiting.
As an achievement hunter I could see the misc. things as something to work towards and unlock more characters.
What would have been great in my opinion (apart from my earlier suggestions) would have been to add achievements for unlocking traits and rewards. 
Something to keep more players engaged. 
The thing which really changed my perspective on replayability is how cleverly the Dev has taken advantage of the core-gameplay. 
While the game mostly is the same it can greatly be affected by lots of things as mentioned before, but it goes even further. 
You can use mutators. This can alter the game sooo much. From removing annoying "disasters" that can occur on floors to making everyone equipped with rocket launchers.

While the game is great for single player it gets much better with multiplayer. It has the option to be played both online or locally (unsure if mix match is possible between local and online).
It goes up to 4 players at the same time and you can revive eachother and kill eachother. It can create funny synergies or pit you against eachother depending on what character you decide to use.
I started playing the game Co-op and had lots of fun. I accidently missed to setup a password the first time and immediately had someone join me so I would assume there is a decent playerbase.
(btw sorry about leaving the game :/)

[h1]The Conclusion[/h1]
With an active Dev and a recent dlc character pack being released, the game is for sure alive with updates to come.
While the core-gameplay can feel a bit dull at times, there can be frustrating moments and hilarious moments all the same.
The game is created in a good way that lets players of different skill levels enjoy it and with all the customability it can keep the replayability high.
I will still say that the multiplayer experience is far superior to playing it alone.

Apart from expanding achievmements and continuing to improve the core-gameplay (enemies, mission types, building types etc.) the game has few flaws when you have learned how it works.
Especially impressive is the ai and level of customization.
It has provided a more casual and creative roguelite-experience than EtG and TBOI and I highly recommend it.

Many games today could be described as wide, but shallow. This game is the complete opposite.

Each mechanic in the game is so simple it's stupid. But there are hundreds of these mechanics, all interacting with each other to make a living, breathing system. This silly, retro, rogue-lite has one of the most alive worlds I've ever seen in a game.

And despite having 'Rogue' right in the name, it doesn't just rely on hair-pulling difficulty like so many others. There are dozens of ways to play, and different ways to tweak and adjust the game for exactly the style of play you're looking for. Easy, hard, stealth, action, good, evil. You'll find it all here and more.

Streets of Rogue is one of those rare games that truly [i]gets[/i] how much potential for interactivity videogames have, and it was obvious even back right at the start of Early Access.

The gameplay is set in one of the most interactive sandboxes I've ever played in. It would take the Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy to catalogue everything that can be done in this game, even within the limitations of a 2D top-down RPG in an underground city. The music is boppin' as hell and it evolves as you go through each biome -- each set of 3 levels has a different theme and the 3rd is by default a special Event with a raging beat. That being said, you can customize the gameplay and remove those Events, or change a hundred other aspects. There's even a level editor now and custom campaigns.

Don't believe what Steam says about my play time. I had a copy of this game that fell off the back of a pirate ship, but seriously a game that gladly destroyed my life for 1000 hours needs my money. Everyone I've ever played this game with has had fun, even my 55 year old mum laughed her ass off at accidentally punching every shop keeper in the face because she kept clicking on people instead of tapping 'E'.

I feel a bit weird about paid DLCs being added to this game, but to be honest if it's helping fund the guy who made it, so he can make more games (which he has expressed interest in doing), then I say it's not the exploitative type of DLC, so it's fine.

A friend told me to get this and I didn't really think to much of it at the time.  2D games generally aren't really my thing but oh boy this one is different.

Its a rogue like but it also feels very heavy on roleplaying.  For example my favorite class is the mech pilot which can be obtained with the character pack which is also hugely worth it.  The description for the mech pilot reads something like straight out of a judge dredd comic.  It's perfect.  I go around in a giant suit of armor protecting the "innocent" and dishing out apocalyptic  justice on the deserving.  Gangsters (crepes and blawds) will attack me on site or run away if I show them overwhelming firepower.  Somehow, someway this single developer has made a 2D game that completely captivates me into the role of whom I'm playing as.  

The challenges this game throws at you are wonderful too.  You'll get to a stage and something like "riot riot riot" or strange gas will cause constant changes to everyone.  I breath in and become a momentary giant capable of smashing through walls like paper and crushing goons beneath my enormous mechanized feet.  The innocent run away to cover as blaster rounds ricochet off walls and shotgun pellets from goons are lobbed back in response.

I really enjoy the combat roles but if that isn't your playstyle you can completely avoid combat.  Need to steal an item from a chest?  Don't want to kill everyone?  Play as a hacker and unlock the doors remotely, then sneak in.  Or choose the alien and just mind control your way past.  So many ways to play and so much replayability.

I absolutely wholeheartedly recommend.  I haven't been stuck wanting to play "just one more round" until 1:30 am in a long time.

It also has lots of perks and items you can find and unlock including weird stuff like the Boo-Urns (Which fill a building with ghosts and makes people evacuate).

It also saves every level in case you can't finish all in one session and thanks to the bizarre chicken nugget based unlock system, even a failed run can still give you progress.

I'll say: Give it a go.

Highly recommended fun and light immersive sim with a large range of characters and factions, each with their own traits and AI. This AI is the driving force of the game, with their actions resulting in all sorts of interesting situations.

Each floor asks for you to perform several objectives such as infiltrate a base and loot a safe, or free an individual from a jail. How you do this is up to you. Whether you decide to bribe the bouncer, blow a hole in the wall of the building or just sneak by.

There's plenty of modifiers and unlocks too to keep things interesting, as well as both local and online multiplayer and the ability to make your own character with their own traits and abilities.

I just witnessed several fire fighters run into a re-enforced base to put out a fire, but their security set off a turret. The fire fighters promptly dealt with the automated system which then annoyed the rest of the people in the building, resulting in fire fighters spraying extinguishers in their faces and cutting all of them down with axes.

You're an underground resistance fighter in a cyberpunk city, trying to take down a corrupt mayor. How corrupt exactly? He promised low taxes and more beer for everyone, but instead he raised taxes and confiscated all alcohol. What a bastard!

Streets of Rogue is a friggin awesome yet underrated real time roguelike. I say "roguelike" instead of "roguelite" due to the amount of emergent gameplay. Instead of roaming a dungeon, you explore procedurally generated city streets filled with NPC:s. Most are friendly until you start some havoc.

You get a few random quests per area, for example "free a gorilla from the lab" or "neutralize this person" or "steal a MacGuffin muffin from that fridge." You can do it the stealthy way, or run in guns blazing, basically turning the game into a twin stick shooter. When things go wrong, GTA-like mayhem ensues. The cops might come after you, or you might infuriate a street gang faction, making them aggro. The whole level might turn into hilarious chaos of explosions and people fighting each other. Infiltrating buildings in creative ways is a big part of the game. You will die a lot, and might get a chronic case of "one more run" syndrome.

You can steal from shops, pickpocket, hack computers, ambush people as a vampire, ally with NPC:s, bribe cops, poison air vents with random effect syringes, turn into a giant, clone yourself, and all kinds of crazy stuff.

As NPC's go about their business and interact with each other, the city feels alive. There's random events to add more color: For example, riots, bomb showers, zombie invasions... You might run into rival gangs fighting each other. You could join in, or let them finish and loot the corpses. There's no "karma" system; You won't get punished for evil deeds unless you get caught.

The game has:

- Tons of items with fun effects, weapons and gear.

- Tons of character classes to unlock, from a pacifist doctor to a rampaging gorilla. There's 26 classes at the time of writing. Not enough? Create your own!

- Tons of unlockable traits. Choose a new trait every time you level up.

- Tons of mutators to customize and alter the experience.

- Active modding community.

- Clean pixel art graphics with lighting effects. Lighthearted music that gets stuck in my head.

- Good controls, though it took me a while to get used to them. While learning I made a few mistakes, like using an item I didn't mean to.

I originally returned the game for a refund due to problems with the Xbox controller, but it has been fixed, and now works like a charm. I never regretted buying it again. Fun in short bursts, for 2-3 hours at a time.

Six years in development and two years after release, the game is still being updated, with possibly a sequel in the works. This is a game I return to time and time again. What a time to be a fan of the cyberpunk genre with Final Fantasy 7 Remake and Cyberpunk 2077 coming so close together. Developed by one person, Streets of Rogue stands proud among the giants.

In the search for good local/couch co-op games, Streets of Rogue came highly recommended. So I picked it up when it went on sale, and there it sat for a long time. It has been surprisingly difficult to get friends to play something local co-op when we're hanging out, but when I finally had the time and curiosity to check it out, these were the stages I went through:
1. Nice retro aesthetics. Love the smoothness of the controls. No idea what I'm supposed to do. Chaos.
2. Running around messing with stuff, starting fights, getting killed.
3. Beginning to understand the order of the universe. Different character classes have different special abilities. Now I know how to accomplish the missions to proceed to the next level. But some classes seem useless? Beginning to utilize synergetic class combinations with friends. 
4. Realized that each class has their own personal quest for each stage. The classes previously thought useless just had subtle mechanics and they are actually the most interesting to play as. There are many ways to accomplish the missions, and being artful about it is the way!

[b]TLDR:[/b] 
Simple mechanics, but requires a little patience and curiosity to figure out. 
Deep application of mechanics!
If friends are open to it, this is one of the best co-op experiences I've had!

If you ever played the original GTA from 1997 (and if you haven't, download it, it's crazy) and enjoyed the top-down mayhem and madness, you will probably enjoy this game.  This game captures that feeling extremely well.  The game play is even similar in some ways, though evolved and improved as fits a modern game.  It's like you took the original GTA, removed the cars and replaced the jobs with secret agent missions.  There are a ton of classes to choose from, allowing a vast range of playing styles.  There are always ten different ways to get almost any obstacle in the game, though all of them might not work based on your class, but the right item will let you harness powers of other classes for tricky situations. I don't need to tell you what makes Streets of Rogue a fucking blast to play. I just need to tell you some of the glorious things I've done in it's amazing universe.

I've frozen a man alive with a freeze ray, then proceeded to push him into a manhole causing him to fall down and die.
I've beaten the final boss of the game by hypnotizing him to like me and simply asking for his hat.
I've mobilized a small red gangster army dedicated to the extermination of all blue gangsters.
I've made everyone attack a holographic bigfoot and then threw grenades in the middle killing them all.
I've won an election victory simply by killing all possible citizens on the floor so I am the only voter.
I've become a scientist who injects people with random syringes he found using a water pistol.
I've become a cop and arrested totally innocent people while killing all the non innocent people.
I've tazed a man in a lake and electrocuted him.
I've given a random guy a cyanide cocktail.
I've knocked people out with chloroform just to have my cannibal friend kill them and eat their body.
I've turned into a giant and proceeded to create a path to the edge of the map just to fall off of it.
I've paid insane amounts of money to every person for their weapons only to attack them after they are weaponless with their own weapons.
I've set a group of firemen on fire only to extinguish the fire after they had all died.
I've run through an entire city breaking down walls as a beefy football player.

Streets of Rogue is indeed a game about player choice, it's literally the most euphoric game you can ever play. You'll still be discovering things you can do after and have insane laughs about "I CAN DO THAT?!?!". Give it a try. It's chaotic, wacky, and most of all, insanely fun.

Streets of Rogue is the perfect indie for rebellious people to strike against their mayor/law enforcer/robot(?) more than once, different every time.

In all seriousness, Streets of Rogue features some of the best replayability I have ever witnessed; from several characters with different stats, traits and game styles, plenty of items to use, functions to interact with NPCs to an excellent and unique design in every floor. To top it all, nothing in the game is super rare, like some items in Binding of Isaac.

Streets of Rogue makes use of finishing quests (often hard to do without some brainstorming) which requires you to make a strategy, like hiring gangsters to kill someone for you, bribing to receive an item, sneaking into a hideout to press buttons or to simply just massacre your way to your objective.

Streets of Rogue includes a leveling system, with every level-up, you can select a trait to take with you on your journey. Traits should be selected to fit with your character's current traits and stats or with the items you currently own.

Every character has their own Big Quest to finish, if finishing a run gets boring, this is often the next step you want to take. Finishing your Big Quest on every floor, you'll receive a nice addition to your character for the final floor.

At the end of the day (or night, depending how long you play), you'll still have achievements on Steam to run after once you have finished all the Big Quests (which after 86 hours, I still have not gotten).

When I think of some of my most fond video game moments, I often remember sitting at my computer in the darkness playing NetHack, navigating my Orc Rogue through perilous dungeons, carefully applying my lockpick to each locked door, slowly but surely getting more experienced and geared up. The game never became predictable due to the procedurally generated levels, but if even if it did begin to become repetitive at times, choosing a different role would introduce a completely unique gameplay experience due to the very different strategies that would need to be employed to be successful.

30 years after NetHack was released, yet another roguelike, Streets of Rogue, was introduced into our world.

Streets of Rogue is a real-time roguelike game set in a futuristic cyberpunk-ish world. The game never takes itself seriously, and is frequently hilarious. The premise has something to do with a mayor who promises lower taxes and beer, but follows through with higher taxes and prohibition. You're essentially going to go through level after level, attempting to complete a predetermined set of tasks before you can go on. Just like most other roguelikes, if you die, you start over.

Similar to the classic roguelike games, you'll choose a character before you embark on your adventure. The character are clever and unique: you can be a stereotypical Hacker, complete with poor hygiene, capable of using his laptop to remotely hack computers in buildings to release toxic gases, disable security systems, and open doors. The Gangster can phone up some of his cronies to assist you in your adventure, the Wrestler can pick up and throw pretty much any object in the game, and the Investment Banker has a lot of cash and get can good prices.

The character you choose will drastically change how you approach the game. If you're a Hacker, you're likely to die rather quickly should you choose to run into a room and attempt to beat down enemies. You need to take a more careful and stealthy approach to your entry, utilizing computers and holograms to be effective. A Gorilla, on the other hand, is incapable of communicating with other characters, but is absolutely devastating with its bare hands.

The available and unlockable characters in this game are a blast, but if you feel such an inclination, you can actually create a custom character, which has traits and starting items of your choosing. The possibilities now become ENDLESS. I plan to create characters based on my friends in real life, complete with all their idiosyncrasies.

The gameplay is fast and frantic, and a groovy, funky electronic soundtrack only helps with the immersion. The enemies in the game explode with money and all sorts of fun items when you kill them (and if you kill them HARD enough, their guts end up everywhere as well). After you complete missions, you collect items to help you on your journey, and you have the ability to gain traits after you complete levels, as well. Otherwise, you're playing a roguelike, so your goal is to keep progressing and improving until you die a shameful death.

As far as persistent unlockables, everything you earn in-game comes from a pool of traits, rewards, etc. that you have unlocked. if you want to potentially gain certain things in game, you have to spend chicken nuggets (a persistent resource across all your attempts) to unlock them, and then whatever you have purchased will be in the "pool" of things to earn during your future attempts. You are also free to spend chicken nuggets on weapons for your next attempt, but if you die, they are gone forever.

If you happen to have friends outside of your computer, Streets of Rogue supports cooperative play up to 4 players. I'm not promising that this will necessarily make things easier (especially if taking a stealthier route), but the more, the merrier!

Streets of Rogue is a really a modern remake of a classic roguelike games. If Rogue, NetHack, Moria, etc. were ever games you were interested in or loved, this game is a no-brainer. If you weren't, this game is still worth a shot due to its near-flawless execution of frantic, RPG mayhem, even in its current Alpha state. Just make sure not to die, because nothing will ever quite be the same.

Streets of Rogue is a highly replayable, rogue-like with intuitive gameplay that allows you to express your own playstyle within the constraints of the game without bogging you down with complicated rules and strategies. It's a pick-up and play experience that doesn't feel overly punishing when you lose--rather, you're encouraged to pick up and play again with a new strategy or choose from a plethora of classes (and maybe your own custom class). The multiplayer is both online and local and it allows for unique strategies to finish missions. The mutators (rules in-game that can be activated to change the gameplay) add variety and ease the game for those wanting to adjust the difficulty of the experience. Overall, the game is highly enjoyable, especially with friends!

I love all rogue- like/lites/etc. And Streets of Rogue somehow feels fresh and introduces a lot of novel concepts for the genre, like it's generally passive, dynamic, living world (which isn't out to kill you by default) once you get your bearings and get a feel for the game, it offers unprecedented freedom in the world itself. Another area in which the game sets itself apart is the option to create your own character, which is quite rare for modern rogues, and offers so much freedom! Also, the devs seem extremely active and passionate about the project. 9/10, the game is equal parts familiar and novel.

Uh...How can I describe this?

"A memetic ultraviolent roguelike role-playing stealth thievery shooter pacifistic hack N' slash vampire/werewolf property destroying social friendship zombie apocalypse political upheaval gorilla uprising simulator brawler" I think can work, alternatively just pure unadulterated chaos.

Ultimately, it's a top down...Whatever you want it to be. You can be an assassin, gorilla, vampire, werewolf, inbred cannibal, police officer, wrestler, hacker, the list goes on and each class has their own niche of how they are best and tackling the scenario but you can freely go off the rails at any time. The goal is to take over the city by becoming the mayor and you have an obscene amount of ways to go about doing that and get friends involved for more fun. You can create custom classes with their own abilities and goals, with a point system to keep from being imbalanced that prevents you from getting upgrade currency, but you can make them as OP as you like if you just want to gib pixels after a long day.

You can talk to the hacker in the home base to rebalance the game as you see fit by altering mechanics and events that effect both the players and the enemies, so for example if you put in unbreakable melee weapons or unlimited ammo it will apply to them too.

Unlike other roguelikes, you can also select what items and perks you want in the reward/level up pool with some fair limitations to keep it from being broken, allowing you to tailor the pools to your desired approach between every run.

The atmosphere is pretty wild and silly, but I have a hard time imagine anyone not having SOME degree of fun with it at some point, there's something for everyone here.

A delightfully fun game, that will make you laugh quite frequently with all of the ridiculous situations you find yourself in. A few glitches & other minor issues, but nothing too serious and the game has been frequently updated since I purchased it with fixes and improvements. This would be a great game to play with RL or online buddies, but not so great joining or hosting random multiplayer games (of which there seem to be very few like 6 on the list). The problem with random MP game is if you die it costs the other players either gold or health to resurrect you, so ...usually they don't, and then your only option is to leave the game. While I haven't finished the game with a handful of the characters, there is plenty of variety in skill sets and play styles to make it worth finishing the game with multiple characters. Making custom characters can be fun too. Some stock characters are a bit underwhelming, and some are over powered, but that allows you to play the game however you want as an OP killing machine or as a weakling for the extra challenge. The only glitch I have found is one of the traits doesn't work properly on my custom character ("Fair Game"), but other than that I haven't noticed any other major glitches. But it makes me wonder if some of the traits and skills that would be doing things that are invisible to the gamer are actually working correctly either. But the game in it's current state is almost a perfect game and one broken trait isn't enough to drag it down. It's just a shame that I reported this bug 2 or 3 patches ago and still hasn't been addressed, but I think the dev team may only consist of 1 person (?) so one could understand how sorting through all of the feedback / bug reports could be a nightmare for 1 person to handle in addition to their normal daily work on improving the game. This game is an easy one to recommend, and I'd even say it's a "must buy" game for anyone who is a big fan of roguelike games - it holds a very special and unique place within the genre.

It's a beautiful example of interlocking systems creating emergent gameplay, and considering the sheer amount of systems there are in the game, it's INCREDIBLY robust.
Despite having an enormous amount of play-time with this game, I'm still finding new and interesting ways of combining and exploiting these systems.

Factions that can be manipulated by the player, classes that play incredibly differently bringing a fresh perspective to the game, a remarkably generous mutator system that allows you to tailor difficulty while still allowing you to earn achievements, genuinely funny humour and an absolutely barnstorming soundtrack all combine to make this a must.

I never grow tired of it; it's my game of the year for 2019, without a shadow of a doubt.

And I've not even played co-op yet!

Fun for the sake of fun and a lot of variety. More fun when your robot character's power out objective doesn't entirely agree with your friend's hacker's need to upload to powered computers.

The amount of run modifiers you can apply and that you can turn off perks is great. I wish more rogues did that.

AI is very consistent. Only dislike is that cannibals only hate players. You can turn that off but you can't make them hate NPCs.

Humour is fun if you don't mind that it's 99% references.

Unfortunately feels very underdeveloped and gimmicky with near zero synergies except for perks/items designed to specifically work with a character/perk/item so are useless to carry in the hope of getting their second half. e.g.
[list]
    [*]Mild gun upgrade system
    [*]Mild specialised elemental system that only ~5 items use and only token environmental effects
    [*]Perks are mostly mechanic stat changes
    [*]Okay pills but useless needles
    [*]Objectives are mostly just kill some doods, tapping buttons under a time limit or escorting (you're allowed to fail) are the more interesting ones out of the fiveish objectives, only specific characters can thieve objectives without murder
    [*]Election objective is cool and involves trading useful items away to specific NPCs but doesn't have much going on
    [*]Boss/disaster floors could use more to dilute the "Half of everyone is now hostile" or "Most NPCs are dying" ones
    [*]Final floor is underwhelming
    [*]Floor challenge doesn't particularly change when you go to the different layers
[/list]

I appreciate the parts that aren't a deathmatch. Police helping me against thieves, mafia mugging me with words and then cops helping me, robot cops actually detaining me or confiscating my items unlike the murderous police, buying a round for an entire bar to like me, optional missions making an entire building like me and defend me from attackers, bribing with money or items to get objectives, getting past bouncers with booze, hitting a wall to distract so my friend can steal something unnoticed, bringing two rival gangs into eyesight by using a noisy slum dweller so I can get a murder objective. Those are things most games would have one of in a token story moment, but here that's normal.

I just wish there was more supported modding than map tiles. And that the editor would work for me.

This game is a job simulator in a wasted city full of crime and murder.
Except that you are not only a barkeeper/policeman/drug dealer/shopkeeper/investment banker/comedian etc., but also a spy for a government opposing rebel faction that kinda has no idea what they're doing.
So while making your way through the devastated distopia of the games city world you also need to fulfill crucial mission objective orders straight from your rebel HQ. The fun thing about that is that there's literally millions of ways of doing that, and depending on what job you're educated in there's even more ways with every playthrough.
For example: HQ orders to get a harddrive from the shopkeeper in town. Now, you could kill the shopkeeper and take it, or you could just threaten him to do just that if he doesn't give it to you right now, or you could give him a very valuable item in exchange. But if you are a shopkeeper yourself you can just buy it from him, if you are a thief you can steal it from him, if you are a slavemaster you can enslave him and make him give it to you, and this whole variability makes the game incredibly fun and long-living.

Other than the missions which are well planned in theory and well executed in practice, the game is all about the player being able to do whatever the fuck they want. I especially like freeing gorillas from science labs while there's still scientists in there with them. Welp.

A lot of other reviews already cover the basics - the game looks great, the controls are smooth, the soundtrack is catchy, and there's a big cast of characters that make each session unique. I want to talk about chain reactions. Bear with me.

Streets of Rogue has a lot of different systems modeled in it's gameplay. For example, most buildings have an air filtration system. If you get to the filter unit, you can use various drugs to poison everyone inside. Or maybe you inject a rage-inducing stimulant in there and everybody inside flips out and starts beating each other to death. This can cascade if, say, one of the people inside is a werewolf. They might punch someone through a wall because werewolves are hella buff. If that someone was a gangster... well there might be rival gangsters out in the street. They see the wrong colors and now a turf war has started. That'll probably attract the attention of local cops - who will also show up with guns and batons to put down the ruckus. With all those bullets flying around, there's bound to be some casualties. Like one of them hitting the doctor that you were supposed to escort to the level exit to complete your mission.

This is just one example. There's a thousand different ways for the systems in the game to interact with each other. It takes already great gameplay and adds a level of unpredictability (and often humor) that makes the replay value of Streets much higher. Definitely recommended.

Cyberpunk-lite. 
In the dystopian city of...somewhere nobody mentioned, you can combine a team ranging from street thugs and hackers to investment bankers, gorrilas and vampires to quickly complete a series of simple objectives but with a surprising degree of options. 
Accomplished objectives can reward you with money or items for this run, or chicken nuggets for being the good boy you are which are redeemed in your base for more potential items, traits and modifiers to your runs. 

There's a surprising amount of depth in a very simple game that can be played as quickly or slowly as you want, within some reason. Brute force tactics are fun, but as you advance you're quickly outgunned and outnumbered. 
Subterfuge is great, until enemies are popping out of the woodwork to murder you. Despite its looks, it's open nature plays more like speed rounds of shadowrun or cyberpunk than it looks.

Solid 9/10 lite rouge, mini “society”, action game. Wish there was a tiny bit more depth, gameplay wise, but it has tons of areas (slums, industry, parks, downtown, upper city) with three levels per area. Also a bunch of chaotic “mutators” a.k.a, random events every 3rd level. A ton of unlockables with dozens of different characters to play as and unlock. You can go in stealth or guns blazing! I think you can be a small social butterfly too but I can’t stop painting the town red long enough to try and persuade people. I wouldn’t mind DLC for this game and secretly hope this game goes further somehow!

I'll be honest, I enjoyed the start of the game. You have a lot of freedom to handle things how you want, can often do things in funny and interesting ways, and its genuinely satisfying to use a melee weapon (guns slightly less so). Your missions are kinda fun and you can even choose to not do them if you wish.

But jesus christ, did i dislike the game once i got a decent way through a run. There's a sudden, and god awful, lurch that occurs once you enter the third stage of the game. It goes from "oh there's people, and some of them dont want me in their house, that's fair" to "okay literally any fucking person i walk up to wants to murder me, even if i've done literally nothing to them and am standing in an open field that no one owns.
and from then on out, you don't really have any freedom, or any way to avoid combat, cause 99% of the people you meet *instantly* lunge at your throat, often from 'hidden' positions (you can see them most of the time, but its still annoying as fuck if you don't pay a lot of attention)

On top of that, and around the same point in the game, you might realize just how repetitive all your missions are.

This game has some comedy, and some real charm to it, and especially its combat system, but I absolutely cannot imagine myself ever reopening this game after only three hours in it. (and I'm sure it would be less if i didn't suck and was stuck in the (vastly more fun) early game for a while.)

It's an amazing game. It takes the immersive sim and simplifies the budget but had all the interactions that make a game like it good. I was a merchant and bought and sold my way into being the mayor one run and the next I was an "aggressively recruiting" zombie making everyone else a zombie to rise to the top. 

You can be a hacker and hack everything which would feel completely different from being a mercenary. Runs never feel alike because all the missions the game throws at you have multiple solutions. 

The game also has solid multiplayer for you to find ways to use the interacting systems in exploitable ways together and perks that further customer your character every run.

If you're looking for a zany, insane, do darned near whatever you want kind of roguelike, this is the one for you. 

There are thousands of ways to get any mission complete. Want to hack the computer and turn the turrets on the unsuspecting target? Do it. Walk in and go guns blazing? Got that too. Feel like you want to Solid Snake the heck out of this one? They've got just the cardboard box you're thinking of. And if you're feeling rather resourceful: Be a zombie and infect the city and have *THEM* do your dirty work for you. 

It is a great and extremely challenging game. so pepper your angus and have a great time.

Em Streets of Rogue você pode fazer literalmente qualquer coisa, e a cidade terá reações para coisa que você faz
Quer ser um policial bonzinho e combater o crime? você pode
Quer ser um bombeiro e incendiar uma casa só pra quando você entrar para apagar o fogo aproveitar para roubar algumas coisas? você pode
Quer ser um assassino e passar o nível inteiro sem alertar ninguém? você pode
Quer fazer com que gangues briguem e causem um tumulto muito grande para os policiais saírem e você libertar um prisioneiro? você pode
Quer ser um zumbi e transformar a cidade toda em zumbi e aproveitar que agora todos são seus amigos para cumprir o resto das missões? você pode
Não quer nada disso mas quer só sair atirando e matando todo mundo que você achar pela frente? você PODE!

E o melhor de tudo, você não é penalizado por escolher um modo de jogar ou o outro
Passou a fase toda sem matar ninguém? Bônus!
Passou a fase e matou todo mundo que você viu pela frente? Bônus!
Não causou nada de destruição? Bônus!
Destruiu quase a cidade inteira? Bônus!
Aqui você faz o que quiser, do jeito que você quiser, e não precisa se preocupar em ser penalizado por escolher jogar de certa forma.

Prepare-se para rir com algumas mortes, tanto suas quanto de inimigos, se pergunte "isso é possível?", ria com algumas dicas que o jogo dá ("coma comida saudável, na vida real, não no jogo, no jogo isso não tem efeito") seja expulso de lugares porque você quebrou algo ou simplesmente porque você é feio (ou porque é um ladrão) ou fique no lugar e se prepare para o dono da loja chutar sua bunda de lá (ou você chutar a dele)

Jogue com até 4 amigos (e receba os parábens por ter amigos) para transformar tudo isso num caos muito maior, ou simplesmente pague para as pessoas se juntar a você (e não se sinta completamente solitário jogando sozinho)

Este jogo vale cada centavo dos R$27,99, os gráficos, a jogabilidade, a diversão, a múscia (a trilha sonora é realmente ÉPICA)

Sobre a jogabilidade, ela é simples, mas o jogo não é fácil, permitindo que seja jogado e divertido para jogadores experientes ou pessoas que nunca jogaram um jogo na vida.

O jogo contém:
Tráfico/Uso de drogas
Uso de bebidas alcóolicas
Violência

Online works great at the moment, with very little lag. Local 4 player co-op with friends is my favorite though. The game is so prone to ridiculous and hilarious events, that one ends up laughing so hard.
