I wanted to leave a review after 8 hours or so before steam sale ends. This game is fantastic, If it looks remotely appealing to you, trust me just buy it. Very unique rouguelike that basically plays out like this:

-You pick one of say 20+ so available classes that range from combat to stealth to hacking or thieving, crazy ones like zombie and gorilla as well that have crazy buffs/debuffs to gameplay
-Levels are all randomly generated so they are different every time you play
-there are 2 or 3 objectives per level and they change as well they range from kill a guy, get an item, blow something up etc.
-how you go about this can vary dramatically, stealth, hack a computer and turn turrets against the guards, walk in and blast everyone, turn the map into zombies and let that play out then just walk in.
-it is very difficult and has great replayability as it is never the same
-the unlocks for new characters seem fun such as kill 20 people on one floor to unlock the cannibal
-there is some lasting progression as well to unlock new perks and traits.
-havent been able to try multiplayer, im sure it is a hilarious riot though given what ive seen.

very unique rouguelike that is a blast to play and find out all its little nuances, super difficult but not unfair, excellent soundtrack. just get it foo.

I can't recommend this game enough. It's a brilliant rouge-lite rpg with action elements (no pause) that boasts extremely smooth gameplay (especially for the genre) and an absolutely pitch-perfect anarchic sense of humor in the vein of the original two Grand Theft Auto games. The game is both deep enough for veterans of the genre and simple enough on the surface to work as an introduction to it. A great indie game that's still being developed

I absolutely love the concept of an open-world cyberpunk roguelite immersive sim (like a mutated hybrid of GTA, Deus Ex and The Elder Scrolls: Daggerfall) but Streets of Rogue is a gimmicky and clunky implementation of the idea, pulling a lot of punches to keep the illusion alive but falling extremely short of the concept's full potential.

It works as a novelty game and if you're just looking for something to waste time with, it's probably worth it at full price but if you're looking for something to really sink your teeth into, I think the depth is just not there - sure, there's a lot to do and look at but that's breadth, not depth. It's definitely entertaining but not really engaging for me.

FTL: Faster Than Light; Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup; GTA itself and Daggerfall Unity are all better games that provide more-or-less similar experiences with far more depth and replay value, in my opinion. Half of them are free too!

I am refunding the game for now but looking forward to picking it up again and beating it a couple times when it reaches 50% off. Right now, even on sale it feels overpriced - especially when compared to similar, better games that are also free to play.

I wish there was a mod that turned this from a series of self-contained levels to a procedurally-generated semi-persistent big city that really felt more like a full fledged RPG with more long term progression, meaningful permanent decisions, factions,  exploration and worldbuilding - more Dwarf Fortress: Adventure Mode and less beating up punks on actual Streets of Rage.

Street of Rogue is a dynamic open-end action adventure game. The game is brutal and has some elements representing dark side of humanity, but it still has a great amount of humorous dialogues and characters. As a rogue-like game, each time you load into a mission; the map, tasks, NPCs, traps, and tools will be randomly placed, making this game unpredictable and infinitely replayable. 
You will be a part of the resistance fighting through the city in order to put an end to the major. There are many different characters you can play as; each one will have his/her own ability that provide different gameplay styles and experiences. 
-
 Should you buy this game? Yes, this game kills boredom.
This is a great game, lots of different ways to play it, and configure the game to the style of game you want to play.

One of the best rogue-likes out there and definitely deserves more attention. The amount of freedom and choice and customizability in this game lets you play this game for hours on end without ever feeling bored. The game has incredible modding potential and still has an incredibly fun base game even though its still in early access. I'm sure I'll be following this gem for a long time.

A good game. Really, the best thing about it is the character builder - you can mix and match different attributes and abilities from all of the playable characters, give them a custom loadout, etc... 

Really like one character's ability and think it would synergize well with a certain item? Create a character and give them that item as a loadout. Really like a certain class, but it's stuck with a shitty Big Quest? Make a carbon copy of them and just give them a different one. Best of all, custom characters don't block you out of achievements or progress, unless you give them literally everything which is hey something you can do if you want to mess around.

If you're reading this review because you're thinking about buying this game, let me stop you here. There is a reason I have over 140 hours into Streets of Rogue. The amount of detail in a pixely game is astounding. Aggravate a target until they attack you in front of a police officer and let the officer do your dirty work for you. Become a cannibal and get more health from consuming cooked corpses and less for eating diseased zombies. Everything in this game makes sense. Attack a slave and the slavemaster attacks you in return. Have a taser? Use it to shoot a person who is in water for a nasty kill. Use a Bigfoot hologram to cause a civil war between police, mafia, and gang members. It's amazing that after all of this time, I am still learning the small details.

Lotta replay value in singleplayer, even more replay value in multiplayer thanks to character synergies.

Streets of Rogue is an experiment of balance with it comes to creative chaos and careful linear objectives designed to capitalize on the skill and cunning of the player. Missions and quests can be completed in any order and there exist multiple items and traits useful for specific builds and situations during game play. While the game is fun played alone it becomes a truly golden experience when friends are involved via the multiplayer aspect. Hard to top painting the town red with two or three of your buddies just dicking around and beating everything in sight.

While playing as one of the various characters my open and close certain doors for you, Streets of Rogue is a truly unique experience in that you can play it any way you want to. If there's a certain gameplay element you don't like, you can easily choose to avoid it and do things your own way. You can even add mutators to the gameplay to alter the gameplay experience to add or remove certain things you might not like such as weapon durability, ammo, or it not being a zombie game. You can even edit the item and skill pool to remove perks you're not into if you really don't want to receive!

With almost every single NPC in the game being playable at this point with only a few exceptions (The Worker, Goon, Clerk, and Musician, maybe one or two others. From what I can gather EVERYONE else is playable), I've been playing this game for about a week now I've sunk 77 hours into it and I'm still not bored of it. This game is definetly more than worth the price even if it's not on sale.

You can literally play the game any way you want to, even stepping outside the bounds of your selected class' traits.

Don't like the classes available to choose from? Create your own with (almost) no limits!

Don't like how the game plays? Use mutators to change almost every aspect of the game in a way that fits YOUR playstyle!

Don't want to play alone? Play with up to three other friends online!

Oh, but you love couch co-op, don't you? This game has you covered there, as well!

Wait, you don't like the level layouts? Oh, well a freakin' level editor just got released!

I could go on and on about what the game is about, and what you do, but the store page you're on right now does that well enough.

Seriously, I can't find a dang thing to complain about in this game. It's just perfect. At least, if you're into stuff like this! If you're not, still give Streets of Rogue a shot. It's freaking amazing!

Streets of Rogue throws you into the slums, a place filled with many different characters, each with unique roles and characteristics. You're given a goal, which is to make your way up to the high class city from the slums you start out in and the rest is up to you.

You can get to your goal by any means necessary. Go in guns blazing killing everyone and thing in your path, play the civilised route and get through the levels with bartering and negotiation, or become a master thief stealing everything you need to survive.

No matter how you play Streets of Rogue is the game for you.

Also there is the added bonus of being able to play with (or against) friends for even more mayhem and fun.

I highly recommend!

[b]Streets of Rogue[/b] is a great game and one of the best roguelikes, and indie games in general, I've played yet. I remember buying and playing it when it was new to the storefront well over a year ago, and it had much to do even when it was so unfinished. With it finally being released out of Early Access, it's been remarkable to see how far the developers have come and how much stuff has been crammed into the game since, and how much is still being added at the time of this review.

Let's get this out of the way first: [b]This is game plays absolutely nothing like its namesake Streets of Rage (a classic series that I am also fond of, and love the reference).[/b] The only similarities are that they both have you beating up people and have great soundtracks. On that subject though, there's plenty of beating up folks in this game - Your objective is to progress from level to level, each with a few floors, starting from the Slums and hopefully making it all the way to the Mayor's residence. To do this you have to accomplish a few randomly assigned tasks per floor, such as finding X person and taking them the entrance/exit, looting X chest in a hideout, or destroying X amount of a certain object. As you complete objectives and other miscellaneous things, you earn XP which can level up your character, giving you the chance to earn more buffs, as well as providing a full health restoration.

The game is played from a top-down perspective and the best way I can describe the gameplay is like Hotline Miami meets Grand Theft Auto. You by no means are encouraged to go in guns or fists blazing and mow down everyone, but you certainly could. Or you could also choose to be stealthy and complete your goals by means of sabotage and manipulating the enviornment. How you play is up to you in the game does not heavily favor one playstyle. There are so many classes to choose from, each with an optional Big Quest for extra challenge, but if you wish, you can make your own characters to play as, too! You can even change the conditions you'll encounter during your run and insert a seed (string of letters/numbers) to generate a set of levels that way.

Being a rogue, Streets of Rogue is inherently quite challenging, but it's not unfair the vast majority of the time. Most of the time, whenever I died, it was because I jumped into the unknown too quickly, took too long to escape an enemy, or simply made a really dumb mistake. While bad luck can happen in any rogue, I find the player can overcome any obstacle given enough thought and patience. And when I do die and my run ends, I very rarely get super salty - I usually end up laughing at the hilarious circumstances that lead to my death. The dialogue in the game is equally humorous.

There is a lot of content in this game, and it only keeps growing bigger. With literally dozens of characters to choose from, unlimited levels (especially with the new addition of the level editor), and many ways to experiment, if you're fan of rogues in any capacity, I [i]highly[/i] recommend Streets of Rogue. I love both indie games and rogues, and this one is a shining example of a developer's passion and commitment to making a top-grade product - a true Early Access success story.

This game has so many little quirks and traits to each individual character you can play and unlock on the wild ride that is STREETS OF ROGUE, Imagine how good Fried Chicken, and smooth smoking blunts are, that is this game.

[h1]General Impressions[/h1]
Streets of Rogue is an easy-to-play, difficult to master rogue-like that lets you start off as just about any realistic character to a few fantasy ones in the efforts to overthrow the mayor of the town. Each town has three floors to gather your influence, and limitless opportunity to throw shit against the fan.

As someone who's placed about 100 hours into the game, I can say without a doubt that the amount of cheese in this game is plentiful, and it can be amazing. As you start earning different traits, items, and characters through chicken nuggets (Mayor had a mild stomach ache after eating some), you can toggle most of them off to have a nice, consistent gameplay experience. Of course, if any of the pre-selected characters aren't your thing, you can always go through a custom character to meet your needs. 


As far as limitless opportunity goes however, you'll soon start to realize that once you head into Uptown, or the last town before reaching the Mayor, that you might have bitten more than you can chew. When I was playing as the slave master, this became incredibly tedious as the last floor of the town had me escorting some slum dweller towards the entrance while a poisonous pink ooze was eating everything away. One of my playthroughs lasted over 2 hours just from being in this town for that long. 

Matt Dabrowski, the (somehow) living legend developer has since allowed players to develop their own levels. Infinite levels = Infinite Gameplay, all from a free update. It's kind of crazy how this game came together, but it's finally out, and worth playing.

You get a task and then are put in a randomly generated city. How you complete this task is completely up to you. That's Streets of Rogue at its core. And it just works so well! No playthrough is the same as your previous one. The game has a varied rooster of NPCs, all have their likes, their dislikes and random behavior that they perform. Then they are all put in a city and you get to watch the chaos unfold. Or even better, create even more chaos.

[THE GOOD]
- The game is really addictive. While the concept it's simple the execution is great. Generating random cities and NPCs allows you to be as creative as possible when you have to solve tasks that go from just pushing a button in someone's house to assassinating the mayor while he's being guarded by an army of police.
- There's a huge number of items, playable characters, perks, disasters to survive, you can even create your own characters and other than locking achievements for overpowered characters the game really let's you do whatever you please.
- Items have a lot of interactivity with one another, which encourages trial and error. Sure, you could eat that pill of cyanide and die. But you could also put it on the ventilation system and clean a whole building with it. You could contaminate a pool's water. You could serve it on a cocktail. If you have an item think really hard "How else could I use this?"

[THE BAD]
- Minor gripe really, but the random humor it has sometimes makes me sigh. I like random, but not THAT random. Other than that I really can't think of any other negative. The game is chaotic but that's intended.

[ACHIEVEMENTS]
- While the game has co-op all the achievements can be obtained by yourself. Some are a bit difficult but once you learn to play the game it's just a matter of planning and executing.

Overall Streets of Rogue is a game about freedom and chaos. Very addictive and it will get a laugh out of you one way or another. With an Overwhelmingly Positive rating in Steam right now it's a very solid recommendation.

This game is such ridiculous fun. Play as your typical gun or melee weapon-toting character or pick from a variety of others like a vampire who sucks blood for health, a comedian who gains followers through joke-telling, or a gorilla with a gorilla army. There are objectives to meet on each floor, but otherwise you're free to cause chaos and do whatever. I haven't laughed so hard in a game in a while. I mean, have your buddy start a gang war and then you take a pill to get huge and just run over everyone and through walls (angering shopkeepers and police as you go for more chaos) all in pursuit of what may or may not be a ham sandwich in that fridge over there so you don't die, and all while trying to avoid ooze that's destroying the level while your comedian friend is back to knocking on doors and telling jokes in the eye of the storm, so to speak...I almost didn't care if I died because it was just so silly. For real, just play this, you won't regret it.

I love this game so much! It's like this game is a mix between Death Road to Canada and some other game I haven't played (maybe Nuclear Throne?), but on robot steroids. The gameplay is simple, straight to the point, and doesn't require you to do everything in a certain way (but you can if you want to). Each character is so similar that you don't have to learn too many different things to play them and so different that they can make you see each level in a completely new way. 
If the other characters' playstyles don't interest you for whatever reason, you can always make your own. Yes, not only do you get tons of different ways to play, you also get character customization!
If you want to be a gorilla who smashes everyone through walls, a doctor who puts everyone to sleep, or an assassin who is running for mayor you can do that.

I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys roguelikes, being a murder hobo, playing with friends (online or offline), goofs, japes, stealth, or just all around fun

The game wouldn't launch for me. Every time I launched the game, the mouse cursor would change, but the application would freeze. I tried everything from the troubleshooting guide that the developer posts everywhere, but nothing worked. I had to refund it. 

I did go and buy it on Switch instead because of this, and I have to say that the game is great and a lot of fun! I can't give it a thumbs-up on PC though because I could never even get so much as a splash screen to come up. If this issue is ever fixed, I would buy it on PC in a heartbeat, but until then I can't recommend it here.

For the record, I have a decent gaming rig (1080ti, i7-1770k, 32 GB RAM), but I use a 3440x1440 resolution monitor.

Update 11-27-2019:
Today I bought a new game and I was having a similar launch issue that I could not resolve again. After remembering this issue from t his game, I decided to do a clean install of Windows on my PC, and after that I was able to launch that game. 
In short, I changed my review because I do not blame the game for it not starting. There must have been something interfering from my computer. Sorry for the thumbs down! Like I said before, I bought it on Switch and love this game!

This is the best game I have played in a long time. I have several friends I've descibed Streets of Rogue to and they've scoffed - but then they've played the game and they understand now.

You choose one of many amazing (and ridiculous) characters and run around a procedurally generated building, trying to complete some random tasks in order to go up to the next floor. It's not going to be easy, but it's going to be fun. It feels like there are 100 different ways you can play this game. You can stealth your way through or just come out guns (or fists, or shrink ray) blazing. But no matter what, you will suffer consequences. Awesome, insane consequences. Survive, and you just might earn enough chicken nuggets to buy something cool in the lobby. 

Developed by just one guy. He did an awesome job. This game is technically "early access" but he's fine tuning it pretty regularly AND I have to say it is definitely ready to play. Do it alone or local or online multiplayer. Just do it.

EDIT: Out of early access and -- surprise -- it still rules, but it's even more polished now. GET THIS.

There is an INCREDIBLE amount of variety in the way you can play the game. Brute-force gorilla? Check. Merciful, pacifist doctor? Done. Want to possess people? Not a problem. There are so many ways you can customize your playthrough to different playstyles.

 Rogue-likes are normally not my thing, but I checked this out and boy am I in love with it. And to think this game is still in early access? I can't WAIT to see what's in store in the upcoming months and years.

Buy this game and show it some love, please.

Update: As of many months later, the dev continues to talk regularly with the community and add to this game. Truly the perfect example of what all indie games and dev should strive to be.

This is a great game. After sinking over 150 hours in it (that's my record!) I can say that I'm not bored and won't be in the nearest future. It's a roguelike game, which takes place in a vertically-built cyberpunk city. Every floor, you have to do 2-3 objectives. You can complete them in many ways. Sneaking in or shooting everyone is just a little part of the options to finish them. There are 5 districts, every one with other, original style. Each has got 3 levels. On the end of a district, things get really complicated, and you have to do your missions quickly to survive. But even the "complications" can be used for completing missions. And now a few words about the gameplay. It's never grindy (you can grind if you want, but you don't have to. You'll get everything in this game without ever a minute of grinding!). And, well, you can do almost everything. Raid a bank or secret labolatory (and free some gorillas in there!), hack everything as Hacker, silently neutralize people with chloroform as Doctor, try to finish your favourite character's Big Quest (that's not as easy as you might think at the beginning...), or, like it's written in the description, become a giant gorilla and smash everything. All on your way to seize the control over the City, ruled by villainous Mayor...

PS.: By the way, even though Streets of Rogue has been already released, the developer still updates the game from time to time. For example, recently we got a totally new character with new abilities and traits.

So, I hope I have convinced you to buy SoR. Good luck on your quest to make citizens of the City happy again!

[h1] An Eclectic Roguelike that Rarely Loses its Charm [/h1]

Streets of Rogue is a "unique" roguelike that emphasizes player choice in tackling various missions. Rather than acting as some dungeon-crawler where you stick to one strategy based on the items you get, Streets of Rogue presents every scenario as having multiple options to be completed. You can go in guns blazing by burning everyone with a flamethrower, or sneak in and hack the turent systems to eliminate the guards without lifting a finger. You collect "chicken nuggets" as you complete the missions that act as a currency to buy new items to assist you in your quest to kill the mayor. Some of these items provide unconventional solutions to the missions, and there is a huge variety of them. You can choose a class when starting the game, and unlock each through special objectives. Each class have their own special objective, that "upgrades" them (this is optional). Many play similarly, but some, such as the gorilla and the zombie, can result in very different play styles.

The game is riddled with humor and can get pretty chaotic, which some may find difficult. The game also has several mutators, which can make the game easier or even more hectic for you (I almost exclusively play with the zombie one). The story is practically non-existent (the mayor is bad, stop him) and the missions themselves are generic and can become repetitive (fetch quest, save person, kill people, press buttons). Overall, however, the game still maintains its charm through its random level-design and making use of new methods through the sometimes-wacky items. It's hard not to recommend this game to fans of the genre, or even those interested in trying it out instead of more difficult ones like Enter the Gungeon.

[h1] Pros: [/h1]
[list]
[*]Addictive gameplay
[*]Procedurally generated maps lead to a high replay value
[*]Vast variety of fun items to try out
[*]Good dose of humor
[*]Simplistic yet appealing pixel art style
[/list]
[h1] Cons: [/h1]
[list]
[*]Repetitive quests
[*]Little variation in some of the characters
[*]Some of the Big Quests have very finicky goals
[*]I feel like the environments (and music) could be a little more varied, instead of seeing the same "locations" over and over again
[*]Too much water in the downtown levels
[/list]

[b] Verdict: 9/10 [/b]

Streets of Rogue is an extremely fun game. It is deceptively simple looking, but has so many options it's hard to keep track of. There are like two dozen characters to play as, custom character creation, multiplayer, level editors... this game is bizarrely deep. You can tackle problems in myriad ways; go stealthy, sneak around! Shoot the place up! Turn everyone into zombies! Do what you want. As long as you complete your tasks, your methods are valid.

You can't be blamed for looking at this game and thinking it's another goofy indie pixel art garbage heap, but the simplicity of the visuals is part of why everything works in a way that's hard to explain. Just play this game. It's fun.

This game never seems to get boring. It gets even more fun with friends, as you now have additional strategies to complete missions and also character combinations to work with. It can also present some crazy obstacles to overcome. If you ever get tired of playing with the many pre-made character types you can create your own. I always seem to come back to this game often since the developer keeps adding and tweaking content.
Overall, A pretty fun game. The Devs really take pride in what they do, :)

Streets of Rogue is a game that does exactly as advertised: throws a sequence of randomly assembled levels at the player, gives them a check-list of missions they're required to complete to move on (with the ultimate mission simply being "become the new Mayor") and then allows them to piece together how they'll go about doing that on their own in a very Deus-Ex esque fashion.

Are they going to crack skulls, punch people through entire buildings and leave others with bullet holes at the risk of being unable to diplomatically become the mayor? Are they going to cause only SOME chaos and prefer the way of words, moolah and stealth?

But then comes another bit of magic this game offers: find a certain character class boring to play as? Don't want ooze or time bomb disasters ruining your day in the last levels of every world? Just want to go as crazy as you like? Create your own custom character classes and mess about with the gameplay mutators to handcraft your ideal playthrough. You can be a gun wielding zombie who leads a horde of the shambling infectious undead whose big overarching quest is to make people laugh for Pete's sake!

This game is a great little rogue-like that you can sit down and play in little bursts (it saves at the start of every level) or lose a chunk of hours to when you're on a roll. Most impressively, it doesn't fall into the pitfall a number of its genre compatriots do of routinely feeling impossibly difficult. Even in the runs where I did run into extreme challenges it all still felt feasible and I was able to routinely turn a number of seemingly doomed runs into successful clears.

Bravo, I say.

Surely the best choice in the realtime rogue-like department. Technically it's a top-down 2d twin-stick shooter/slasher with funny physics model, but it's also so much more than this! For an Early Access title the amount of content is already unbelievable - you get a bunch of characters that differ greatly in what they can do & the level of interactivity is plain jaw-dropping - the world around readily answers all your most perverted calls, letting you perform things you couldn't imagine doing even in a computer game! In this sense Streets of Rogue can only be compared to GTA series.

How bout taking a 'giantizer' pill, temporarily become a human godzilla & walk over a police station & a hospital while cops madly blaze their shotguns around & unintentionally kill all the panicked patients? Or take a 'miniaturizer' & walk freely below deadly lazer traps in high-security buildings. It's genre is close to 'Enter the Gungeon' or 'Synthetic' for example, but the levels depict neutral city life, so it's much broader in available methods, not just kill-em-all - theft, intimidation, starting fights between conflicting NPCs & other hilarious sabotaging with the help of found gadgets, which are plenty.

As a rougue-like it's quite classic - there's permadeath with meta-progression (unlockables between the runs) & different global quests for every character type. All in all, it's addicting as hell & deserves 100% recommendation!!!

This game is incredible! I felt like I had all of the freedom of a game of DnD in a rogue like, randomly generated world. 
Do you want to hack a TV, turn up the volume, and make it explode - You can do that
Do you want to freeze a person on train tracks and watch them get smashed - You can do that
Do you want to be Robert Downey Jr. - Possessing people's bodies and "acting" when you have a drug addiction - You can do that
Do you want to be a gorilla, Open a barrel of monkeys, and watch tiny gorillas punch everyone in the street - You can do that. 
Do you want to be a robot that enslaves people and then eats human flesh to survive - You can do that. 
Do you want to be a wrestler that challenges people to fits, and after you punch someone to death they rise again as a zombie - Yup you can do that too. 
Do you want to shot someone with a water gun, and watch them grow 40x their size killing everyone they step on and destroying buildings - Oh yeah!
Most importantly - Do you want to do anything you imagine with 3 of your friends also doing whatever they can imagine at the same time! Heck yes. 

The options on what you can do are limitless. The custom character creation lets you make any wild build you can imagine.
The comedy in this game always keeps me laughing. The items in this game have inspired several DnD items in my own campaigns. This game is easily one of the best co-op experiences around.

Once upon a midnight dreary, while I pondered, weak and weary,
Over many a quaint and curious volume of forgotten lore—
    While I nodded, nearly napping, suddenly there came a tapping,
As of some one gently rapping, rapping at my chamber door.
“’Tis some visitor,” I muttered, “tapping at my chamber door—
            Only this and nothing more.”

    Ah, distinctly I remember it was in the bleak December;
And each separate dying ember wrought its ghost upon the floor.
    Eagerly I wished the morrow;—vainly I had sought to borrow
    From my books surcease of sorrow—sorrow for the lost Lenore—
For the rare and radiant maiden whom the angels name Lenore—
            Nameless here for evermore.

    And the silken, sad, uncertain rustling of each purple curtain
Thrilled me—filled me with fantastic terrors never felt before;
    So that now, to still the beating of my heart, I stood repeating
    “’Tis some visitor entreating entrance at my chamber door—
Some late visitor entreating entrance at my chamber door;—
            This it is and nothing more.”

    Presently my soul grew stronger; hesitating then no longer,
“Sir,” said I, “or Madam, truly your forgiveness I implore;
    But the fact is I was napping, and so gently you came rapping,
    And so faintly you came tapping, tapping at my chamber door,
That I scarce was sure I heard you”—here I opened wide the door;—
            Darkness there and nothing more.

    Deep into that darkness peering, long I stood there wondering, fearing,
Doubting, dreaming dreams no mortal ever dared to dream before;
    But the silence was unbroken, and the stillness gave no token,
    And the only word there spoken was the whispered word, “Lenore?”
This I whispered, and an echo murmured back the word, “Lenore!”—
            Merely this and nothing more.

    Back into the chamber turning, all my soul within me burning,
Soon again I heard a tapping somewhat louder than before.
    “Surely,” said I, “surely that is something at my window lattice;
      Let me see, then, what thereat is, and this mystery explore—
Let my heart be still a moment and this mystery explore;—
            ’Tis the wind and nothing more!”

    Open here I flung the shutter, when, with many a flirt and flutter,
In there stepped a stately Raven of the saintly days of yore;
    Not the least obeisance made he; not a minute stopped or stayed he;
    But, with mien of lord or lady, perched above my chamber door—
Perched upon a bust of Pallas just above my chamber door—
            Perched, and sat, and nothing more.

Then this ebony bird beguiling my sad fancy into smiling,
By the grave and stern decorum of the countenance it wore,
“Though thy crest be shorn and shaven, thou,” I said, “art sure no craven,
Ghastly grim and ancient Raven wandering from the Nightly shore—
Tell me what thy lordly name is on the Night’s Plutonian shore!”
            Quoth the Raven “Nevermore.”

    Much I marvelled this ungainly fowl to hear discourse so plainly,
Though its answer little meaning—little relevancy bore;
    For we cannot help agreeing that no living human being
    Ever yet was blessed with seeing bird above his chamber door—
Bird or beast upon the sculptured bust above his chamber door,
            With such name as “Nevermore.”

    But the Raven, sitting lonely on the placid bust, spoke only
That one word, as if his soul in that one word he did outpour.
    Nothing farther then he uttered—not a feather then he fluttered—
    Till I scarcely more than muttered “Other friends have flown before—
On the morrow he will leave me, as my Hopes have flown before.”
            Then the bird said “Nevermore.”

    Startled at the stillness broken by reply so aptly spoken,
“Doubtless,” said I, “what it utters is its only stock and store
    Caught from some unhappy master whom unmerciful Disaster
    Followed fast and followed faster till his songs one burden bore—
Till the dirges of his Hope that melancholy burden bore
            Of ‘Never—nevermore’.”

    But the Raven still beguiling all my fancy into smiling,
Straight I wheeled a cushioned seat in front of bird, and bust and door;
    Then, upon the velvet sinking, I betook myself to linking
    Fancy unto fancy, thinking what this ominous bird of yore—
What this grim, ungainly, ghastly, gaunt, and ominous bird of yore
            Meant in croaking “Nevermore.”

    This I sat engaged in guessing, but no syllable expressing
To the fowl whose fiery eyes now burned into my bosom’s core;
    This and more I sat divining, with my head at ease reclining
    On the cushion’s velvet lining that the lamp-light gloated o’er,
But whose velvet-violet lining with the lamp-light gloating o’er,
            She shall press, ah, nevermore!

    Then, methought, the air grew denser, perfumed from an unseen censer
Swung by Seraphim whose foot-falls tinkled on the tufted floor.
    “Wretch,” I cried, “thy God hath lent thee—by these angels he hath sent thee
    Respite—respite and nepenthe from thy memories of Lenore;
Quaff, oh quaff this kind nepenthe and forget this lost Lenore!”
            Quoth the Raven “Nevermore.”

    “Prophet!” said I, “thing of evil!—prophet still, if bird or devil!—
Whether Tempter sent, or whether tempest tossed thee here ashore,
    Desolate yet all undaunted, on this desert land enchanted—
    On this home by Horror haunted—tell me truly, I implore—
Is there—is there balm in Gilead?—tell me—tell me, I implore!”
            Quoth the Raven “Nevermore.”

    “Prophet!” said I, “thing of evil!—prophet still, if bird or devil!
By that Heaven that bends above us—by that God we both adore—
    Tell this soul with sorrow laden if, within the distant Aidenn,
    It shall clasp a sainted maiden whom the angels name Lenore—
Clasp a rare and radiant maiden whom the angels name Lenore.”
            Quoth the Raven “Nevermore.”

    “Be that word our sign of parting, bird or fiend!” I shrieked, upstarting—
“Get thee back into the tempest and the Night’s Plutonian shore!
    Leave no black plume as a token of that lie thy soul hath spoken!
    Leave my loneliness unbroken!—quit the bust above my door!
Take thy beak from out my heart, and take thy form from off my door!”
            Quoth the Raven “Nevermore.”

    And the Raven, never flitting, still is sitting, still is sitting
On the pallid bust of Pallas just above my chamber door;
    And his eyes have all the seeming of a demon’s that is dreaming,
    And the lamp-light o’er him streaming throws his shadow on the floor;
And my soul from out that shadow that lies floating on the floor
            Shall be lifted—nevermore!
One of a kind.

do you remember playing console games as a child and finding a secret? a secret area, a hidden character, a way to manipulate the game that the developers hid from you and rewarded you for figuring out? it was the best feature of the 8- and 16- bit eras. streets of rogue essentially takes this dynamic and makes an entire game out of it. the missions are pretty straightforward, and you choose a character from one of the professions (only some are available until you unlock others,) and use that profession's quirks to complete the missions. this is hardly and adequate description of the game, but i highly recommend it. it provides hours of fun, and updates keep rolling out.
There is so much to do, so many modifiers, so many characters, and its getting updated all the time. 10/10 Easy Buy.
Amazing game love it please keep updating.

I would strongly recommend this game. It's challenging and the RNG leads to some genuine hilarious moments especially when random fights break out amongst NPCs.  I've been mostly been playing as the hacker which is one of the more tactical player characters- challenging and fun working out what to hack.

Only negatives are- windows 10's numerous security 'features' wouldn't let save games write to the C drive and I've never had this issue with another Steam Game. Disasters are over powered making some levels completely unplayable- this isn't something you can overcome by 'gitting gud' as the riot disaster will kill rescue targets at the other end of the level map within a few seconds of starting the level- not fun nor rewarding.  This is easily fixable by turning disasters off at the homebase screen.

A really great game with a lot of depth - characters are balanced and require some time getting to know their loadouts and strengths. The SNES era 16 bit RPG graphics are great as is the extremely catchy music.
Great 8-Bit action!

A great 'little' game that combines a quirky humor, with properly done LD-graphics and a simple, yet very satisfying gameplay.

As well, a perfect positive example for a developer who puts his heart and soul into a game, yet listens to the community and works tirelessly to polish this gem of roguelike games.

As well, provides a hilariously entertaining coop mode.

Honestly, just grab it, I doubt there's a single sane person on the planet that wouldn't enjoy the game.
I played this aboard the pirate ship, and then i came ashore to buy it. I enjoyed every second of it, and i hope you will too. Please buy it. It is fun, smart, captivating game, that never bores you.

It's quite impressive how much depth there is to this game. It's got a ton of playable characters, each with their own skills, traits, and personal "Big Quest" to fulfill on top of the standard objectives on each floor. 

You can complete most quests in the game in a variety of ways; if you have to "Neutralize" an NPC, you can kill them with your weapons, or you could talk to them and ask them or threaten them to leave, and that will fulfill the quest if successful! The randomized city and the tons of character variety will give you endless hours of fun in your quest to overthrow the Mayor!

It's the strangest thing. A roguelike that isn't an unbalanced RNG mess.

Streets Of Rogue offers so many options in how to tackle objectives that even if one option is unbalanced there are always other options. Can't steal? Kill everyone. Can't kill everyone cause they're too powerful? Poison them. There's no vent to put the poison in? Go buy a giant pill that turns you into a giant and makes you way OP for 15 seconds. Got an item to turn enemies into friendlies? Use that and go in and convince them through dialogue to leave. 

Every area in the game (it has 5 + 1 bonus boss level) has a distinct look, generation and obstacles to overcome or exploit. It's very simple with its graphics and detail and it makes everything stand out so you can easily see what's going on. A muckload of items, be it weapons, healing, armor, tools, throwing stuff or chems so the game has a lot of little secrets to uncover and figure out how to exploit. It has a ton of playable characters that differ vastly in playstyle and has a super version which can be unlocked by completing an overarching big quest throughout the campaign.

And it's still being developed, even now that it is officially out it is still being worked on and added to. We just got a level editor in the beta which shows a lot of promise in its ease to use and customization.

When i first played it the game looked like it was bad, unfinished, and not worth it. But i barely scratched the surface. with about 30 different characters, each with their unique playstyle, stats and abilities, a bunch of helpful items, challenging quests and disasters that can go horribly wrong if not treated carefully, streets of rogue is an amazing replayable stealth action shooter with so much to offer. give it a try!
